text:
Sections

The Indigenous Tradition
Hispanic Traditions and Transformations
American Traditions and Transformations
Philippine Dance During the Third Republic (1946-72)
Philippine Dance During the Fourth Republic (1972-86)
Philippine Dance During the Fifth Republic (1986 Onward)

There is a dazzling diversity of dance in the Philippines because of the country’s geography, history, and ethnicities. The landscape has greatly contributed to this variety of expressions in ritual, social, occupational, and mimetic dances. Many of these dances reflect their locales’ environment and social milieu while some are linked to regional epic and poetic literatures articulated in the people’s choreographic formulations. There are also some acknowledged influences from other Asian countries. On the other hand, the colonial experiences introduced Western choreographic expressions to the Philippines. Spain brought its own devotional, social, and theatrical dances and those of its European neighbors. When the Americans established themselves in the country at the turn of the century, they brought in more social and theatrical dances, especially in the popular genres with some from the Caribbean Islands. During both colonial periods, the indigenous peoples continued their own dances that reflected their beliefs and occupations. These expressions had particular ways of engaging with foreign influences and colonial realities. With the increased interest in indigenous cultures, more researchers started to explore the rich terrain of indigenous dances in the 20th century. After the country gained independence, postcolonial Philippines continued to witness the dynamic life of Philippine dance as more transformations occurred in the forms introduced during the colonial eras and as new ones emerged and enjoyed popularity in the country. The first fifteen years of the 21st century saw the vitality of Philippine dance as it interacted not just with sociopolitical, economic, and cultural forces, but also with the rapid changes in technology. The trajectory of Philippine dance has shown how this cultural expression has always and will always be a living form, with a strong pulse that creatively responds to the beat of the nation.

 

The Indigenous Tradition

 

Many of the ethnic tribes have been in the Philippines for many millennia. Their survival through years of colonial invasions has been due to their hardy industry, as witnessed by the rice terraces of the Cordilleras, or to their indomitable spirit, as exemplified by the desire for political independence of the Muslims in the south. Their spirit for survival has also been inspired and strengthened by animistic beliefs and shamanistic leadership. Close and familiar as the people were with their environment which to them possessed mysteries and potencies that had to be courted or propitiated, the people created rituals and incantations to the divine Bathala or Laon, to the diwata or spirits of the mountains, rivers or trees, or to the anito or spirits of ancestors who may either curse or bless their descendants.

 

 

In the north, the mambunong or katalonan, and in the south, the balyan or babaylan, took on priestly duties offering rituals to assure a good harvest, to cure the sick or to ensure success in war. Many rites were meant to get in touch with the spiritual world that is related to the psychic resources and needs of the people—like the pagdiwata of Palawan which involves offerings during a festival to solicit a good harvest; the lapal among the Subanon which is meant to communicate with the diwata of the forest; the dugso among the Higaonon which is a thanksgiving ritual for a bountiful harvest, the birth of a male child or for victory in war; the cañao in the Cordilleras during which a chicken, pig, or carabao may be sacrificed; and the sanghiyang of Alfonso, Cavite which is the ritual dance over fire.

The geographic locations of the indigenous groups greatly influence the kind of work they engage in. With zestful spontaneity and resourcefulness, the ethnic Filipinos continue to express themselves directly, and with unrestrained humor and easy joyfulness in work or play. As a consequence, many tasks are turned into dances of communal fun. The rice culture is replete with dances of seeding, planting, harvesting, threshing, winnowing, and pounding. The Isneg of the north mime the same process with a bamboo pole as prop and add an enacted lullaby. The Bagobo of the south also imitate rice or corn planting. Fetching water among the Kalinga maidens becomes a stylized display of skill in balancing pots on their heads, a singular feat for a people living in the varied terrain of the mountains.

Those close to the sea enact fishing—with a net in pasigin in Aklan, and in mangingisda, or with handheld fishtraps in pandanggo sa bulig,the last two from Bocaue, Bulacan; with a spear in agpanikop among the Manobo, and in tawti among the Sama and Tausug; and with bare hands in kin-naras in Ilocos. To signal the shore to the fisherfolk at night, the oasioas is dexterous in flinging to and fro lighted glasses wrapped in large kerchiefs, which create a twinkling constellation of grace. There are many more occupational dances on cotton beating, spinning, weaving, basket making, pot making, and broom making. Gold panning is demonstrated in the pabirik from Bicol.

For spiritual blessings, in defending themselves and their territories, for revenge or victory, the people created even more dances. In the sagayan, elaborate headdresses, the kris(a Muslim sword), and a shield underscore the bravery of the Maranao. If work or war is imaginatively turned into dance, the surrounding animal life also lends itself to imitative dances that are both graphic and symbolic. After all, men, women, animals, plants, and the surroundings are one in nature. A sense of playful communion is inherent in the Blaan dance imitating squirrels called kinugsik-kugsik. Other animals that inspire imitation arethe fish among the Yakan in tahing baila, the crab among the Capiznon in inalimango,the snake among the people of Meycauayan, Bulacan in culebra, and the fireflies among the Batangueño in alitaptap.As the Philippines is a bird country, it has a great number of dances depicting birds, including poultry. The pabo is an imitation of the turkey, the itik-itik of the duck, the kalapati or sinalampati of doves, and, the most famous of them all, the tinikling of thetiklingbirds which farmers try to trap because they prey on the rice fields.

There are also a number of hawk dances—the kinabua among the Mandaya, the man-manaok among the Manobo, the banog-banog among the Blaan, and the binaylan among the Higaonon. Dancers of the Kalinga courtship dance salip or the Bontoc pinanyowan look like swooping birds of the highlands.

Among certain groups, dance could also dramatize popular narratives. To the Maranao, for instance, a choreographed elaboration on the epic Darangen has the hero Bantugan pursuing a princess, Gandingan, during a supposed earthquake. Today, the singkil reenacts this scene in a climactic crescendo of clashing crisscrossed bamboo poles.

Indigenous dances have been affected by the changing times. The performances of many of these dances are mostly of theatrical nature especially in urban centers and no longer integrated into the daily lives of the indigenous folk. Continued practice of and interest in indigenous dance traditions need to be encouraged through research and performance of these gestural treasures to deepen the understanding of Filipino identity and ingenuity.

 

Hispanic Traditions and Transformations

With the coming of the Spaniards and the spread of Christianity, the people transferred the object of their worship to the saints, though they did not completely abandon their native impulse and style. Animistic rituals were injected with Catholic doctrine, symbols, and saints while movement traditions were given new musical accompaniment in church songs and recited verses. With many occasions to celebrate, like the feasts of the local patron saints, of the Virgin Mary, and Christ’s birth, death, and resurrection, Christianity turned native to a certain extent and became a vehicle for the Filipino way of spiritual and communal expression.

Folkloric expression adheres in the dance veneration of the Nuestra Señora de los Dolores in the turumba of Pakil, Laguna; in the pandanggo or fertility dance for the Nuestra Señora de Salambao, Santa Clara and San Pascual in Obando, Bulacan; in the worship of the Santo Niño in the sinulog in Bohol and Cebu; in the rhythmic movements of the ati-ati in Aklan and Cuyo; and in the subli for the Santa Cruz in Batangas. Indigenous practices are the roots of these religious celebrations whose devotion have shifted to Christian personages, objects, and beliefs.

Foreign influences from countries other than Spain found their way to Philippine soil through the heightened socioeconomic and cultural exchange encouraged by the Acapulco-Manila galleon trade. Supposedly from Mexico is the dance called pastores de belen which is about the visit of the shepherds to Jesus’s stable in Bethlehem. As it survives in Bicol and Cebu, the pastoresis very secular in color and gaiety.

At the salubong enacting the encounter betweenthe sorrowful Mater Dolorosa and the Risen Christ on Easter morning, the child-angel lowered from a scaffold lifts the veil of sorrow from the image of the Virgin Mary. In the dance bati, which means “greeting,” the resurrection of Christ is welcomed by individuals who wave flags, dance, and create music.

Performed to honor town patron saints like Santiago Matamoros, the moros y cristianos is a dance that depicts the fight between Christians and Moors. Similarly, the palo-palo of Ivana, Batanes is danced with cane sticks; and the maglalatik with coconut shells (latikor condensed coconut milk) of Biñan, Laguna enact the same theme. Today these dances display the men’s agility, a contest between two camps costumed in different colors.

As the Spanish government imposed itself on the people and the latter were proselytized into Christianity, the European way of life filtered down into the people’s social and economic activities. There was an empowerment of the Filipino elite. Social dances of the West found performance platforms in the grand celebrations hosted by wealthy families replacing indigenous practices. In social functions, the French quadrillecalled rigodondehonor (or its subsequent American equivalent, virginia )highlighted balls in ordinary towns and cities, as well as in Malacañan Palace. These secular events completed the feast days, celebrated the trips of the galleons across the Pacific or welcomed a new governor general or bishop. Another social dance performed during weddings is the mascota where plates are set for gifts of money. This dance was adopted by the Ibanag of Cagayan and Isabela.

Other dances popular during the Spanish period were European dances like the minuet, locally known as minueto;the cachucha,locally called katsutsa; fandango, popularly called pandanggo;the jota; the polka; the mazurka; the valse, known as balse; the schottische, locally called escotis; and even the zapateado, locally called pateado. All of these underwent regional transformation in the colony, evident in the variations of the jota from northern Cagayan to the southern provinces. As they became localized, these dances gained regional characteristics, adapting bamboo, coconut, or shell castanets, scented handkerchiefs, andpaypay(native fans). Musical accompaniment was also indigenized through a variety of native instruments.

Dances about love, courtship, and marriage abound in the islands. In these dances many devices used are really ploys—a blanket, a scarf, a handkerchief, a fan, a hat, and even a plate or a drinking glass. Traditionally, the female dancer is meant to be modest and undemonstrative; thus, these ploys help in the subterfuge. The male dancer is expected to be aggressive, resourceful, naughty even. Among the Tagalog, kerchiefs are used foralcamfor(a scent) and in the sayaw sa pag-ibig. Fans are flirtation props in the cariñosa and the putritos, as hats are in the pandanggo sa sambalilo. In Bohol, a boy offers a saucer in the pingan-pingan pino.

In the Zambales sinambali and the Bicol pantomina, coins are showered on a wedding couple. There is even a dance between a male and a female, spurned by their respective beloveds, who luckily find each other in the timawa from Capiz or among the guerilla fighters in the voluntario from Iloilo. A classic wedding dance is the habanera botoleña from Zambales, an elegant transformation of a dance from Cuba.

Lowland folk dances continued to be performed until the American period but were slowly threatened by the spread of American culture.

 

 

 

American Traditions and Transformations

On 12 Jun 1898, the Filipinos declared independence from Spain but by December of that same year, Spain had sold the islands to the United States of America, which set out to crush the Philippine Republic in order to establish itself as the new colonizer of the Philippines. Inevitably, the American cultural infusions came in. Most pervasive was the use of English as medium of instruction in schools. It was first dispensed by visiting Americans and later by Filipinos sent to the US aspensionados(scholars).

A most popular entertainment was the vaudeville brought to the country in the 1930s and 1940s by foreign artists who taught the Filipinos different kinds of dances such as the fox-trot, cakewalk, tap dance, and the charleston. Eventually, Filipinos took center stage, replaced the imported performers, and in time, vaudeville combined foreign and local talents, themes, and tastes. It was thus localized and called the bodabil. This kind of mix resulted in creating local counterparts of American originals, such as the dancing pair Bayani Casimiro and Nieves Manuel, the “Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers of the Philippines.” During World War II, the formulaic bodabilformat dominated movie houses which were prohibited from showing American movies. This time, it included a drama and dance at the end and became known as the stage show. The visiting groups brought in by the Japanese performed at Manila’s Metropolitan Theater. At the end of World War II, the country’s stage and television shows were influenced by the popularity of Broadway and Hollywood performer Gene Kelly who danced tap, jazz, and ballet in his films.

The social dances from America, like the fox-trot, cakewalk, ragtime, slow drag and tango,raged on and went into clubs and cabarets with the prominent in society. Meanwhile, the earlier balse, pandanggo, polka, and mazurka from the Spanish period continued in rural areas.

Local ballet took ground with visits of foreign troupes, like the Russian Baroufski Ballet Circus with ladies in pink tights in 1902, or the visit of Anna Pavlova in 1922 that inspired Anita Kane, whose migrant father worked in the Paracale mines in Camarines Norte. Kane is credited with choreographing the first full-length ballet Mariang Makiling to original music by Ramon Tapales in 1939. Luva Adameit, a Polish-Russian, came in 1927 and stayed in the Philippines all her life. From her came the country’s first prominent dancers like Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, Remedios de Oteyza, Rosalia Merino-Santos, Inday Gaston-Mañosa, and Joji Felix-Velarde. They became choreographers, with Orosa-Goquingco merging native themes and dances with ballet technique and aesthetics.

“ Free dance,” which referred to any departure from ballet’s classicism and later named modern dance, was already seen with Ada Delroy in the vaudeville circuit. While there were other exponents, the most significant was Trudl Dubsky-Zipper who ran three seasons at the Manila Metropolitan Theater with her Manila Ballet Moderne from 1939 to 1940. She drew in both folk and ballet dancers to realize her range in repertoire. During the war and postwar years, she left an indelible influence on many, including those who later moved to the academe.

But even as these new forms of dance were being introduced from the West, indigenous and folk dances continued to be performed in the hinterlands and the rural areas. Various indigenous groups from north to south kept on with their own ritual, occupational, and imitative dances that addressed and reflected their daily lives and animistic beliefs. In Christianized areas, there prevailed dances linked to religious devotions, like the pandanggo in Bulacan, turumba (tripping-like) in Pakil, the bati (greeting) in Antipolo, the sinulog (like water-surge) in Cebu, ati-atihan (imitating the native Aetas) in Aklan, and the varieties of the pastores (shepherds) in Bicol and in other Philippine islands.

Francisca Reyes-Tolentino (later Aquino) was determined to save Filipino folk dances from the incursions of the Americans and the Jazz Age. Encouraged by the project of recovering Filipino art works by University of the Philippines (UP) president Jorge Bocobo, she went out to the field with musician Antonino Buenaventura and her husband-photographer Ramon Tolentino to find and record the indigenous and folk dances of the Filipinos. The multifarious and far-reaching results of her efforts include: the formation of the UP Folk Song and Dance Club in 1937 for the dissemination of knowledge on and performances of folk dances; the publication of her research findings in the Philippines and in the United States before and after World War II; and the encouragement of further regional researches that followed in her wake. Her influence was pervasive in physical education and dance research, the latter institutionalized through the Philippine Folk Dance Society in 1945. Ultimately, Philippine dances won local adherents among public school teachers.

 

Philippine Dance During the Third Republic (1946–72)

Philippine dance reflected the nation’s neocolonial condition and realities following World War II and after gaining independence from the United States. During this period, Americanization permeated education and media. Fulbright scholarships facilitated the immersion of Filipino scholars to artistic trends in the West resulting in Filipino dancers training abroad through scholarships. The rise of mass media facilitated the entry of colonial cultural imports in the country. In theater, transitions were apparent as dance shifted from theatrical stage to the media platform. Broadway musicals, popular in the late 1950s to 1970s, were made into films and shown in the Philippines.

But even as American cultural influences flooded the country once more, Philippine dance sought to accommodate or appropriate these foreign forms and harness them for the expression of Filipino themes. Thus the Filipinization of various cultural imports prevailed during the period.

Meanwhile, major global events such as the start of the Cold War and the Cultural Revolution in China affected the sociopolitical events in the country. In the late 1960s, there was a rise in student activism and widespread demonstrations against imperialism and corruption in government. Dance in this period was utilized to promote ideological goals for mass movement. As a result, revolutionary-themed plays, skits, and musicals were featured in street rallies and protests which highlighted the tumultuous history of the period.

With global mobility due to advancements in transportation, various foreign performers introduced ballet immediately after World War II to the 1960s, and mentored local dancers who later shaped the form to suit the Philippine cultural mold. With the establishment of ballet schools in the capital and also in the regions, ballet performances were transformed and developed to express native dance themes and styles. Anita Kane was influential with her Filipinist ballet such as Mutya ng Dagat (Muse of the Sea), Inulan sa Pista (Rained-out Feast), and Aswang. Two of Orosa-Goquingco’s known productions incorporating indigenous themes were Noli Dance Suite and Filipinescas: Philippine Life, Legend, and Lore in Dance. From the late 1960s to the 1970s, the Hariraya Dance Company, under the direction of Remedios de Oteyza and Inday Gaston-Mañosa mounted Legend of Sarimanok and Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird) while Dance Theater Philippines (DTP) produced Katakataka Sin Rajah Indarapatra (Stories of Rajah Indarapatra), Babae at Lalake (Woman and Man), Zagalas de Manila (Young Maidens of Manila), Kalingan, and Tanan (Elopement).

Following the performances of foreign companies in Manila and the proliferation of local ballet instructors, choreographers established ballet schools such as the School of Classic Dance of Anita Kane and the Classic Ballet Academy of de Oteyza which both opened in 1947. In the 1950s, the Manila Ballet Academy was considered the biggest among all the dance schools in the Philippines. The Hariraya Dance Company of Gaston-Mañosa was established in 1968, and Vella Damian’s School of Ballet and Dance Arts, in 1969. In other parts of the country, Carmen Dakudao Locsin opened her Locsin Dance Workshop in Davao in 1947 and Fe Sala-Villarica established the Cebu Ballet Center in 1951.

Likewise, modern dance flourished through the initiative of foreign choreographers and local adherents who incorporated indigenous expression into the modern dance style. Spanish modern dancer Manolo Rosado’s choreographed pieces based on folk traditions and history were The Debutant, The Fisherman and the Mermaid, and Ultimo Adios (Last Farewell). Rosalia Merino (later Santos) had Filipino subject matter in her Of Cocks and Kings, Ugaling Pilipino (Filipino Attitudes), and Sari Manok. But it was Alice Reyes’s establishment of her Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company and its performance of Amada, 1970, that further strengthened the foothold of modern dance in the Philippines.

The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), inaugurated in 1969, served as an important venue for staging ballet, modern dance, and other cultural shows. Other cultural establishments during the period include the FEU Auditorium, the University of the Philippines (UP) Theater, Mapua Auditorium, Araneta Coliseum, Rizal Theater, Philam Life Auditorium, Meralco Theater, Folk Arts Theater, and the Manila Film Center.

With the entry and popularity of foreign dances, there persisted a threat to Philippine folk dances, despite their continued relevance in local communities. Folk dancer and researcher Francisca Reyes (now Aquino), who led the documentation of Philippine folk dances since the 1930s, expanded her scope of work, coming out with local and international publications like Philippine National Dances, Dance Steps for All Occasions, Philippine Folk Dances and Songs,and the six-volume Philippine Folk Dance, from 1945 to the 1970s. She established the Filipiniana Folk Dance Society in 1949 and was a key figure in setting up the Philippine Folk Dance Society. Due to her contributions in enriching Philippine folk dance, Aquino received the Ramon Magsaysay Award in 1963 and was named first National Artist in dance in 1973. Furthering Aquino’s aim to preserve folk dances, national and regional researchers also documented, performed, and popularized folk dances in different parts of the country.

Philippine folk dance achieved its renaissance in the 1950s when various folk dance troupes were recognized in the international stage. In 1958, the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company successfully represented the country at the Brussels Universal Exposition. Their achievement was soon followed by other local dance troupes such as the Far Eastern University (FEU) Folk Dance Troupe, the Leyte Filipiniana Dance Troupe, the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group (ROFG), and many other local dance troupes. There were also several university-based folk dance troupes established between the 1940s and 1970s: the University of the Philippines’s UP Folk Song and Club Troupe, the Philippine Normal College’s (PNC) Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe, the Leyte State University’s Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company, the Mindanao State University’s Darangan Cultural Troupe, and the University of Santo Tomas’s Salinggawi Dance Troupe. The popularity of folk dancing was such that they were featured and incorporated into local films. Later, folk dances were performed in commercial establishments such as hotels and restaurants which signaled its future commercialization.

While rural folks continued to revel in native dances, urban dwellers widely accepted popular American dance trends as part of the vibrant social life during the neocolonial period. Social dances during this period followed the American dance trends and were usually performed inkabaret(dance halls), grand balls at hotels, and gatherings at social clubs. Filipinos were infatuated with the mambo, samba, and cha-cha, as well as camel walk, aqua velva, shiminy, and esalato in the 1940s and 1950s. In the 1960s, the popularization of rhumba, tango, swing, and limborock led to the proliferation of ballroom dancing schools which were mostly found in Quiapo. Television became a major conduit for these social dances from the 1960s to the 1970s. The cha-cha and boogie were popularized in The Nida-Nestor Show while Helen featured the latest dance craze with Helen Gamboa’s signature song and dance “Bang-Shang-A-Lang.” Dance-O-Rama drew attention to a range of dance moves such as the chicken, mashed potatoes, the shovel,and watusi,while Dance Time with Chito featuring Al Quinn, Lito Calzado, and Chito Feliciano further intensified the dance craze. Later trends like the twist, boogaloo, bossa nova, frug, pachanga,and hustle found their way to more TV dance shows.

From the time the Philippines was granted independence to the impending declaration of Martial Law, Philippine dance remained transformative. While it continued to be influenced by Western dance practices, it also sought its own independence and identity. Thus, the Philippine dance scene reflected the paradoxes of the country’s neocolonial experiences which were characterized by the constant interplay of sociocultural forces: localization and internationalization, preservation and adaptation, importation and exportation, and transformation and conservation of the nation’s cultural identity. All these continuously shaped Philippine dance in the succeeding years as the country underwent drastic political and economic upheavals.

 

Philippine Dance During the Fourth Republic (1972-86)

The 1935 Philippine Constitution prohibited a third presidential term but President Ferdinand E. Marcos sought to perpetuate himself in power. The most expedient measure for the continuation of his rule was to declare martial law. The Marcos administration justified the call for a state of emergency because of the widespread violent youth protests, the communist threat, as well as the growing armed secessionist movement among organized Muslim Filipinos. Thus, on 21 Sep 1972, Marcos signed Proclamation No. 1081 placing the whole country under a state of martial law. Press and broadcast media were shut down. Critics and opponents of the government were imprisoned.

Then First Lady Imelda Marcos took the lead in using art and culture to propagate the tenets of the Bagong Lipunan or New Society under the authoritarian regime. The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) became the nerve center of national and international activities in art and culture while the Folk Arts Theater was built in 1974 as a venue for more popular presentations for the masses. Another project with such a goal was the Metropolitan Theater which was restored in 1978. The regime built an art hub outside the National Capital Region called the National Arts Center atop Mt Makiling. This was the site of the Philippine High School for the Arts, built in 1977, which offered academic dance courses to high school scholars.

Western classical dance forms such as ballet and modern dance flourished under martial law. State support became concentrated on select dance companies. In ballet, the main beneficiary was the Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company, subsequently called the CCP Dance Company and renamed Ballet Philippines in 1981. Ballet classics comprised the main offering of CCP as typified by “Aurora’s Wedding” (Act 3 from the Sleeping Beauty ) restaged in 1976 by Gener Caringal, Effie Nañas, Tony Fabella, Lydia Gaston, Eddie Elejar, and Marius Petipa; and the Filipino adaptation of Nutcracker, 1978, created by Alfred Rodrigues, Effie Nañas, Gener Caringal, Armin Wild, and Alice Reyes. Other dance companies such as Dance Theater Philippines and the Hariraya Ballet Company, which no longer enjoyed CCP’s support, pursued their artistic goals by performing at Ballet at the Park and Puerta Real Evenings in Luneta and Intramuros, respectively. Whether supported by the administration or not, artists of ballet and modern dance produced a bountiful harvest of original works drawing inspiration from indigenous culture, Philippine literature, and history. Examples of works during this period are Eddie Elejar’s Kapinangan, 1972; Gener Caringal’s Ang Sultan (The Sultan), 1973; Lydia Gaston’s Anak Bulan (Moon Child), 1976; Alice Reyes’s Rajah Sulayman,1975 and Tales of the Manuvu, 1977; and Cora Iñigo’s Sisa , 1978.

Indigenous and folk dances continued to thrive among Christianized lowland groups as among ethnic groups all over the country. Folk dance groups that stylized elements from these indigenous and folk dances prospered in this period because folkloric and stylized choreography of indigenous dances like the singkil,maglalatik, and the tinikling were popular, because they were exotic. The most prominent dance company under martial law was the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company whose international fame was already undisputed even in the late 1950s. The glamour of Bayanihan performances were effective in promoting the government’s policies and programs. A relatively new dance company, the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group, also enjoyed state support because it had its own niche as being more “authentic” and anthropological in choreography and production design. Meanwhile, tourism as a major program of the regime gave rise to the construction of new venues of folkloric dancing in plush hotels and international convention sites. Tourism promotion in the provinces also initiated the commercialization of street dancing, the classic example of which is the hybridization of the Ati-Atihan into a parade fashioned after the Mardi Gras.

Outside Manila, dance and cultural research flourished, even in places where there were continued military operations such as Southern Philippines. One significant development in dance was the undertaking of Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa who pioneered in the documentation of the dances and related artistic expressions of the Sulu Archipelago. These dances were the pangalay / pansak / igal, the langka or martial style, and the lunsay or song-dance. Up north, the militant struggles of the Cordillera peoples against big government projects such as the Chico River Dam and the Cellophil Resources Corporation led to a strong opposition against the Marcos dictatorship under the Cordillera Peoples’ Alliance. The Cordillera peoples expressed their sentiments through their indigenous dances that upheld their socio-economic-cultural rights and affirmed their struggle for self-determination.

Social dances were propagated through entertainment TV, which was important to show normalcy under a state of military rule. TV dance shows rose in popularity with programs like Discorama and Penthouse. Movie stars like Vilma Santos and Alma Moreno danced in their own variety programs. Disco music and dancing became a craze with the rise of Original Pilipino Music (OPM). Local dance movies starred Vilma Santos, Nora Aunor, and Maricel Soriano. The numerous disco night clubs, such as the iconic Coco Banana, were the watering holes of the disco-dancing crowd. In the early 1980s, Michael Jackson won the hearts of Filipino fans with his signature moves that accompanied his hit songs.

The economic prosperity in the early years of martial law, which was due to large borrowing and spending, eventually resulted in a huge deficit in the balance of payments. The economic woes of the country were aggravated by the international oil crisis. The situation of the lower classes worsened as unemployment rose, thus forcing many Filipinos to work abroad. Among these were the entertainers who were either singers or cultural dancers. Thus, cultural dancing, which consisted of a repertory based on folk and pop dances, became a means of upward social mobility. Training schools in cultural dancing proliferated, the main purpose of which was to train amateurs as overseas cultural dancers, with Japan as the most popular destination.

Dance in theater under martial law included Broadway musicals and the restaging of sarsuwela at the Metropolitan Theater. Conchita Sunico, the Met’s executive director produced Ang Kiri (The Flirt) and Ang Palabas Bukas (The Show Tomorrow) in1979; Cats in1984; and Aristocrats in 1985. Dance, creative movement, and martial arts were utilized in the staging of historical plays, allegorical plays, and adaptations of foreign plays with veiled opposition to martial law. This strategy was used by theater groups like the Philippine Educational Theater Association and its youth arm, the Metropolitan Teen Theater League. Examples of these theater productions were Ang Hatol ng Guhit na Bilog (The Caucasian Chalk Circle ), 1977; Sampung mga Daliri (Ten Fingers), 1978; May-i, May-i, 1979; Canuplin, 1980; Pilipinas Circa 1907, 1982; and Nukleyar I and II (Nuclear I and II), 1983/1985. The progressive Christian Churches were instrumental in using dance in theater for emancipation, such as Teatro Pangkatilingban (Community Theater) spearheaded by Fr Alan Abadesco in Negros and the Kolambugan Dance Theater organized by Fr Dong Galenzoga in Lanao del Norte.

The major catalyst that united different sociopolitical forces opposing martial law was the assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr in 1983. Enraged by the blatant murder of Senator Aquino, choreographers expressed their sociopolitical sentiments. Many groups used ballet and modern dance to create works that were openly anti-Marcos. Basilio’s Misa Filipina (Filipino Mass), 1984, portrayed the death of Ninoy Aquino within the framework of the Roman Catholic mass. The 1928 kundiman “ Bayan Ko ” (My Country) was revived by Freddie Aguilar in the early 1980s and was interpreted by many dancers in all kinds of venues and spaces. The groups Peryante and Patatag performed their kilos-awit or songs fused with creative movements and dance performed during street demonstrations. This form had been used by Tambisan sa Sining to organize workers since 1979. MAKIISA, the First National Theater and People’s Festival on Theater and Culture, was convened in Dec 1983 in Manila, with workshops on the arts that included music, mime, and indigenous dances. Broad coalitions and alliances were instrumental in staging the rallies and demonstrations before the historic Feb 1986 uprising.

The Marcos dictatorship ended with the 1986 EDSA Revolt. Martial law, which lasted 14 years in the history of the Philippines, was a significant period for the development of dance and other art forms. The era witnessed the development of state-sponsored aesthetics that raised the artistic level of ballet, modern dance, folk dance, and theater. It was an aesthetics that may be viewed as elitist by the anti-dictatorship forces. However, repression and militarization did not impede the development of an aesthetics of protest. In fact, the era gave rise to divergent forces which developed various artistic forms that expressed dissatisfaction with the existing sociopolitical and economic situation. Such discontentment led to the groundswell of protests which overthrew the Marcos dictatorship.

 

Philippine Dance During the Fifth Republic (1986 Onward)

Dance in the Philippines after the fall of the Marcos dictatorship in 1986 took another turn as changes were felt in the sociopolitical and cultural spheres of the country. The political climate was one of inclusion, and this had an effect on the cultural life of the nation. Still reeling from the oppression of the martial law period, the Filipinos were hopeful that participatory democracy would reestablish a government respectful of human rights and freedoms. At the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), the new thrusts of Filipinization which emphasized original Filipino works, democratization which gave venue and productions grants to dance companies, decentralization which encouraged participation of dance artists from the regions, promotion of artistic excellence, and reorientation of international exchanges translated into changes in the dance scene. Established in 1992, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts aimed to provide more institutional support to the arts. Through its National Committee on Dance, dance practitioners, teachers, community-based performing groups, companies, schools, arts councils and foundations, and even local government units, had the opportunity to apply for dance project grants enabling them to research on, create, perform, and compete in dance.

The ballet scene felt a sense of reinvigoration with the regular season performances of CCP’s two companies: Ballet Philippines (BP) which was generally identified with classical ballet as well as “neo-ethnic” modern pieces, and the newly-established resident company Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) with its classical ballet works complemented by a contemporary repertoire. Also within the confines of CCP and intensifying the choreographic impulse of the period was BP II, established in the 1990s under the direction of Agnes Locsin. Soon, Lisa Macuja’s Ballet Manila (BM), was established as another strong company with its full-length classical ballets in the Russian tradition.

These three major companies provided Filipinos with a range of productions to choose from. BP’s veteran and young choreographers created a wide selection of pieces: Gabriela byCorazon Iñigo; Tambol at Padyak (Drum and Stomp) by Tony Fabella; Icarus by Enrico Labayen; Pakiusap : A Mail Order Bride by Kristin Jackson; Swimming the Pasig River by Alden Lugnasin; Itak ni Andres (The Sword of Andres) byDwight Rodrigazo; Crisostomo Ibarra by Paul Morales; Rey-sing by Carissa Adea; Two of You by Ea Torrado; and You, Me, Us byRonelson Yadao.

Aside from producing full-length ballets like Tom Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet, The Hunchback of Notre Dame and La Bayadere, PBT reworkedearlier pieces such as David Campos-Cantero’s Carmina Burana. The company staged mixed-bill productions such as Tribute to Maestro Lucio San Pedro, Curtain Call, and Serenade and Other Ballets, and popular works including Gener Caringal’s Pangarap na Bituin (A Dream Star), Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), and Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (Wish There’s No End).

Aside from the full-length classical ballets in the Russian tradition staged by BM, the company also produced original works like Tatlong Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Three Stories of Lola Basyang) based on the tales of enchantment of Severino Reyes and Alamat: Si Sibol at si Gunaw (The Legend of Sibol and Gunaw) based on Philippine myths, tales, and contemporary environmental issues.

Also contributing to the vibrant scene of ballet were the many ballet schools during the post-martial law era. The Association of Ballet Academies, Philippines’ (ABAP) roster has around 30 members working together to strengthen ballet education in the country. A number of its members and the three major ballet companies joined the CCP’s annual Balletfest launched in 1987 to further stimulate ballet in the country.

Modern dance which was introduced to the Philippines in the late 1920s was continuously propelled particularly by Locsin whose works braided the vocabularies of indigenous movements and modern dance. Her works which Filipinized both ballet and modern dance became popularly known as “neo-ethnic” and was a strong presence in the dance scene in the 1980s. Some of her known works during this period were Igorot, Hinilawod, Bagobo, Moslem,and Babalyan. Other dancers explored the incorporation of Philippine material and indigenous themes in their modern works : Gener Caringal in Ang Sultan (The Sultan), Denisa Reyes in For the Gods, Edna Vida in Visions of Fire, and Eli Jacinto in Sa Panimula ng Buhay (At the Beginning of Life).

Foregrounding Philippine culture and national issues was Denisa Reyes’s Neo-Filipino series featuring Filipino-themed choreographies characterized by a range of dance vocabularies and techniques, including modern and contemporary dance. From the 1990s onwards, the series saw a wealth of works from both seasoned and budding choreographers: Hazel Sabas’s Cry for Home, Victor Ursabia’s Pas Galawgaw, Rodrigazo’s Bread of Angels, Brando Miranda’s Rhapsody, Max Luna’s KatiTaog, Lugnasin’s Ulaging (Daog-dog sa Sang Libong Kulog),Gerardo Mercardo’s Ang Krus ng Alitagtag (The Cross of Alitagtag), Cristine Crame’s Sinotris Gentillorum (The Miraculous Virgin and Guardian of God the Father), Judell de Guzman’s Juan at ang Bagong Adan (Juan and the New Adam), Novy Bereber’s To Whom it May Concern,Edna Mae Labitoria’s PG 13, and Eisa Jocson’s I am not a robot, maybe a cyborg.

The decade of the 1990s saw the emergence of a new breed of dance makers working outside major institutions, and with minimal state support. The efforts of carving out spaces for contemporary dance began among a small group of independent artists who were likewise key figures in the establishment in 2009 of the Contemporary Dance Network Philippines, which was later renamed Contemporary Dance Network Manila in 2011.Earlier works of contemporary danceinclude Truth.con Furia of Myra Beltran’s Dance Forum and Jay Cruz’s Dancing Wounded Contemporary Dance Commune, R-18 ofAirdance, and Anatomy of Love and Desire curated by Donna Miranda. Several contemporary pieces also made use of Philippine rituals and epics as seen in Sulog sa Kinabuhi (Surge of Life) byAl Bernard Garcia, Nasalapuan (Birthing) byJapheth Mari Cabling and Abigail Carlos, and pieces created by Elenia Laniog and Sergio Gahol for Nicanor Tiongson’s play Labaw Donggon: Ang Banog ng Sanlibutan (Labaw Donggon: Hawk of the Universe).

Performance of indigenous dances which was expected to diminish, let alone vanish, in the late 20th and early 21st centuries, actually continued in different places of the country. Dance was still integral to the Kalinga’s bodong (peace pact) rite, the Ibaloi’s bendiyan, and the Sulu archipelago’s rituals to drive away spirits causing illness. Many locals and pilgrims praying for fertility and other blessings continued to dance in honor of Obando’s patron saints and Pakil’s patroness.

But indigenous dances survived not only in their “natural” contexts as they were likewise integral to the nation’s tourism, labor, and employment programs. Folk dances charmed tourists who were looking for quaint cultural performances within the cozy spaces of hotels and restaurants. Also part of the Local Government Unit’s efforts to boost tourism during the post-EDSA period was the promotion of regional folk dance festivals such as the Panagbenga or the Flower Festival in Baguio, Dinagyang in Iloilo, Sinulog in Cebu, MassKara in Bacolod, Tinagba Festival in Iriga City, Kaamulan Festival in Bukidnon, and the Agal-Agal Festival in Tawi-Tawi. The Aliwan Fiesta, dubbed as the Mother of All Fiestas, began in 2003 and held every summer in the Star City Complex, Pasay City. It has brought together the best performing groups of some of the aforementioned festivals. Folkdance also went beyond national borders as Filipino cultural entertainers learned to perform indigenous dances before international audiences.

Further boosting interest in Philippine indigenous dances were the endeavors of the CCP to promote them by sustaining two regular dance festivals, the Pang-alay: A Festival of Philippine Folk Dances andthe Sari-Saring Sayaw, Sama-Samang Galaw: Mga Tradisyon at Interpretasyon (Different Dances, Unified Movements: Traditions and Interpretations).

Academe was also a home to folk dance groups which represented their respective institutions. Some of the many groups still active today are the St Louis University Dance Troupe, the University of the East Dance Troupe, the Sining Kalinangan Mapua Tech Dance Company, the UP Filipiniana Dance Company, the University of Santo Tomas Salinggawi Dance Troupe, the Araullo University Dance Group, the Bulacan State University’s Lahing Kayumanggi Dance Troupe, the Lahing Batangan Dance Troupe of the Lyceum of the Philippines University in Batangas, the Silliman University Kayahag Dance Troupe, and the Palawan State University’s Sining Palawan Dance Troupe. Not part of academe but persistently committed to promoting indigenous dances are groups such as the Francisca Reyes-Aquino Memorial Foundation and the AlunAlun Dance Circle cofounded by Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa.

Dancing in television shows became ubiquitous during the post-EDSA era and this phenomenon intensified the interest in social dance.TV dancing was in full swing in the 1980s with talented groups dancing commercial pop, jazz, ballroom, funk,and broadway in shows such as Vilma! later retitled Vilma In Person; Superstar; Maria! Maria!, later retitled Maricel Live!; The Other Side of Alma and Loveliness; Manilyn Live!; Lotlot and Friends; Tonight with Dick and Carmi; POPS!; Vina; and The Sharon Cuneta Show. The Spanish hustle, salsa, LA walk, swing, the bop-bop girl, and cycling punk were also popularized in TV dance contests.

Soon after, record companies strategically deployed their own groups to promote their labels. In the 1990s, noontime shows like Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!)thrilled the viewers by havingsexy back-up dancers like the Sex Bomb girls in their daily contests. Ballroom dancing on TV then took another turn in the mid-1990s when Bb. Pilipinas-Universe Charlene Gonzales and 1993 Ms Universe Dayanara Torres dazzled their audience in Eezy Dancing on ABC 5, which was later retitled Keepon Dancing on ABS-CBN 2.

A higher level of ballroom dancing appeared in the form of dancesport in the late 1990s, and easily gained a following among dance enthusiasts, both young and old. Lucy Torres-Gomez’s Shall We Dance, which eventually became Celebrity Dance, contributed to the popularization of this dance form. Since the launching in the country of competitive style of ballroom dancing, regular competitions have been held throughout the year, not only in Manila, but also in the other regions of the Philippines. The Filipinos’ talent for this athletic dance has been witnessed by audiences of international dancesport showdowns.

Popular music, songs, and dances gained their respective audiences. Making waves and changing the landscape of dance in the Philippines during this time was hip-hop, reaching the country via the music and movies on hip-hop culture in the United States. Soon, the dance form became popular via local television, movies, and music, with the strong presence of rapper Francis M and his crew, The Eclipse (b-boy crew) and Spindicate Posse (DJ crew) in the 1990s, and later, Mastaplann, Andrew E, and the Disco Mix Club (DMC) Philippines headed by former radio Dj Jessie Cambosa. Dance clubs and discotheques became usual spaces of encounters among hip-hop rappers and dancers, as were parking lots which served as face-off venues. In the 21st century, dance studios became a major breeding ground of hip-hop groups such as the Philippine All-Stars and the UP Street Dance Club.

Beginning 2000s, there emerged a strong contender for viewership of basketball fans— cheerdance. Introduced through the University Athletic Association of the Philippines’s cheerdance competition in the mid-1990s, the form has acquired a distinct and prestigious identity as excited spectators root for their respective dance groups: UP Pep Squad, UST Salinggawi Dance Troupe, NU Pep Squad, De La Salle University Animo Pep Squad, Ateneo Blue Babble Battalion, and the UE Red Squad.

If television was crucial in the perpetuation of social dance and hip-hop, e-mail, cellular phones, social media, and other circuits of communication were behind the success of the dance flash mob in the 21st century. Referring to surprise dance performances by people mobilized by digital technology, this dance form has been used by the global campaign of One Billion Rising aimed to get together one billion people to put a stop to violence against girls and women. Begun in the Philippines in 2012, the campaign since then has rallied girls, women, men, and the LGBT (lesbians, gays, bisexuals, and transgenders) to protest current national issues inextricably linked to women’s concerns.

Although national support for dance in the past 30 years could hardly be a source of total optimism and dance practitioners could not be too sanguine about how this so-called ephemeral form has been perceived, dance in the Philippines proved its vitality as the period saw the emergence of performers and choreographers working independently, more daring choreographic works, impressive productions in festivals, intelligent use of dance to articulate various issues, and a distinct sensibility in responding to tourism, media, and technological leaps. Most of these outstanding works have earned recognition from institutions and award-giving bodies: the Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Association’s (Philstage) Gawad Buhay (Life Honor) and Natatanging Gawad Buhay (Honor for Life), the CCP’s Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, the City of Manila’s Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award, the NCCA’s lifetime-achievement award Dangal ng Haraya (Honored Contribution), Gawad Alab ng Haraya (Brilliant Contribution Prize), and for a brief period the Pasasalamat ng Bayan sa Sayaw (National Gratitude in Dance), the Aliw Awards Foundation, Inc’s Aliw Awards, and National Artist Award. The more congenial socio-political and cultural climate after martial law proved to be promising enough for the ingenious Filipino whose imaginative energy could not be denied or contained. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, Rosalie S. Matilac, Clarissa Mijares, Senecca Pellejo, and Ruth Jordana L. Pison
