text:
Sections

From Komedya to Bodabil
Ballet
Modern Dance
Folk and Social Dance
Conclusion

 

The Philippines declared its independence from Spain in June of 1898. However its new life was overtaken by the Spanish-American war that began in Cuba and Puerto Rico in the Caribbean. In May, Cmdre George Dewey of the United States sailed across the Pacific to subdue the Spanish fleet in Manila Bay. But even after the surrender of the Spanish to the Americans, the latter did not leave, having decided to buy the islands from Spain for 20 million dollars. As a result, the new country was embroiled again in the ensuing Philippine-American War, which officially ended in 1901, with the beginning of the American colonial period.

Despite objections from the anti-imperialists in the United States, the McKinley administration sent several batches of American teachers called the Thomasites, after the ship that they came in from the United States. They imposed the English language and oriented the people to American culture. And to hasten the Americanization of the Filipinos, the American colonial government sentpensionados(Filipino pensioners or scholars) to the United Statesto train in American universities. On the other hand, American popular culture was propagated all over the islands by the theatrical form called “vaudeville,” later Filipinized to bodabil, which showcased American popular dances, songs, and comic acts. Together with bodabil, the movies from Europe and the United Statesexposed Filipinos to the Western way of life, which became their ideal, and the dances associated with it

 

 

From Komedya to Bodabil

But even after the takeover of the Philippines by the American government and the attempts at Americanizing the Filipinos, the old Hispanic culture which was centuries old, continued to flourish especially in the provinces. The Hispanickomedyacontinued to be the popular form of entertainment during town fiestas. As in the past, the komedya performance had theatrical conventions which included marcha (march), paso doble (double step), eskaramursa (waltz), and the batalla (choreographed combat). Princesses would sing and dance the balitaw and balse (waltz) during intermissions. Komedya performances would last for days in the towns and the countryside.

Also surviving the change in political order, the Spanishzarzuelacontinued and evolved into its Tagalog form. Earlier stars, like Praxedes “Yeyeng” Fernandez who was noted for her tango and can-can, Patricio Tagaroma who married comedian Jose Carvajal, and their daughter Patrocinio Carvajal who was called a “Diosa de Baile” by Flavio Zaragosa Cano, still appeared in Teatro del Oriente in Compania de Zarzuela Comico-Lirica. But the Spanish zarzuela was swiftly being replaced by the nativesarsuwelain Tagalog, Pampango, Pangasinan, Ilocano, Cebuano, Waray, and Hiligaynon. Most prominent examples of the Tagalog sarsuwela were Walang Sugat (Not Wounded), 1902, by Severino Reyes; Ang Kiri (The Flirt), 1926, by Servando de los Angeles; and Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), 1919, by Hermogenes Ilagan and composer Leon Ignacio. With the sarsuwela’s plot and music came dances like balitaw and balse. Active theaters in Manila were the Zorrilla, Filipino, Nacional, Universal, Oriente, Paz, Libertad, and Sirena. Like the komedya, the sarsuwela was deployed to the regions, especially at fiestas. Due to the sarsuwela’s popularity, sarsuwela-type films were made, such as Pakiusap (Plea), Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), and Giliw Ko (My Beloved), all with singing and dancing.

In the direct American rule from 1901 to 1946, the United States brought in American musical and theatrical innovations. The local bodabil saw dancing in variety shows. Its origin is in the American vaudevillegestated from songs in Normandy, France, later popularized as theater in the United States. Consequently, this was also propagated in the Philippines. It catered to both Filipinos and American expatriates. Minstrel troupes (typically with blacks, and whites putting on black make-up) sailed across the Pacific. They featured popular music, the buck-and-wing and clog or tap dancing (of Irish or African origin), soft-shoe, and straight-forward jazzand bluesmusical genres. Made famous in the United States, this variety show was called vod-a-vil by Cebuano jazz pianist Lou Borromeo. Eventually, it was known as bodabil.

Other Americans brought in the skirt-dance and pseudo-orientalia or exotic (also called aesthetic ) dancing. The first dance ingeniously manipulated the skirt, while the second took on the fascination with oriental culture from the Near to the Far East. All these enthralled audiences at the Zorrilla, Libertad, Paz (formerly Orpheum), Filipino, Alhambra, and Cosmopolitan. Among the new bodabilhouses were Savoy Nifties (later Clover) and Sirena (later Lux), and all hyped up their shows as “novelty” acts.

If Tony Pastor was the “father of American vaudeville,” John Cowper, who came to the Philippines with Henry Brown, was called the “dean of Philippine vaudeville.” Cowper’s first venture was at Paz Theater with an all-European cast in 1911. He lost money and ended up working for the famous Lou Borromeo. Meanwhile, Brown formed a group at the Lux and also produced shows at the Rivoli and Savoy. European dancers—like Anita, Emilia, Teresa, Planella, Malgrosa, Francisca Nabalo (famous for her “flea dance”), the Agita Sisters (“a clever Spanish trio”), and the Frezagonda Sisters—performed alongside American entertainers (Villaruz 2006, 70).

In her own class was Ada Delroy, who billed herself “the world’s greatest dancer.” In 1900, she introduced Filipinos to what was a pyrotechnical and choreographic success in Europe. She must have imitated the American Loie Fuller (1862-1926), so celebrated at the Paris Folies-Bergere that they built a theater for her at the 1900 Paris World Fair (Horst Koegler 1982, 166). Fuller turned the skirt-dance into a spectacle with her own costumes and lighting design. A contemporary of Isadora Duncan, she was celebrated in the art nouveauor new art of the time. From Fuller’s Serpentine Dance and Fire Dance, Delroy might have derived her own The Fire of Life. It was probably based on the English Rider Haggard’s orientalist novel She. This was well received at the Zorrilla in 1900. The then current fashionable orientalism was pervasive, like depicting Salome in Oscar Wilde’s play and Richard Strauss’s opera—the composer casting Jovita Fuentes as Salome. For her part, prima ballerina Anna Pavlova portrayed Asian deities with the Indian dancer Uday Shankar (Mukhopadhyay 2004, 16-21).

 

Foreign vaudeville artists continued to visit in the 1930s and 1940s. The most notable were the African-American “brothers” Richard and Raymond Reynolds, who taught tap dancing and the charleston to Filipinos. Others were Helen and Lucy Martin, and the remarkable Portuguese “Don” Jose Zarah who came with a Spanish troupe and stayed on. Zarah spent World War II with Lou Salvador’s Merrymakers at the Dalisay, Strand, and Palace theaters. He became an independent dancer and impresario at the Clover (earlier the Savoy Nifties), performing flamenco and other Spanish dances with Bebe Marcaida. He also guided Charito “Chuchi” Hernandez as a choreographer into the 1960s. Hernandez rose from a chorus girl in 1927 to become a dancer of character and international dances, jazz, tap and some ballet learned from the Spanish-American Carmen “Chuchi” MacLeod.

Before long, Filipinos replaced the imported entertainers. In the 1900’s, Sunday Reantaso founded the first Philippine Vaudeville Company. Sarsuwela stars in Atang de la Rama (“Queen of the Kundiman”) joined Katy de la Cruz (“Queen of the Jazz” and “Carmen Miranda of the Philippines”) on the bodabil stage. With the advent of the movies, Hollywood musicals left their mark on the bodabil. Movie dancing stars were led by Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. Soon enough they got bodabil’s counterparts in Bayani Casimiro and Nieves Manuel. Also idolized on stage and in film was child star and tap dancer Shirley Temple, who first won fame with black partner Bill “Bojangles” Robinson. Among Temple’s local counterparts was the young Tita Duran, later singing and dancing with husband Pancho Magalona. Before the World War II ended, Gene Kelly rose from Broadway and Hollywood as versatile icon in tap, jazz, and ballet, all seen in his many films. In turn those films influenced our stage and later television. In various degrees, local stagings imitated the geometric spectacles of Busby Berkeley. His style can be traced back to the balletmecanique of Luigi Manzotti (1835-1905), an example of which was seen from Dubsky in the 1930s.

Writing in 1929, a John Maynard favorably compared Philippine bodabil to the American product, describing Buster Dunston at the Savoy as “a clever and versatile dancer.” Dunson trained the famous Garcia Sisters, Flor and Modesta, and designed costumes for shows. Maynard called Katy de la Cruz “the greatest favorite of Manila variety,” naming her “the Sophie Tucker of the Philippines.” There were singer-dancers like Toy-Toy, Leonora Reyes, Elizabeth “Dimples” Cooper, Vitang Escobar, Nazarina Farias, Carmen “Miami” Salvador (with a “hula wiggle that is entirely unequalled by any other performer”), and the Garcia Sisters who formed with Dunson a “three-cornered combination [that was] the best dancing act Manila has ever had.” In Philippine Magazine, Maynard enthused, “There is a dainty nymph-like grace and beauty about those tiny Malay figures possessed by no other race in the world. They are quick in learning their routines, and are natural dancers” (Maynard 1929a, 164-65, 305-07; 1929b, 40-43).

When the Japanese occupied the Philippines in World War II, 1942 to 1945, they banned American films, and Filipino movie production also ground to a halt. Joining the war with its allies in Germany and Italy, Japan took the agenda of Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere. This included the teaching of the Japanese language and the encouragement of local artists. Writing about those times, Nick Joaquin said that when the bodabil was dying “in the dingy houses on Echague where it was making a last stand, [it] returned to triumph” (Joaquin 1990). Joe Climaco was among the first to stage a show during the Japanese occupation. People queued for hours in the morning, as they did for food and other things, before the theaters opened at noon for the three shows of the day. Various conglomerations sprouted, such as the Merrymakers of Lou Salvador, the Philippine Artists’ League of Sammy Rodriguez and Lamberto Avellana, the Filipinas Revue of Jose Climaco and Ramon Estella, the Stage Revue of Ruben and Corazon Roque, the Stage Revue of Jose Generoso, and the production outfit of Fernando Poe. Salvador staked out Dalisay, Strand, and Palace; Rodriguez and Avellana, the Avenue; the Roques, the Lyric; Climaco, the Life; Generoso, the State; and Poe, the Capitol, theaters found in Quiapo, Santa Cruz, and Avenida, Rizal. It was during this period that bodabil expanded to include the “drama-skit” and was then renamed stage show.

Despite the general opposition to the Japanese, there was also a shift of mind with their emphasis on Asia for the Asians in cultural expressions. Back in 1939, Leonor Orosa danced for a cultural mission in Japan. This was a year before she had choreographed Morolandia, inspired by her childhood in Sulu where her father had a medical assignment. For the stage shows in the war years, Filipino folk dancers joined the musicians and actors. Francisca Reyes-Tolentino (later Mrs Aquino) staged dances for the bodabil stage. Earlier in 1937, she founded the University of the Philippines Folk Song and Dance Club. It was under the auspices of UP Pres Jorge Bocobo who espoused the serious and broad study of Filipino culture. Her two dancers in Patria Panajon and Lucio Sandoval danced at the Avenue for Avellana’s productions, like Pista ng Bayan. A third was Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte who staged dances for Climaco in State Theater and for Fernando Poe in Avenue Theater. In 1946, she founded the Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe at the Philippine Normal School (now University) the Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe.

After the war, the bodabil or stage show maintained its popularity. To celebrate the end of the Japanese occupation, Salvador staged “a mammoth stage show” at the Apollo for 40 days. It featured the biggest stars such as Carmen Rosales and Rogelio de la Rosa. The stage show came to be the regular double-feature with the movies into the last days of Clover and the Manila Grand Opera House (MGOH) to the 1960s. Clover showcased the choreography and direction of the Portuguese Don Jose Zarah. The MGOH was subsequently owned by Toribio Teodoro, who reconstructed it with air-conditioning, and inaugurated it in 1947 in the presence of Pres Manuel Roxas.

 

Ballet

Ballet took its first steps on the bodabil stage. In 1901, the “ballet girls” of the Lilliputians (a term for children groups) came from Australia to grace the Zorrilla in 1901. They performed Amber, Housemaids, Seaweed Ballet, Widow Ballet,and Pierrot Ballet. Similarly, the company of youth in the Japanese Infantile Company opened at Teatro Oriental in Santa Cruz with what was billed a “Japanese ballet.” In 1902, the Baroufski Imperial Ballet Circus performed in Hashim’s National Cycle Track (later MGOH). It advertised 25 “ballet beauties” in dance pantomimes called The Sea Robbers, Faust, and one about the Boer War. The Manila Times described the pantomime as a “mammoth production,” adding that “the lovers of lingerie, pink tights and shapely anatomy with pretty faces were not disappointed when the nightly ballet and pantomime numbers were given.” Circus troupes, like the Barnes and Cogill-Sutton companies, gave performances at the Zorrilla which were “the best that had been given in Manila since many moons.”

A certain Paul Nijinsky came to Manila in 1915 and 1916, declaring himself a member of the Imperial Russian Ballet in St Petersburg. He performed for the Belgian Red Cross at the Manila Hotel. He danced to Chopin, Saint-Saens, Grieg, Wieniawski, and Schubert, music then found too serious for ballet but which approach was espoused by Isadora Duncan. This “Nijinsky” attributed his costumes to Serge Diaghilev’s own designer Leon Bakst in the famed Ballets Russes, danced barefoot, and was assisted by “the best local talents.”

In 1922, the world’s most celebrated ballerina Anna Pavlova saw those local talents during one of her global tours. Like Sarah Berndhardt, Pavlova performed on vaudeville and music-hall stages around the world, popularizing ballet as no other artist had done. Pavlova’s performances at the MGOH inspired many young girls. One of them was Anita Kane who decided to study in Manila with Katrina Makarova, a refugee from the Russian Revolution who claimed links with St Petersburg Imperial Ballet (Sembrano 2015, C-2). From Cebu, Fe Sala-Villarica—who later trained with Kane—studied in Manila with Mara Selheim who also claimed Russian descent. (Many then used pseudo-Russian names, often by their own companies’ marketing ploy.) Remedios Villanueva Piñon mentions Olga Dontsoff and Vladimir Bolsky to have briefly taught in Ermita. From 1924 to the mid-1930s, the Englishwoman Kay Williams also ran a studio there. Among her pupils was opera’s diva Mercedes Matias Santiago.

Kane herself lived in the Philippines for most of her life. She grew up in Paracale, Camarines Norte, where her father worked for a mining company. Later she trained further in England and USA, and started a graded teaching system in the Philippines. Briefly, she also taught dance in the University of the Philippines. Kane produced the first full-length ballet Mariang Makiling, 1939, to original music by Ramon Tapales. Elisa Robles essayed the title role. In 1951, Kane worked with composer Marcelino Carluen for Reconstruction Ballet, on the Filipino efforts to reconstitute their lives after the World War II. Her Anita Kane Ballet Company was later called Pamana Ballet.

Lubov “Luva” Adameit was more influential than either Makarova or Williams. She graduated from the Malinovsky School of Ballet and Free Art in Kiev. She claimed she danced with Pavlova’s company (not necessarily that of 1922). With her manager G. Leibovitz and pianist Ivan Sitnik, she came to Manila in 1927 to found her Cosmopolitan Ballet and Dancing School. Briefly, she also taught at Philippine Women’s College (now University). Some of Adameit’s students started young in their careers as choreographers inveladas(evening parties) and shows for Manila Carnival. Distinguished were Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, Remedios “Totoy” de Oteyza, Rosalia Merino-Santos, Mitos Sison, Maria Luisa “Inday” Gaston (later Mañosa) and her sister Conchita (who became an international opera diva), Chloe Cruz-Romulo, Pacita Madrigal-Gonzalez (later Warns), Elsie Uytiepo-Torrejon, Chona Recto-Kasten, and Esperanza Santos. The last named her own ballet school after Adameit. Another Adameit alumna is Fely Franquelli who was among the first to make a dent abroad as a solo artist in the 1930s. At her coming home, she enjoyed the rave review of writer Salvador P. Lopez.

Adameit’s annual recitals were staged at the MGOH and later at the Metropolitan Theater. Among her original ideas was putting folk dances en pointe, as in the Cariñosa and Planting Rice, thus nurturing the seeds of stylized folkloric ballet. This path was extended by Orosa-Goquingco in well-plotted and unified ballets. Her most significant works are Trend: Return to Native, 1941, and Filipinescas: Philippine Life, Legend and Lore in Dance, 1961, parts of which consolidated some of her earlier works like Vinta and Morolandia (1938). Orosa-Goquingco’s works that combined classical ballet and folk dance was hailed as “an important milestone in what cultural historians now call the period of stylization in the history of Philippine dance” (Laconico-Buenaventura 2012, 128). For her early and later works, Orosa-Goquingco was named National Artist in 1976. Another one of Adameit’s noted pupils was de Oteyza, who herself won a prize for choreography at the Manila Carnival. Later she studied in Paris with retired Russian prima ballerinas Olga Preobrajenska and Lubov Egorova, and the young choreographer George Balanchine who was a great influence in her succeeding choreographies set to music by Grieg, Tchaikovsky,Rachmaninoff, Frank, Khachaturian,Rimsky-Korsakov, Ravel, Gershwin, and much later to Rodolfo Cornejo and Alfredo Buenaventura. Her school group evolved from the de Oteyza Ballet in the 1950s to Manila Ballet Company, and Hariraya Ballet Company, 1968, collaborating with Inday Gaston Mañosa, both from the Adameit school.

Another student of Adameit was Rosalia Merino-Santos, her “baby ballerina,” known as such for her skill and versatility. She danced Adameit’s Planting Rice on pointe, and was first to do the difficult fouette (continuous spinning en pointe). She also studied ballet with Joseph Stemberski, Spanish dance with Conchita Sotelo, folk dance with Reyes-Aquino, and modern dance (then called ausdrukstranz or expressionistic dance) with Trudl Dubsky-Zipper. She went on to pursue modern dance for her master’s degree in Wisconsin with Margaret H’Doubler (who started the first dance degree in US), with Martha Graham and Doris Humphrey in Bennington College, and with Mary Wigman and Harald Kreutzberg in Europe. Her thesis in Wisconsin was a lecture-demonstration on dance as choreographic process, called What Is Dance, 1958. She came to direct the Far Eastern University (FEU) Folk Dance Troupe and the FEU Modern Experimental Dance Troupe.

During the war years, the Hungarian Paul Szilard taught and choreographed in Manila, particularly for the Metropolitan Theater (later the Manila Metropolitan Theater). Before and through the war years, he worked with dancers who had trained with Adameit for his versions of the classics Swan Lake and Sylvia, his own The Four Seasons, The Mad Thinker, and “Dance of the Hours” in the opera La Gioconda (The Jocund One). In 1953, he organized Philippine Art Theater to stage its Ballet Philippines production which stylized Philippine folk dances into a ballet-theater form. Later he became an impresario in New York and sent prominent dance companies to Manila.

 

Modern Dance

Aside from the ballets first seen on the vaudeville stage, there were theatrical dances that did not conform to the strict tenets of classical ballet. One is called modern dance. Later,its aesthetics and formulation refocused and is now called contemporary dance. At first it was an outright rebellion against the aesthetics of ballet. The coming of Ada Delroy was a foretaste of it in the Philippines. A further intimation of modern dance was seen at the MGOH in 1926 with the Denishawn company that went to the Far East and South East all in two years. The group was led by the couple Ruth St Denis and Ted Shawn. St Denis was known for her adaptation of oriental dances. On the other hand, Shawn availed of both American Indian and Greek imageries. Later he espoused the cause of the male dancer with his All-Men Dancers Group (1933). He also founded the Jacob’s Pillow in Massachusetts, where he founded a dance festival. The Denishawn’s repertoire had mixed Western and Asian-inspired works which were also featured in the vaudeville circuit in USA. In Manila, the group added The Cosmic Dance of Shiva by Shawn and A Japanese Court Dancer by St Denis. While briefly in the Philippines, Shawn went to Baguio to view dances of the Bontoc, Ifugao, Kalinga, and Apayao. About these he wrote in Dance Magazine (Feb 1927): “We went to a natural area in the hills and there saw dancing in the most violent contrast to the anemic and unoriginal dancing of the [Christian] Filipinos.”

From the European end came the Austrian Kaethe Hauser in 1932. She started a school in modern dance, known at that time in Europe as Ausdrukstanz or creative/interpretive dance, then advertised as ballet to attract a clientele. Among her pupils was Manolo Rosado, already notable in Spanish dance and who later fully turned to modern dance. After Rosado studied in Jacob’s Pillow, Shawn hailed him as “among the most talented artists of our generation,” while dancer-author La Meri hailed him as “the poet of dance.”In 1937, Hauser also brought in a fellow Viennese, the Czechoslovakian Trudl Dubsky. In Europe, Dubsky was a major member of Gertrude Bodenweiser’s troupe. (Bodenweiser was the first to bring modern dance to Australia. After the war some of those she had influenced, like Shona MacTavish, appeared as teachers or dancers in the Philippines.) Before coming to Manila, Dubsky appeared with the noted German modern dancer Harald Kreutzberg, and in the famous Max Reinhardt productions in Berlin. For a time she taught for the Vienna State Academy and choreographed for the Camargo Society that helped usher in the solid foundation of ballet in Britain. Moving to the Philippines, Dubsky taught modern dance at the Academy of Music and foreign dances in UP. Among her first tasks in Manila was working with Alexander Lippay, conductor of the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO). After Lippay died, Herbert Zipper became MSO’s conductor. These coincidences led to Dubsky’s marriage to Zipper. Of Jewish-Austrian extraction, Zipper was incarcerated in a German concentration camp. There he composed “Dachau Song” to boost the spirit for his fellow prisoners (Cummins1992). With Zipper’s support, Dubsky formed the Manila Ballet Moderne that ran annual productions at the MGOH between 1939 and 1941. Dubsky was intensely prolific, producing numerous works all in those seasons. She produced Petite Suite—Au Bord de la Seine (Little Suite—of the Seine) to Debussy, The Iron Foundry to Mossolow, Peer Gynt Suite to Grieg, Voices of Spring to Strauss, Pictures at an Exhibition to Moussorgsky, Polovestsky Dances to Borodin (from his opera Prince Igor ), The Toy Box to Schubert, and The Women of Arles to Bizet. Immediately after the war, she revived her group for dance concerts for the USAFFE (USA Forces in the Far East), and tried soliciting funds in the US for an arts center in Manila. One of Dubsky’s dancers, Cora Generoso-Iñigo, attributes to her the gift of drawing out dance potentials from athletes and amateurs to elicit inspired performances. Those she trained include Ricardo Reyes and Lucio Sandoval (both known as “Mr. Folk Dancer”); playwright Severino Montano; and dancers Adina Rigor-Ferrer, Maggie Shea, and Villanueva-Piñon. Others danced for her, like de Oteyza, Felix-Velarde, Merino-Santos, and Gaston-Mañosa who came from the Adameit and other schools.

Manila Ballet Moderne’s prewar seasons were linked to the Metropolitan Theater story, a dream of Mayor Tomas Earnshaw. It was designed by architect Juan Arellano. The “Met” was done in the art nouveau style, and its interior featured Filipino flora and A. V. H. Hartendorp hailed its pinnacles as “a tiara of … minarets” that fly “on wings of song” (after Mendelssohn), and its interior featured the Filipino flora. The foyer had Fernando Amorsolo’s murals Sayaw (Dance) and Awit (Song) (Laconico-Buenaventura 2010, 113-14, 118-19). Before and during the war time, the Metropolitan Theater hosted the dance productions of Adameit (after MGOH), Orosa-Goquingco, Szilard, and Dubsky. In the war time, it continued to serve as venue for both concerts and operas.

The time saw a consolidation of Filipino artistry in these forms, including that of several composers. There were also dramatic presentations that helped nurture the rise of Filipino actors and playwrights. During the Commonwealth, Pres Manuel L. Quezon espoused the policy ofFilipinizar a los Filipinosor “Filipinize the Filipinos”(Laconico-Buenaventura 2010, 128). The war did not stop the activity of dancers of local and visiting variety troupes, mostly appearing at the Met. These shows came to be paired with the showing of films that increasingly came to Filipino hands. In 1939, the Marcus Follies (supposed to have followed Ziegfeld’s on Broadway) brought in 80 variety artists who stayed on for a month’s showing. Among the hits were numbers Under the Sea that had a 25-foot dive, and “an eye-popping fan dance performed with real ostrich feathers from South Africa.” In 1941, there was a novelty act with the dancer-impersonator Alfred Stebel who imitated a ballerina, a hula-girl, and the witty comic idol in Mae West. The Japanese authorities brought in their own revues to entertain their soldiers. In 1942, they had Namiki Mitoko singing Japanese and Latin songs, and Namimi Satoye rendering a Spanish dance. A chorus line had a “hot rhumba ” that changed everyone’s idea about the “ever bowing and gentle kimonoed Haponesa,” now replaced by a “pert, modern Japanese girl” (Laconico-Buenaventura 2010, 131-34, 161).

At the Met, the Japanese period allowed Filipino talents from schools and stages to sustain presentations. Many rose to the challenges of both acting and playwriting. At the same time, many women went into social work. Based at the Met, the Volunteer Social Aid Committee (VSAC) served Filipino and American prisoners in feeding, nursing, and entertaining. In 1943 and 1944, they staged benefit shows, and often sponsored the presentations of Dramatic Philippines and Music Philippines. Among the VSAC members who were in ballet were Ma Teresa Escoda Roxas, Chona Recto, and the sisters Totoy and Maitos de Oteyza. After the war, two of their members, Helen Benitez and Conchita Sunico, were awarded the Philippines’ Legion of Honor. Cristina Laconico-Buenaventura reports that when one was asked to join VSAC, “No one … ever said no” (Laconico-Buenaventura 2010, 169).

 

Folk and Social Dance

The 1930s saw the blossoming of nationalism in dance. UP president Jorge Bocobo sent out to the field folk dancer Francisca Reyes (later Tolentino, then Aquino), musician Antonino Buenaventura, and photographer Ramon Tolentino to do research in Philippine folk dance and music. The work officially started in 1937, but earlier Reyes had already initiated research work as a student. Consequently, this project became her lifetime work. The team scoured the countryside, low and high lands, on foot and in bancas to find those dances and document them in musical scores and verbal directions. In 1927, New York publisher Silver Burdett and Company published Philippine Folk Dance and Games (coauthored with Petrona Ramos), and delayed by the war, Philippine National Dances in 1946. Now known as Mrs Serafin Aquino or “Mrs Aqui,” she went on to publish her monumental work with the six-volume Philippine Folk Dances that came between 1950 and 1976. All became the “bible of folk dances” used in the physical education curriculum. It cannot be ascertained whether the dances in the postwar books were in fact researched on before or after the war. To maintain the incentives in folk dance research, Aquino formed in 1949 the Philippine Folk Dance Society (PFDS) which has extended her influence to this day. Beyond research, Aquino also espoused the perpetuation of folk songs and dances in performance. In 1937, she organized the University of the Philippines Folk Song and Dance Club that toured Luzon and the Visayas. Hindered by the war, this came to a halt. Yet in those years she staged folk dances for the stage shows in cinema houses. Her dancer Paz Cielo-Belmonte also did the same in the productions of Climaco in State Theater and of Poe in Avenue Theater. Right after the war in 1945, Aquino formed the Filipiniana Dance Troupe to entertain active American and Filipino forces. Ever a guiding spirit in Philippine dance, Aquino was the first in dance to be named National Artist in 1973.

Reflecting the social dances from the Spanish to the American times, the PFDS continues to document dances for its annual workshops and its eight-volume Sayaw. Among those identified to have lived on through the American period is the lanceros (from lancers) which quadrille formation is equivalent to the rigodon (from the French rigaudon ). The lanceros was originally popular for 50 years in England. Philippine variations are found in the lanceros de Lingayen in Pangasinan, and the lanceros de Negros in the Visayas. The ba-ingles (frombaileandIngles)has similar formations, and according to Aquino it was first brought in by the early English traders. A variation has survived in Cabugao, Ilocos Sur, danced in peasant clothes and embellished with the kumintang (wrist-circling) gesture. Using more formal gowns like in the mascota or maria clara, the birginia is thought of as from the Virginia reel in US, as it reels in and out in the final figure called caracol, a spiral pattern. At the same time, the earlier Hispanic dances like the jota, balse,and pandanggo prevailed as the most popular of social dances, some of them integrated in the sarsuwela performances.

From those and earlier times, and persisting to this day, are Christian-related ritual dances of the folk, like the adapted pandango in Obando, bati in thesalubongin Antipolo, turumba in Laguna, subli in Batangas, sinulog in Cebu and parts of the Visayas, gapnod in Negros Oriental, ati-atihan in Aklan, sanghiyang in Cavite, and pastores in Bicol. This is not to speak of the innumerable non-Christian ritual dances that are meant to propitiate theencantosand other spirits that subsist among the numerous ethnic groups through the islands (Obusan 1994).

American colonialism drastically changed Philippine social life. While the folk continued to dance their versions of the Hispanic jota and pandanggoin the towns and barrios, the urban public tried out the fashionable foreign dances in cabarets, locally calledkabaret.At first, a “color line” separated Caucasians from Malay Filipinos, but Nick Joaquin (whose brother was a band musician) tells how Manuel L. Quezon and Gov-Gen Francis Burton Harrison broke the line by dancing across it. The most famous cabarets were in Santa Ana (advertised as the biggest dance-floor in the world, Maypajo in Tondo, La Loma in Santa Cruz, and the Rainbow in San Juan del Monte. They hosted floor shows, like thecariocain the style of films stars Astaire and Rogers. With the establishment of the Commonwealth in 1935, there were fireworks in Luneta, balls, and a floor show with Carmen “Miami” Salvador, Bayani Casimiro—the Fred Astaire of the Philippines, and the Diaz Sisters at the Santa Ana. Right up until the 1950s and 1960s, there were still cabarets in the small towns.

Aside from the dancing clubs, there were many dancing schools and grand balls at the Oriente Hotel. Rich Chinese, like the Palancas, threw balls of their own. Elite social clubs like the Mancommunidad, Smiles, Kahirup, and Club Filipino held their own affairs with social dancing. The musical and dance rages were the ragtime and cakewalk. Holdovers from the previous century were the can-can, habanera, square dance, and the two-step. The first years of the century saw a dizzying array of dances: the boston, bunny hug, camel walk, crab, fish tail, grizzly bear, maxixe, one-step, slow drag, tango, veleta, turkey trot,and other dances named after animals. There were also new-fangled fox-trot and lindy hop in the 1920s; the rhumba, charleston, black bottom, shimmy, variety drag,and quickstep in the 1930s; and the beguine, big-apple, hokey-pokey, jitterbug, lambeth walk, conga, paso doble,and the samba in the 1940s. The list shows a lot coming from the Caribbean and the black population cultures, reflecting their unrestrained and infectious feeling. Yet the idols of the day were the urbane Irene and Vernon Castle for their class and elan, and the astute Astaire and Rogers for their agility and panache—seen in the last Hollywood couple’s song and dance films. From the beginning of the American period, many ballroom-dancing schools were advertised, and many were still operating in Quiapo until the 1960s.

Spanish dance in both flamenco and folk forms continued to live through American times. Many like Conchita Sotelo taught the versatile Merino-Santos. Santos’s ballet contemporaries, like Mitos Sison and Chloe Cruz Romulo, also turned to Spanish dance. Another exponent in Manolo Rosado also turned to modern dance, but he combined these while dancing in Europe and Mexico. The younger Ruben Nieto studied flamenco here and abroad, and was a dancer on stage and in films. Nieto’s influence remains in his postwar partner Rose Borromeo. Another maestro in Guillermo Gomez said that his own mother was coached by the famous Antonia Merce, known as La Argentina, when she came before the war. Beyond her Spanish repertoire, La Argentina also danced the cariñosa, a version of the pandanggo and binasuan, and thus introduced these Filipino dances to the world (Gomez 1994). Gomez also acknowledges the long work of Portuguese Jose Zarah with Bebe Marcaida into the 1960s.

 

Conclusion

The Philippine ties forged with the United States lasted beyond 1946 when independence was gained. From culture to governance, these ties were not soon rescinded due to forces of economic circumstance and political dominance. At the same time, Filipinos adapted and modified cultural influences to suit their own lives and needs. Imaginative Filipino artists who studied abroad came back to assert their own specific idioms and identities, leading others at home to find their own modes of expression. The restriction against American films in World War II and Japan’s stress on Asian identity made the Filipinos capitalize on their own modes of cultural expression. Examples were how the American vaudeville was transformed into the Filipino bodabil, and how the regional folk dances documented by Francisca Reyes-Aquino became part of the stage presentations in schools and movie houses. These stage adaptations of folk dance continued in dramatized stylization as scripted by Orosa-Goquingco. This transformation may have been earlier hinted at by her teacher Adameit. All these Philippine encounters with the world have effects on the life of the contemporary Filipino, and on the course and discourse in dance to this day. The forms of expression brought in by both American and Asian colonial experiences were transformed in form and content by the inventiveness and creative imagination of the Filipino people. Whatever forms of adaptation and translation emerged, these transformations came out as identifiably and meaningfully Filipino. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz and Seneca Pellano
