text:
Sections

Dance in Theater
Ballet
Modern Dance
Indigenous Dances
Social Dances
Epilogue

The neocolonial attraction toward Western cultural products continued to affect the Philippine dance scene even after the Americans granted independence in 1946. During this period, American influence in the country’s political, cultural, and socioeconomic landscape continued to permeate every aspect of Philippine life. Neocolonial control was evident in trade and military pacts, signed to secure the Republic’s dependence on its former colonizer (Guillermo 1999, 201). As a result, the country’s aim to attain actual development and freedom was hampered by the economic structure characterized by the iniquitous relations between the former liberator and its newly-liberated colony (Doronila 1992, 174).

Aside from socioeconomic and political control, it was necessary for Americans to colonize culture by propagating their influence through media and education. The Fulbright scholarship, an education exchange program which replaced the earlierpensionadosystem, ensured the Americanization of the country’s educated class. At the height of the program in the 1950s, practically all Filipino artists and academics were given scholarships and lecture grants in American universities, subjecting them to “cultural campaign” through immersion in American society. As a result, the Filipino artist’s creative and scholarly output can largely be evaluated in terms of “keeping up with artistic trend in the United States and elsewhere in the West” (Lumbera 1997, 181-82). In the 1950s, notable dancers who received scholarships to study abroad were Rosalia Merino-Santos as a Fulbright scholar in 1959; Benjamin Villanueva Reyes who studied in New York through the sponsorship of Ricardo Casell, Manila Music Lovers Society, and Asociacion Musical de Filipinas; Felicitas Layag-Radaic and Alice Reyes through Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines; Israel Gabriel and Antonio Llacer on full scholarships at different ballet schools in the United States; and Joji Felix-Velarde at Ballet Rambert School in London and Ballet Art Studio in New York through the support of British dancer and choreographer Alicia Markova.

 

 

However, Filipinos did not only seek dance education and influences outside, but also received performances from the West. The Philippines enjoyed various shows in ballet, modern dance, and folk dance from international dance troupes such as the Royal Ballets of London and Copenhagen, the New York City Ballet and the San Francisco Ballet, and the Soviet Union’s Kirov, Bolshoi, and Perm, and the folkloric ensembles, which visited the country from the 1950s to the 1970s. Moreover, famous foreign dancers and choreographers such as New Zealand-born Anita Kane, Polish Luva Adameit, American couple Roberta and Ricardo Cassell, Hungarian exile Paul Szilard, and Austrians Trudl Dubsky-Zipper and Kathie Hauser all contributed to the development of ballet, modern dance, and theatrical dance forms in the country.

From the late 1950s to the 1970s, Broadway musicals, which showcased theatrical and dance performances for live audiences, were adapted into movies. Famous musicals such as Showboat and King and I, 1951, Peter Pan,1954, Oklahoma, 1955, Carousel, 1956, West Side Story and Cinderella, 1957, Gigi and Flower Drum Song, 1958, Wildcat, 1960, and Man of La Mancha, 1965, were made into films, and thereby also reached a wider audience. The rise of mass media in the West, thus, facilitated the entry of colonial imports in the country.

In 1953, the Philippines had the first television station in Asia (Enriquez 1998, 35). Colonial mentality, especially with the expansion of eight television channels and their affiliated radio stations in the 1960s, was quickly disseminated through importation of foreign films and adaptation of American entertainment format (Ables 2003, 33). In 1955, there were about 6,000 television sets all over the country, which quickly increased with the introduction of colored broadcasting in 1966. These developments in media technology paved the way for television to become one of the most influential sources of entertainment in the country (del Mundo Jr 1998, 400).

With TV entertainment, Filipinos soon yearned for American dance rhythms through the introduction of bodabildancing, ballet, modern dance, and social dance. Television dancing, in particular, gained following as dances were featured extensively on TV shows presented in a variety show format, a remnant characteristic of bodabil shows which faded in the 1960s. Julie Borromeo’s Dance Company was the first to present group dancing on TV through its performance on Caltex Star Caravan in 1960 (Castro 1994, 214).

 

Soon, well-known choreographers like Alice Reyes, Al Quinn, Julie Borromeo, Lito Calzado, and the Aldeguer Sisters worked behind the dance scenes of popular TV shows in the 1960s and 1970s such as The Lyn Madrigal Show, Superstar with Nora Aunor, Friday Variety Show, Pilita Corales Show, That Young Image, and Tancho Tique Show Generation. In the previous decade, the audience already revered the performances on TV characterized by quick movement and increased dance dynamics of American dances, such as boogie woogie and rock n’ roll.Dance fads of the period such as mashed potato, twist, boogaloo, bossa nova, frug, pachanga, watusi, and hustle were popularized and taught in the hit television show, Dance Time with Chito (Villaruz 1994, 76).

However, despite the trend of what seems like a “passive colonial importation” of American dances, there was also a nationalist move “to bring out in art the long dominated indigenous cultures” by presenting Philippine dances to a wider audience in both local and international stage (Guillermo 1998, 276). The revival of national consciousness against the neocolonial backdrop of the 1950s and 1960s was demonstrated through the success of the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, Filipinescas Dance Company, University of the East Dance Company, UP Filipiniana Dance Group, and the Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company (Cortes et al. 2000, 391).

This exportation of indigenous dance forms and cultural performances abroad signified not only growing internationalization, but also the awakening of nationalist sensibilities of Filipino as well as foreign dance teachers and choreographers in the country. Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, Corazon Generoso-Iñigo, Rosalia Merino-Santos, and Alice Reyes utilized Western dance forms such as ballet and modern dance to express folkloric themes and style. Thus, the 1960s and 1970s witnessed the influence of Philippine folk dance on ballet and modern dance (Corpus 2007, 108).

As the Philippine dance scene flourished, national and private cultural institutions awarded grants and scholarships to groups or individual dancers who excelled in the art form. There were venue grants for stage presentations and travel grants for group representation in international competitions. These grants, privately or publicly funded, ensured that dancers and dance companies were supported either to impart their experiences from abroad or to make their mark outside the country (Villaruz 1994, 116).

As the trend to express what was Filipino in dance arose, spaces for cultural performances emerged to reach a wider audience through the construction of new venues such as the FEU Auditorium built in 1949, the Araneta Coliseum in 1960, the Philam Life Auditorium in 1961, the New Frontier Theater in 1968, and the Claire Isabel McGill Luce Auditorium of Silliman University in 1973.

Dance, within the 26-year period of the Republic, reflected the paradoxes of neocolonial experiences of Filipinos who, on one hand, accommodated Western influences in the art form and, on the other, transformed these influences to project Filipino identity in the international landscape of dance. The nationalist projection of native dances on the international stage and the utilization of foreign dance forms to express native sensibilities reflected the country’s longing to be recognized by both its own people and foreigners as having a distinct and rich dance culture.

Thus, Philippine dance during the neocolonial period was vibrant in local adaptations of foreign dance forms, cultural importations from the West, and fusion of foreign and local dance forms. Indeed, as American neocolonial ideology was shaping the Philippine dance landscape, Filipino artists and performers were also seeking to shape dance with a Philippine cultural mold.

 

Dance in Theater

Despite the lingering effect of American colonization, traces of Spanish influence in Philippine performing arts continued to thrive during the neocolonial period. Thesarsuwelain Tagalog and in other Philippine languages such as Cebuano, Hiligaynon, Ilocano, Bicolano, and Pampango were still performed in urban areas and in the provinces. Sarsuwela dancing included traditional dances such as balitaw,balse, and polka but also incorporated American dances like the fox-trot, cha-cha and boogie. With the rise of films in the 1950s, sarsuwela migrated into cinema.

The same transition from stage to film happened tobodabiland stage show, which remained popular after the war. Initially, bodabil was shown alternately with movies in Manila. Bodabil, which featured songs, dance performances, and comedy skits, eventually replaced the komedya and sarsuwela. Bodabil shows were presented at the Manila Grand Opera House (MGOH) in Rizal Avenue and Clover Theater (previously called the Savoy) in Santa Cruz, Manila. The form continued to adopt popular trends in post-World War II American dances, such as mambo, cha-cha,and bossa nova, as well as popular dance styles of the period which included tap, soft-shoe, can-can, apache,and adagio dancing (Villaruz 1989, 17-18).

Bodabil’s established traditions lived on to the 1950s and 1960s. The theatrical genre was perpetuated by performers like Bayani Casimiro and Nieves Manuel, partners dubbed as the “Fred Astraire and Ginger Rogers of the Philippines.” Other dancers were Paquito Bolero and Angelita “Rhumba” Rey, the Rusca Bothers who were known as the “tap-dancing wizards,” Dandy the “tap-dancing expert” who became the comedian Casmot, Millie Sparks aka Lopita, Rosa Aquirre, and Metring David. Comedians Chichay and Patsy both started as chorus girls, while Chiquito and Dolphy were remarkable dancers. Much later came Ramon Zamora and Jun Aristorenas who both became action movie stars. Lasting long as dancers were Shirley Santos, Marie Cui, Arturo Zamora, and Aldo Joingco. The dancers who grew to be well-known choreographers for the stage shows, musicals or movies were “Jun” Salvador, Jake (or Jack) Jacinto, Jamin Alcoriza, and Al Quinn (Pangan, 1979). In 1953, the life in the bodabil stage was captured in the film Vod-a-vil which starred its well-known performers such as Bayani Casimiro, Katy de la Cruz, and Jose De Villa.

Aside from local performers, there were also foreign performers on the bodabilstage such as British dancers and choreographers Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin, who visited the country with the Far Eastern Entertainment for the Fil-American Variety Show in 1948; American dancer, choreographer, educator, and social activist Katherine Dunham who performed with her company in 1957; and famous Spanish dancer and choreographer Luis Perez Davila known as “Luisillo” who graced the bodabil stage in 1962.

When bodabil declined in the 1960s, theaters like Inday and Art featured burlesque dancing in haba-haba shows, an unsavory term for bodabil. The haba-haba, which was performed at the Alegria or the MGOH, featured less singing and dancing and more parading of women in skimpy clothes for “fashion shows.” Burlesque shows, housed in dodgy theaters such as the Gala, Cubao Cinema, and theaters near American bases in Olongapo, were later replaced bybombaor sex films that marked the decline of the bodabil era in the country (Fernandez 1994, 70). This went on to the 1970s in Dragon and Playboy theaters, where burlesque queens were known as Virgie Night, Betty Co, Nina White, Jenny Moh, and Carlotta.

On the other hand, the 1960s also tried to restore the bodabil’s prestige and popularity. The Araneta Coliseum and the New Frontier Theater (with a revolving stage) hired Corazon Generoso-Iñigo, daughter of stage show producer Jose Generoso, as choreographer-director. Many were lured to choreograph for the movie producers Sampaguita, LVN, and Premiere. Among them were Iñigo, Alcoriza, Quinn, Rally Calvo, and flamenco dancer Ruben Nieto. Dancers Chichay and Dolphy became movie stars and were joined by singing-and-dancing love teams like Pancho Magalona and Tita Duran, and Nestor de Villa and Nida Blanca. Bodabil’s allure went on in television with its variety or stage show format.

Noted choreographers in those days were Quinn, Lito Calzado, Ernie Estrella, Julie Borromeo, Alice Reyes, Amelia Apolinario, and the Aldeguer Sisters Lally and Terry. There were also TV dance shows in the 1960s such as Dance Time with Chito which taught the cha-cha, mambo, twist, and bossa nova; Penthouse 7 or later Penthouse Live followed up into the 1970s and 1980s.Thus, the migration of bodabil performers from stage to broadcast media spelled bodabil’s decline on stage.

As the sarsuwela and bodabil experienced transformations over the decades, there was another cultural phenomenon that drew the attention of Manila’s middle and upper class—the Broadway musical. This form is considered by many to have been popularized, or perhaps even introduced to the Philippines by the American Jesuit Fr James B. Reuter who was behind several musicals staged in Assumption San Lorenzo and St. Paul’s Manila. For the latter, he directed The Sound of Music in 1964 featuring young performers who eventually gained prominence in either television, film, or theater. Some of them were Vic Silayan, Subas Herrero, June Keithley, and Tina Santos. Unlike other musicals which became popular after their film versions were shown, the The Sound of Music ’s movie version came to the Philippines after a year when Filipinos had already enjoyed its stage production. In 1965, Reuter’s staging of My Fair Lady for Assumption San Lorenzo starred Agapito “Butz” Aquino, Gary Lising, Nick Lizaso, Chloe Cruz-Romulo, Tony Manuud, and Cristina Caedo Galang. Stunning the audience was not just the astounding chandelier used for the ballroom scene, which Malacañan “lent” for the duration of the production, but there were also all kinds of lavish ball outfits worn by the performers. And although the production came months after its film was released in the country, and despite its pricey tickets, Reuter’s musical was a great success. Brigadoon, starring Aquino with Baby Barredo and Tina Santos, followed in 1966. The show impressed the audience with its Highland sword dance and the playing of bagpipes by Scotsmen in kilts outside the Fleur-de-Lis Auditorium on Herran Street.

Behind these high-quality Broadway musicals were not only talented artists who sang and danced to the audience’s delight but also the live performance of the Manila Symphony Orchestra’s Broadway musical arrangements. For years, these impressive productions provided the Filipinos with high-caliber entertainment until other companies such as the Repertory Philippines and Julie Borromeo’s Dance Theater Arts Philippines shared the Philippine stage (Garcia 2015).

Dance as an art form was not only utilized solely for entertainment but also for furthering social movements and sociopolitical goals. In the global context, the Philippines’ neocolonial period overlapped with the beginnings of the Cold War and the Cultural Revolution in China. During this tumultuous period in world history, dancing was influenced by revolutionary ideology that propagated specific goals for the movement. For instance, dances as part of the Chinese Cultural Revolution’s propaganda were visible, such as the ballet Red Detachment of Women, 1970, that promoted the ideologies of the Communist Party (Lin 2009).

During the late 1960s, the country witnessed the rise of student activism and widespread demonstrations against American imperialism and corruption in government. The founding of militant youth organizations, such as Kabataang Makabayan (KM) in 1964, heightened the political tensions between student groups and state forces during their encounters in rallies, riots, and demonstrations. Philippine art, as a result, became the battleground for youth groups to combat the State-sponsored program for art patronages that divorced the people from sociopolitical reality through its promotion of art-for-art’s-sake aesthetics. Revolutionary artists’ organizations, such as Nagkakaisang Progresibong Artista at Arkitekto in 1971 and Konsehong Tagapag-ugnay ng Rebolusyonaryong Sining in 1972, were established to serve as a cultural arm of the movement (Guillermo 2001, 51). In outlining the basic premises of committed art forms, Panulat Para sa Kaunlaran ng Sambayanan or PAKSA, a militant art group active in 1971, provided a framework to dramatize the “three evils of Philippine contemporary society: imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucrat capitalism” through the so-called new people’s literature, music, and drama (Guillermo 1987, 7). Thus, many young artists and writers of the period produced works that were “reflective of a historical and social consciousness” of the people through protest literature and revolutionary aesthetics (Guillermo 1993, 4).

Meanwhile, Philippine dance was incorporated in the movement’s staging of skits, plays, and musicals, which highlighted street rallies and protests during this period of sociopolitical turmoil. With the development of proletarian theater in particular, dances were performed–together with songs, choral chants, and ensemble movement—on the streets and outdoor areas as part of street plays that confronted the ongoing struggle of the masses (Brigino et al. 2012, 131). Moreover, dances were also accompanied by marching songs during political protests.

Groups that used dance along with other art forms for their plays include pioneering proletarian theater groupsKamanyang, Tanghalang Bayan, Gintong Silahis of Samahang Demokratiko ng Kabataan, and Panday Sining of KM. Kamanyang’s Pakikibaka (Struggle), for instance, highlighted the treachery of imperialists, land owners, and the bourgeois in the dance performance “Sayaw ng Pagtataksil” (Dance of Betrayal) (PAKSA and NPAA Handbook 1991, 15). The Konsehong Tagapag-ugnay ng Rebolusyonaryong Sining organized several activist cultural groups such as Gintong Silahis, Sining Bayan, Kamanyang, Tanghalang Bayan, and Panday Sining and mounted Pest of Badway satirizing CCP’s penchant for Western musicals, in particular, the The Best of Broadway. Comprising of parodied vignettes from Broadway musicals, the performance was directed by Behn Cervantes and Leo Rimando (Tiongson 2015; Quimpo 2012, 193). Dances and musicals choreographed by activists, thus, adhered to the themes and premise of proletarian art aimed to depict the mass campaign, the dialectical struggle in society, the triumph of mass action, and the symbolism for the movement’s future (PAKSA and NPAA Handbook 1991, 23-25).

 

Ballet

Immediately after World War II to the 1960s, foreign ballet and Spanish groups started visiting the country. In war-torn Manila and other places, the stars of Ballets Russes Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin came in 1948, dancing in the MGOHand a movie house in Bacolod. They were followed by ballet stars Mia Slavenska, Alexandra Danilova, and Frederic Franklin. In the 1950s, Danilova returned with Michael Maule, Mocelyn Larkin, and Roman Jasinsky, dancing with Filipino dancers brought together by Kane. The 1950s witnessed performances of foreign ballet companies in Manila such as the Martha Graham and her company of 14 dancers at the FEU Auditorium in 1955. She also delivered a lecture-demonstration on modern dance to an audience of dancers and teachers at the Mapua Memorial Hall (Ylanan and Ylanan 1974, 170-71). Then followed more dance companies such as the San Francisco Ballet in Manila in 1957 (Ross 2007, 155), the Katherine Dunham and Company at the MGOH in 1957 and the New York City Ballet at the UP Theater in 1958 (Alejandro 1978, 234-35). Some of these companies were brought in by Hungarian exile, Paul Szilard, who strengthened ballet in the country when he organized the Philippine Arts Theatre and produced Ballet Philippines, 1953, a presentation recognized for its infusion of folk dances into ballet theater. Through Szilard’s initiative as a New York impresario, various American ballet companies came to perform in Manila from 1958 onward. This also led to long-term residences and short visits by Russian, English, American, and other foreign ballet instructors who helped shape ballet education in the country.

One distinguished dancer and teacher-choreographer who returned to Manila in the 1950s was Ricardo Cassell after serving in the US Air Force during the war. This time he came with his wife Roberta who taught first for Anita Kane. On the other hand, Madrigal-Gonzalez invited him to teach in her Manila Ballet Academy, and to stage Giselle for her. Later Cassell and his wife founded their own dance studio on Taft Avenue. This gave birth to the Studio Dance Group in 1953. The latter embarked on a mission to professionalize ballet by establishing an annual season and building an adventurous repertoire, mostly of original works. Already Cassell had worked with Villanueva Reyes in Giselle, and pushed for the latter’s scholarship in New York. Many say that this youth was among the most gifted in those times.

Cassell’s choreographic work is substantial in musical and dramatic range: Fifth Symphony to Tchaikovsky, Adagietto to Mahler, The Transgressor to Gould, Ballet Blanc to Luigini, Sketch Class to Offenbach, Graduation Ball to Strauss, Backstage, Merry Wives of Windsor, Divertissements, Beauty and the Beast to Ravel, Peter and the Wolf to Prokofiev, and several dances to Gershwin, including for a local film version of the composer’s musical Lady Be Good.

Cassell nurtured the artistic growth of many Filipino dancers: Villanueva Reyes, Julie and Rose Borromeo, Corazon Generoso-Iñigo, Elizabeth Guasch, Greta Monserrat, Yvonne de los Reyes, Cristina Carrion-Bichara, Amerlia Garcia-Yulo, Mercy Lauchengco-Drilon, Lulu Puertollano, Alice Reyes, Eddie Elejar, Marcelino Garcia, Tony Llacer, Israel Gabriel, Cesar Mendoza, Mario Recto, and Pancho Uytiepo. But in 1955 the Catholic hierarchy banned ballet dancing for girls, and this discouraged the Cassells who decided to return to the United Statesin 1956. During their brief stay, Manila enjoyed regular ballet performances for the first time. The dancers they left behind continued to professionalize the art.

Following the performances of foreign companies in Manila and the proliferation of local ballet instructors, choreographers established ballet schools such as the School of Classic Dance of Anita Kane and the Classic Ballet Academy of Remedios de Oteyza which both opened in 1947; the Hariraya Dance Company of Totoy de Oteyza and Inday Gaston-Mañosa, 1968; and Vella Damian’s School of Ballet and Dance Arts, 1969. The Manila Ballet Academy was deemed to be the largest dance school in the 1950s. In the regional scene, ballet schools were pioneered by Carmen Dakudao Locsin of Davao through her Locsin Dance Workshop which was founded in 1947. In Cebu, Fe Sala-Villarica established the Cebu Ballet Center in 1951 (Alejandro 1978, 49; Villaruz 1994, 124; Alejandro and Villaruz 1978, 235- 36).

Parallel to the growth of ballet schools was the establishment of a cultural arena to host ballet performances. Built in 1969, CCP served as an important venue for the staging of ballet, modern dance, and other cultural shows. Other places where significant ballet performances were held during the period were the FEU Auditorium, University of the Philippines (UP) Theater, Mapua Auditorium, Araneta Coliseum, Rizal Theater, Philam Life Auditorium, Meralco Theater, and the Folk Arts Theater (later Tanghalang Francisco Baltazar) (Villaruz 1994, 52).

The early pioneers who developed ballet in the country were Polish-Russian Luva Adameit and New Zealander Anita Kane who trained the first generation of Filipino ballet dancers and choreographers during the neocolonial period.Anita Kane--who remained active in mentoring ballet dancers even after her retirement in the 1970s--promoted “Filipinism” in ballet. While touring around the country with her Kane (later Pamana) Ballet Company, she produced performances inspired by local themes and folkdance movements. Kane’s Filipinist ballet output during the neocolonial period include the staging of Reconstruction Ballet, 1951; La Mer, 1957; Mah Jong, 1962; Mutya ng Dagat (Muse of the Sea), 1950; Inulan sa Pista (Rained-out Feast), 1961; Aswang, 1969; and Dularawan: Gintong Salakot (Image-Play: Golden Salacot), 1969 . Luva Adameit, on the other hand, set up the Cosmopolitan Ballet and Dancing School on Pennsylvania Street, San Marcelino, Manila where she mentored Leonor Orosa-Goquingco.

Following Adameit and Kane’s Filipinism, Goquingco also incorporated indigenous themes in her stylized works especially in the well-recognized performances such as Noli Dance Suite, 1956, which integrated scenes from Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not); The MagicGarden, 1958, which is an adaptation of Nick Joaquin’s fiction; and Filipinescas: Philippine Life, Legend, and Lore in Dance, 1961, which is a full-evening suite. In 1950, Orosa-Goquingco worked on The Story of Man which was danced to a speech and singing choir, and in 1971, she choreographed for William Butler Yeats’s Kalbaryo (Calvary), an adaptation by Philippine Educational Association which was directed by Brooks Jones. She also worked in drama with her own Her Son, Jose, 1955, which composer Lucrecia Reyes Kasilag later developed into an operatorio in 1976. Among her works set to Western music are The Firebird to Stravinsky and The Clowns to Meyerbeer, and pieces in the Celebrazione ’89 program that marked her 50 years in dance. She danced for a cultural mission to Japan in 1939 and acted in New York as a student in drama at Columbia University. She brought her Filipinescas Dance Company on several world tours in the 1960s and 1970s, winning festival awards.

Remedios “Totoy” de Oteyza, another student of Adameit, studied in Paris with retired Russian prima ballerinas Olga Preobrajenska and Lubov Egorova, and the young choreographer George Balanchine who influenced her greatly. This was in her abstract ballets that were inspired by music, an interest drawn from her musically-inclined family. These include two ballets to piano concertos by Grieg and Tchaikovsky,Rachmaninoff’s Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini, Tchaikovsky’s Serenade for Strings, Frank’s Symphonic Variations, Khachaturian’s Masquerade Suite ,Gershwin’s Rhapsody in Blue, Rimsky-Korsakov’s Capriccio Espagnol, Ravel’s Bolero, Dohnanyi’s for a story ballet The Haunted Ballroom,and Rodolfo Cornejo’s Spectrum.

Her ballet troupe evolved from the De Oteyza Ballet to become the Manila Ballet Company, and finally to Hariraya Ballet (earlier Dance) Company in 1968. Through the years she collaborated closely with Gaston-Mañosa as its ballet mistress. For her part, the latter became the first artistic director of Philippine Ballet Theatre founded in 1987. Both women taught and choreographed for artists who became leaders in Philippine dance—Joji Felix-Velarde, Maribel Aboitiz (who both started with Adameit), Nelly Ledesma, Sony Lopez-Gonzalez, Lydia Madarang-Gaston, Lulu Puertollano, Vella Damian, Effie Nañas, Nida Onglengco, Maniya Barredo, Maiqui and Mia (Monica) Mañosa, Gina Katigbak, Eddie Elejar, Jamin Alcoriza, Edgar Mendoza, Rene Dimacali, Eric Cruz, and Basilio.

Aside from these performances, other native-inspired modern ballet performances using Filipino folklore include the production of Jose Garcia Villa’s Mir-i-nisa,1969, choreographed by Julie Borromeo and Felicitas Layag-Radaic; Nick Joaquin’s “May Day Eve,” 1971, by Radaic; and Juru-Pakal (The Enchanted Kris), 1971, based on the legendary story of Indarapatra and Sulayman choreographed by Eddie Elejar. All these came from Dance Theater Philippines.

Towards the 1960s, a development in dance emerged through the popularization of Philippine dance theater or creative dance (Goquingco 1980, 231). It was during this period that Broadway presentations blended with ballet and musical productions. Dance choreographers Julie and Rose Borromeo, starting in the 1960s, Lally and Terry Aldeguer, in the 1970s worked for Broadway adaptations and local musicals.

From 1960s onward, frequent visits of European ballet groups in the Philippines intensified due to the development in aviation and improvement of telecommunication systems worldwide (Corpus 2007, 36). There were more visits from international ballet troupes such as the Royal Ballets of London and Copenhagen; France’s Paris Opera, Les Grands Ballets de France, and Ballet Theatre Contemporaine; America’s New York City Ballet and San Francisco Ballet; and Soviet Union’s Kirov, Bolshoi, and Perm and the Folkloric Ensembles. There were also visits made by ballet companies and folkloric troupes from Israel, Cuba, Venezuela, India, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, China, Taiwan, Thailand, Indonesia, and Malaysia (Villaruz 1989, 19).

With the continued development in ballet, two professional ballet companies were founded in 1968: the Hariraya Dance (later Ballet) Company and Dance Theater Philippines (DTP). Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company was founded later in 1970. Still echoing the Filipinist trend of the period, these ballet companies continued to incorporate native themes into their material. Philippine life and legends became common sources of ideas for choreographic works. The Hariraya, guided by de Oteyza and Gaston-Mañosa, assigned Lulu Puertollano as ballet mistress and trained ballerinas like Effie Nañas, Vella Damian, Maniya Barredo, and Nida Onglengco. It produced Legend of Sarimanok by Bayani Mendoza de Leon, Reynaldo Alejandro, and Roberto Caballero, 1968; and Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), by Rodolfo Cornejo, Remedios de Oteyza, and Inday Gaston-Mañosa, 1970.

DTP was led by its three founders: choreographers Julie Borromeo, Felicitas Layag-Radaic, and Eddie Elejar. Later, Tony Llacer and El Gabriel joined as ballet masters and choreographers of the company. In 1968, DTP staged Katakataka sin Rajah Indarapatra (Stories of Rajah Indarapatra)by composer Jose Maceda and choreographer Eddie Elejar, Babae at Lalake (Woman and Man) by Ramon Tapales and Julie Borromeo, and Zagalas de Manila (Young Maidens of Manila) by Julio Nakpil and Julie Borromeo. In 1969, it produced Kalingan by Angel Peña and Julie Borromeo and Tanan (Elopement) by Juan Silos Jr and Layag-Radaic.

Ballet during the neocolonial period flourished in the Philippines in three ways: through visits of foreign dance troupes and popular choreographers in the country; by the establishment of ballet schools through foreign and local tutelage; and via Filipinism or adoption of ballet as a dance form to express native themes and styles. The art form flourished due to the creative adaptation of both its foreign and local adherents who molded the dance form to suit the Philippine cultural landscape.

 

Modern Dance

Despite the challenges it faced when it veered away from strict rules of ballet, modern dance continued to flourish due to the determined efforts of its adherents who aimed at popularizing the form during this period. Modern dance had previously gained local admirers and practitioners in the Philippine stage following the introduction of the form by renowned choreographers such as Ruth St Denis and Ted Shawn in 1926, and Vienesse Kaethe Hauser and Czech Dubsky-Zipper in the 1930s.

A student of Hauser, Spanish modern dancer Manolo Rosado, returned to Manila in 1958 following his success in the international stage. Rosado previously went to the USA in 1952 to study with Shawn, Graham, and Jose Limon. To identify himself, he bannered his “mystic and poetic” style in his teaching and presentations. He went on to dance with a Viennese company and Spanish ballet companies in Spain and Mexico. He brought back to Manila many of his heroic and poignant solo works. Among them were The Blind Beggar to Chopin, Judas to M. Salvador, El Greco to Turina, and Don Quixote to W. Newmann. In the 1960s, he created pieces based on folk traditions and life in Quiapo, The Debutant, The Fisherman and the Mermaid, and Ultimo Adios (Last Farewell). Although he never had a group of his own, he staged ensemble works for others like the groups of de Oteyza and Julie Borromeo. His teacher Shawn called him “among the most talented artists of our generation,” while dancer-author La Meri hailed him as “the poet of dance.” Rosado’s influence was limited but inspiring for those who witnessed his art.

After World War II, Dubsky-Zipper also returned to the country after failing to collect funds in the US to establish an arts center by reviving Manila Ballet Moderne and conducting USAFFE dance concerts. Upon her return, the prolific Dubsky-Zipper collaborated with local artists such as Cesar Legaspi and Nick Joaquin for Khatchaturian’s The Idol, 1952, and Hindesmith’s Pieta, 1953. She also choreographed Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream and The Fateful Dress, 1951, and the ballet opera Bastien and Bastienne, 1952, to Mozart. She produced operas featuring dances such as Die Fledermaus to Strauss, 1954; Acis and Galatea to Mandel, 1959; notable, Tagalog productions of Carmen, with Conching Rosal, 1956 and 1958; and The Soldier’s Tale to Stravinsky, 1969 (Villaruz 1994, 54).

Dubsky-Zipper also mentored renowned dancer-choreographers Corazon Generoso (later, Iñigo), Ricardo Reyes, Lucio Sandoval, Adina Rigor Ferrer, Magie Shee, and Remedios Villanueva-Piñon. Dancers and choreographers who danced for her include: Remedios de Oteyza, Mercedes Lauchengco (later Drilon), Roberta Cassell, Carlyn Manning, Rosalia Merino-Santos, Lydia Madarang (later Gaston), Greta Monserrat, Inday Gaston (later Mañosa), Joji Felix (later Velarde), Chloe Cruz-Romulo, Jamin Alcoriza, Rally Calvo, Alcuin Pastrana aka Al Quinn, and Eddie Elejar (Villaruz 1994, 54).

After Dubsky-Zipper, other foreign practitioners of modern dance followed suit. In 1955, Martha Graham visited Manila and came back in the 1970s. Alvin Ailey and the Lavallade-Ailey American Dance Company presented dances characterized by jazz movement vocabulary at the Araneta Coliseum in 1962 (Ylanan and Ylanan 1974, 172). Supported by the US Department of State Cultural Exchange Program and the Bayanihan Folk Arts Center, Jose Limon and his company had two shows at the Rizal Theater in 1963. Aside from these two performances, Limon also had performances in Cebu, and a lecture-demonstration of dance techniques to an audience of teachers at the Philippine Women’s University (Ylanan and Ylanan 1974, 171). American Paul Taylor visited the country in 1967 during his Middle East and Asia tour and shared with Filipino dancers his technique of incorporating everyday movements in dance.

The year 1972 saw more international dance figures in the Philippines. Modern dance teacher-choreographer Norman Walker had a short stint as choreographer and dance master of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Dance Workshop. Carole Johnson held master classes and lecture-demonstrations at the Thomas Jefferson Library, FEU, and the CCP. Highlighting the marriage of theater and dance, she showed how these two could be used in creating works with important issues. And also giving master classes to ballet and modern dance students at the CCP was Emily Frankel whose experimental use of everyday sounds in her performance at the CCP Little Theater that same year left quite an impression on the audience (Ylanan and Ylanan 1974, 171). In 1976, the phenomenal Alwin Nikolais brought his innovative Dance Theater. He composed his music, choreographed, and designed his lights and costumes.

With various foreign choreographers visiting the country, more modern dancers such as Pauline Koner, Garth Welch, Takaka Asakawa, and Gray Veredon were involved in mentoring future practitioners and performers of modern dance (Villaruz 1989, 31).

Following her mentors Hauser and Dubsky-Zipper, Rosalia Merino-Santos went on to pursue modern dance for her master’s degree in Wisconsin with Margaret H’Doubler (who started the first dance degree in US), and also with Martha Graham and Doris Humphrey in Bennington College, and Mary Wigman and Harald Kreutzberg in Europe. Her thesis in Wisconsin titled “What Is Dance,” 1958, was a staged lecture-demonstration on the choreographic process. Her choreographies ranged from the abstract to the thematic as in Fanfare and Feminine Gender ,both in 1958, and Opus 17. Then she turned to Filipino subjects: Ugaling Pilipino (Filipino Attitudes), 1963; excerpts from Sari Manok, 1968; and a part in Dularawan:Gintong Salakot, 1969, for the inaugural season of the CCP. With CCP she also staged Halina’t Maglaro (Come and Play), 1971. Her most noted work is Of Cocks and Kings, based on a legend retold by Alejandro Roces and to music by Kasilag. While teaching at Far Eastern University (FEU), she directed both the innovative FEU Modern Experimental Dance Troupe and the FEU Folk Dance Troupe that won raves at Theatre de Nations in 1959. In her active years, she kept affiliation with the Philippine Folk Dance Society (PFDS) and the Francisca Reyes Aquino Memorial Foundation (FRAMF).

Other dancers who were influenced to promote modern dance in the country were Rosado, who taught and briefly directed the University of the East Dance Troupe, and Carmen Adevoso, who taught modern dance in public schools for a brief period before immigrating to the United States.

It was Alice Reyes, however, who made modern dance earn “a legitimate place in Philippine theatrical dance scene” through the debut performance of her Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company at the CCP during the Philippine Music and Dance Festival in 1970 (Corpus 2007, 42- 43). Trained in modern dance at the Sarah Lawrence, Reyes reworked her master’s thesis Amada, 1970, which was inspired by Nick Joaquin’s “Summer Solstice,” after forming the company of 16 members from DTP, the Bayanihan alumni, and the UE Dance Company. In the same year, Alice Reyes and Modern Modern Dance Company presented the one-act ballet Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf) as its offering to the Philippine Music and Dance Festival in association with the League of Filipino Composers at the CCP. Showcased along with Hariraya Ballet Company’s presentation of Adarna, Itim Asu was highly regarded by critics as an achievement in Philippine dance (Vida 1994, 152-153).

The company’s success led to the creation of the CCP dance summer workshop with Eddie Elejar in 1970. Featured pieces were those of Alice Reyes, Eddie Elejar, Antonio Fabella, Gener Caringal, Rosalia Merino-Santos, Miro Zolan, Norman Walker, and Esteban “Basilio” Villaruz. By 1972, the Philippines was assured of having established a modern dance troupe whose leading proponents aimed to develop the dance form for future audiences.

 

 

Indigenous Dances

During the Third Republic, Philippine folk dance continued to thrive among the populace as ritual dances remained relevant to the lives of the many groups throughout the archipelago. Folk dances continued to be performed among the ethnic groups. These dances may be classified as dances of prayer or ritual such as the dugso of the Bukidnon, dinuy-a and bangibang of the Ifugao, pattung of the Kalinga, and the ritual courtship and wedding dances such as the salidsid of Tanudan, Southern Kalinga, tadek inlaud of the lowland Tinguian from Abra, and takik of the Western Mountain Province. There were also mimetic dances that imitated daily scenes and activities in the community. These were either mimetic dances that imitated animals such as the bird dances banog-banog of theBlaan,binaylan of the Higaonon, kinabua of the Mandaya,man-manok of the Manobo,paypato oftheIfugao, and the linggisan of the Tausug; or occupational dances rendering community activities such as planting, fishing, smoking out of bees, training for war, and headhunting. Examples of these dances are the tawti of the Tausug, pinapanilan of the Aeta; and the different war dances like the kayaw, also known as mamakar or mangangayaw of theBontok from the Central Mountain Province, the binabayani of theAeta in Zambales, the ballangbang or tallibeng of the Applais group in the Western Mountain Province, and the pallo-ok of the Tinguian or Itneg of Abra.

Among theChristianized groups there were also prayer dances like the turumba in Pakil, Laguna, pandangguhan in Obando, subli in Batangas, malaket-a-polka (happy polka) in Estanza, Pangasinan, ati-atihan in Kalibo, Aklan, sinulog in Cebu, and diyandi in Iligan City, Lanao del Norte. Like the indigenous groups, the Christians have their mimetic animal folk dances such as the tinikling (tikling birds), itik-itik (ducks), and sinalampati (doves) and mock war dances like the maglalatik in Zapote and Loma of Biñan, Laguna.In weddings and other celebrations, the Christianized groups danced the mascota in Cagayan and Isabela, kuratsa in the Visayas and Bicol, kuradang in Samar, the habanera in Ilocos, Cagayan, and Pangasinan, polka sa nayon in Batangas, and the polka tagala in the Tagalog region.

However, it remained a danger that folk dances might be lost with the changing times. Confronting this challenge of collecting, documenting, and researching on regional dances, folk dancer and researcher Francisca Reyes-Aquino, since the 1930s, contributed to the documentation, preservation, and enrichment of Philippine folk dances. With the support of UP Pres Jorge Bacobo, music composer Antonino Buenaventura, and photographer Ramon Tolentino, Aquino intensified and expanded her research which led to local and international publications of her valuable works on Philippine folk dances. In recognition of her works, Aquino was honoured in 1962 by the Ramon Magsaysay Foundation that pays tribute to distinguished Asians. Ever a guiding spirit in Philippine dance, Aquino was the first to be named national artist in dance in 1973.

Within this period, Reyes-Aquino published the Philippine National Dances and later, the six-volume Philippine Folk Dance,1953-70,as well as other writings: Philippine National Dances, 1946, Dances for All Occasions, 1950, Philippine Folk Dances and Songs, 1966, as coauthor; and many other works on Physical Education (PE) and dance. In 1949, she established the Filipiniana Folk Dance Society, composed largely of educators all over the country. Through her pioneering work, further studies on regional folk dances increased. These materials then became useful sources, especially for public school teachers, who use Aquino’s six-volume work on Philippine folk dances in teaching native dances in the PE program established in public schools in 1915.

As volumes of Aquino’s research works were published both in the Philippines and the United States, universities and regional colleges all over the country continued Aquino’s explorations. Moreover, regional and national researchers further pursued Aquino’s aim to intensify folk dance studies in the country. Among these noted dance scholars were Juan Miel, Petronila Suarez, Jovita Sison-Friese, Teresita Ines-Pascua, Jose Balcena, Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, and Libertad and Joan Fajardo. Other researches were also done by artistic directors of Folk Dance companies such as Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula of the Bayanihan Dance Troupe, Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte of the Baranggay Dance Troupe, and Ramon Obusan of the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group.

University-based folk dance troupes established during the period include the University of the Philippines’s Folk Song and Club/Troupe, 1948; the Philippine Normal College’s Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe, 1958; the Leyte State University’s Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company, 1960; the Mindanao State University’s Darangan Cultural Troupe, 1966; and the University of Santo Tomas’s Salinggawi Dance Troupe, 1967 (Iñigo 1994, 79).

As various folk dance troupes began to flourish locally, Philippine dance troupes were beginning to be recognized in the international stage in the 1950s. In 1958, theBayanihan Philippine Dance Company caught the world’s attention through its success at the Brussels Universal Exposition, which led to their Broadway and television performances across Europe and the US. Three years after Bayanihan’s victory, a company called Ice Capades produced an ice skating show based on Philippine dances in Atlantic City, New Jersey. With Lucrecia Urtula as consultant, the company mounted the Philippine Dances Suite, 1961,featuring Philippine folk dances like singkil and sakuting (Garcia 2015).

Aside from the Bayanihan, the Far Eastern University (FEU) Folk Dance Troupe also succeeded in dominating the international dance scene through its presentation at the Theatre des Nations in France in 1957 and its win in Mallorca and Caceres, Spain. Other dance groups that have gone on world tours and successfully gained international recognition include the Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe of the PNC, the Leyte Filipiniana Dance Troupe, and the Fiesta Filipina Dance Troupe (Alejandro 1978, 50-51). In 1971, Ramon Obusan founded the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group (ROFG) that subsequently gained international prominence and awards. Like the Bayanihan, the ROFG was always backed by a musical ensemble, for rondalla and ethnic music. Obusan also did the costuming and scenery for his group, drawn from his broad collection of cultural artifacts.

Indeed, the 1950s onwards marked the renaissance of Philippine folk dance not only because local dance troupes achieved international success, but also because Philippine folk dances were popularized through their inclusion in local films. Years before this decade, however, LVN, one of the country’s biggest movie producers, had already started showing musicals. Its inaugural film titled Giliw Ko (My Beloved), 1939, was followed by Hiyas ng Dagat (Treasure of the Sea), another musical drama, 1941 (Tiongson 2008, 24). It was in the 1950s, however, when Manuel Conde, considered one of the Philippine’s best directors, began creating films integrating Philippine folk dances. In 1955, moviegoers enjoyed thepamamanhikan(asking for the woman’s hand in marriage) scene in the satirical movie Pilipino Kostum-No Touch! (Filipino Custom-No Touch!) The encounter between the Hispanized and Americanized Filipinos was depicted in a “dance debate” between the “conservatives” who performed the cariñosa, pandanggo sa ilaw, tinikling, maglalatik, and “the moderns” who performed the charleston,boogie-woogie, cha-cha, and rock n’ roll (Tiongson 2008, 94-95). Also shown in the same year was the box-office hit musical Ikaw Kasi! (It’s All Your Fault) which entertained the audience with songs, dances, and impressive gowns. This was followed in 1956 by another box-office hit, the Christmas musical, Bahala Na (Whatever Happens). Among the reasons behind the latter’s success was the entertaining repertoire of 30 pairs of colorfully-costumed dancers performing modernized interpretations of folk dances like the tinikling, cariñosa, patpat, and the bao (coconut shell) dance (Tiongson 2008, 104). Tingnan Natin (Let’s See), also a Christmas musical comedy, was shown in 1957 (Tiongson 2008, 118).

Folk dances were not only featured in musicals but also in LVN films that were critical of Philippine society. The popular Juan Tamad Goes to Congress (Lazy Juan Goes to Congress), 1959, presented the Baranggay Dance Troupe of the PNC. The movie inspired the production of another Juan Tamad movie, Juan Tamad Goes to Society (Lazy Juan Goes to Society), 1960, which also featured a folk dance troupe. To ensure the success of Society, LVN hired a musical director for the film and got the FEU Dance Group to perform Maranao and various folk dances under the direction of Corazon Iñigo (Tiongson 2008, 143).

Even while Society was in the production process, Conde, director of the Juan Tamad movies, was already working on another movie featuring the Bayanihan Dance Company which was already making waves in the dance scene after it was applauded at the Brussels World’s Fair. With the theme of community development, the movie titled Bayanihan, 1959, had a well-shot dance sequence which Conde later edited and transformed into a 10-minute documentary on the dance group. The film, which competed in the 5th International Film Festival on Music and Dance in 1960, in Valencia, Spain, did not only win the gold medal but also the silver medal in the Ibero-Americana y Filipina Section of the 4th International Festival of Documentary and Short Films in Bilbao, Spain that same year. The documentary continued to garner more local and international awards (Tiongson 2008, 150).

Aside from the popularity of folk dances as a result of media exposure, they were also performed widely in schools as part of contests, field demonstrations, and performances to welcome visiting guests and dignitaries.

Meanwhile, Spanish dances continued to thrive. Flamenco dancer Ruben Nieto studied in the Philippines and abroad. Coming home, he taught his partner Rose Borromeo, and formed an ad hoc ensemble with Marilen Martinez, Lito Arellano, Bobby Ongkiko, and danseur Eddie Elejar. He moved to Madrid in the 1970s. Guillermo Gomez, whose mother studied under the renowned Antonia Merce or La Argentina, also taught Spanish dances. According to Gomez, aside from his mother’s Spanish repertoire, she likewise danced the cariñosa,a Filipino version of the pandanggo,and the binasuan. The Portuguese Jose Zarah with Bebe Marcaida contributed to the popularization of Spanish dances until the 1960s. Although there was a period when interest in this type of dance waned, there was a revival of enthusiasm in the 1990s.

Later, the popularization of folk dance extended to commercial places, in hotels, clubs, restaurants, and foreign cruise ships where dances performed for visitors and customers, signaling the future commercialization of the folk dance form (Iñigo 1994, 80). With the Philippines’ link to Hawaii during the American period, Hawaiian, Tahitian, and Polynesian dancing became popular. Learning was formalized in dance schools, and went on stage in clubs and theaters. Well-known teachers were Lucy Gonzales, Naty Bas, Chiqui Ocampo, Nenuca Ros, Carmen Garcia, and Carmen Gonzales. Among the active groups were the Pacifica Cultural Dance Troupe, Maile Dance Company, Tiare Dance Troupe and the Aldeguer Sisters. Perhaps with a different kind of dancing required by clubs in Japan, the interest and investment in these faded away.

 

Social Dances

American influences in dance did not only lead to the country’s accommodation of Western cultural products but they also altered the social life of the Filipino people. While rural Filipinos continued to dance Philippine folk dances, urban dwellers revelled in foreign steps and dance styles for social dancing. Filipinos continued, throughout the duration of the Third Republic, to yearn for American beats and trends by performing rhumba, tango, samba, mambo, paso doble, cha-cha,and the limbo rock.

These American dances were seen on TV variety shows that flourished during the rock and roll era of the 1950s. Dancing shows on TV mirrored the vibrancy of social dances in the country. Cha-cha and boogie were popularized in The Nida-Nestor Show , 1964-72 which featured the popular tandem of Nida Blanca and Nestor de Villa. It was choreographed by Julie Borromeo who also worked with members of Dance Theater Philippines for Pilita Corales’s weekly show.

Dubbed as the original “Dancing Queen,” Helen Gamboa hosted her own show titled Helen, 1966-70, which also featured her signature song and dance “Bang-Shang-A-Lang.” Another dancing show, Dance-O-Rama, 1967–72, featured ad-lib or maskiPops (from “maski papaano” or anything goes) dance moves derived from popular dances such as chicken, mashed potatoes, the shovel, and watusi. There was also the hit TV show Dance Time with Chito, 1962–72, which was popularized by Al Quinn, Lito Calzado, and Chito Feliciano.

During the 1940s and 1950s, Filipinos danced to popular steps of mambo,samba, and cha-cha as well as camel walk, aqua velva, shiminy, esalato, and boogaloo (Bercades 1994, 103). A specific feature of popular American dances in the 1950s was its faster speed and increased dance dynamics; for instance, the boogie-woogie ’s combination complicated dance patterns and movements, and rock n’ roll incorporated ballroom acrobatics and somersault in its performance. Toward the 1960s and 1970s, popular dance trends of the period such as mashed potato, twist, boogaloo, bossa nova, frug, pachanga, watusi, and hustle were popularized and taught in television dance shows (Villaruz 1994, 76).

These fashionable dances of the period were performed usually in cabarets or known locally askabaret, a spot for late-night dancing entertainment for the urban masses, which were still popular in small towns during the 1950s and 1960s (Villaruz 1994, 57). Meanwhile, for urban elites, membership in social clubs such as Kahirup, Smiles, Mancomunicad Pampangueña, and Club Filipino allowed them to enjoy foreign dances that blended with Philippine folk tradition. Aside from this, there were grand balls thrown by rich families or enjoyed at big hotels such as Oriente Hotel.

Ballroom dancing schools were found all over Quiapo in the 1960s which continued to feature swing, mambo, and limbo rock (Villaruz 1994, 57). Over all, there was a vibrant acceptance of popular American dance trends, mostly in urban areas, by Filipinos who were continuously enticed by the lure of American cultural products during the neocolonial period.

 

Epilogue

Philippine dance during the neocolonial period was a melange of cultural meanings as it registered the sociopolitical changes after the country was granted its independence. The strong American cultural influences that seeped through Philippine cultural practices were visible in the changes in the dance scene. The Third Republic might have been characterized by how Filipinos continued to be fascinated by the West but it also showed a workingwithandaroundthe onslaught of changes. Foreign dance choreographers, companies, and pop dancers in the United States might have made a mark in the history of Philippine dance, but so did the works of Filipino scholars who were committed to documenting and preserving the country’s folk dances. As much as there was the allure of anything American, there was likewise the desire to discover what was “Filipino.” There was, in other words, a counterculture.

Media, in particular, film, might have been greatly responsible for the migration of American musicals to the Philippines, but the movies were also used to depict the multifaceted encounter between the foreign and the local cultures. Philippine dance anchored on the Filipino body manifested the overlayerings of American and Hispanic colonial legacies. As an ever-changing form, this dance and its various types, managed to keep its peculiar rhythm informed by the beat of the nation’s history. And when the country pushed towards mid 20thcentury and found itself amidst the Cold War and the strong ideological influence of the Left in China, Philippine dance took another turn and became a strong form of political expression. In the bodies of activists, dance did not only protest against the state, capitalists, and the oligarchy. It also embodied an ideal for the country that was heading toward a dark future. From the time the Philippines was granted its political independence to the impending declaration of martial law, Philippine dance, despite colonial influences, was an affirmation of the local culture and a somatic expression of the people’s aspirations. Dance in the country was a fertile ground for the battle between cultural and political meanings. As the Philippine nation continued to be enchanted by the West yet simultaneously pursued a vision of independence, Philippine dance remained tenacious and transformative. Dance was a constant reworking of both new and familiar idioms, generating nuanced ways of understanding the Filipino identity. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz
