Introduction

Three years before the declaration of martial law, the State already prepared its art and culture institutions that could complement and lend an amiable face to an authoritarian rule. In 1969, amid mounting political unrest and criticism against the Marcos administration, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) was built to focus on the performing arts such as ballets, operas, and orchestra concerts. The CCP was part of the strategy of then First Lady Imelda Marcos to gain international recognition for the Philippines. The CCP also fitted the plan to make the country a hub for international events and a haven for tourists. During its inauguration, the CCP commissioned the creation of Mir-i-nisa, 1969, by several dance companies led by Dance Theater Philippines. Mir-ini-sa was a grand ballet production based on Jose Garcia Villa’s love story involving Muslim Filipino characters. The CCP also became the home base of Alice Reyes who created modern dance choreography in 1970 starting with the First Modern Dance Concert andfollowed by Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf) based on Virgie Moreno’s provocative play that fuses historical facts with fiction. Despite the encouragement to use native themes with western art forms, the State’s culture and arts program was labelled as elitist and colonial by Marcos’s political rivals and by militant youth activists who were then relentlessly staging huge political rallies that often ended up in violent dispersals.

Dance and drama were used as effective tools of protest in the big rallies led by student activists in Manila during the eve of martial law. The battle cry of youth activists then was to resolve the fundamental problems of the Filipino people, namely, American “imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucrat capitalism” (Guerrero 1970, 40-68). Red Banner dances, an influence from the art forms of Mao Tse Tung’s Chinese Cultural Revolution, were the usual choreography that complemented marching protest songs. One of the most daring face-offs between the State and the student demonstrators happened right at the corridor of CCP. The Konsehong Tagapag-ugnay ng Rebolusyonaryong Sining led militant cultural groups such as Gintong Silahis, Sining Bayan, Kamanyang, Tanghalang Bayan, and Panday Sining to mount a show titled Pest of Badway, a parody of the CPP presentation at the time, The Best of Broadway. Behn Cervantes and Leo Rimando directed the production consisting of farcical vignettes from Broadway musicals. The cultural activists daringly performed near the famous CCP fountain on the gala premiere to mock what they considered as another elitist production supported by the State and the ruling class (Tiongson 2015; Quimpo 2012, 193). Such song-and-dance performances were effective tools of entertainment and education during the pickets and rallies that stormed the national capital region of the country. But the huge youth demonstrations were silenced by a single declaration from Marcos.


 
 

 

On 21 Sep 1972, by virtue of Proclamation No 1081, Pres Ferdinand Marcos signed the declaration of martial law in the Philippines. Congress was abolished, democratic rights were curtailed, and press operations were halted. The Roces-owned Sunday Times Magazine was closed, its last edition which was never circulated had ballerina Tina Santos on the cover (Villaruz 2005, 227). Television and radio stations were shut down. The National Media Production Center and the Office of the Press Secretary seized ABS-CBN Channel 4. Critics of the government--politicians, members of the press, student activists, or mass leaders--were arrested and imprisoned. Those who eluded arrest went into hiding, sought political asylum abroad, or joined the underground movement. There were virtually no opponents left to challenge the regime except for the insurgencies led by the Communist Party of the Philippines, the National Democratic Front, and the New People’s Army on one hand; and the Moro National Liberation Front and the Bangsa Moro Army on the other.

Southern Philippines became the target of massive militarization as Pres Marcos threatened to wipe out Moro insurgents in three weeks’ time after 21 Sep 1972. Before the deadline, 400 rebels in Marawi City defeated government troops. In reprisal, whole divisions of armed forces were deployed to Southern Philippines. By the end of 1972, the fighting escalated into a gory and bitter war that killed an estimated 60,000 to 80,000 civilians and rendered about one million people homeless and poor. At least 200,000 refugees fled to other parts of the Philippines and to Sabah. Contrary to the notion that a military rule was imposed because of Muslim insurgency, it was militarization under martial law that fueled the armed rebellion led by Nur Misuari (Mackenna 1998; Rasul 2015; Buendia 2006).

Several months after martial law declaration, the broadcast media resumed normal operations. Kanlaon Broadcasting Network Channel 9 which later became Radio PhilippinesNetwork was run by Roberto S. Benedicto, a Marcos ally who was also the Philippine ambassador to Japan and the head of the country’s sugar industry. Benedicto then proceeded to open the Banahaw Broadcasting Network Channel 2 and the Inter-island Broadcasting Corporation Channel 8 (Crewdson 1986). In 1974, GMA Network Channel 7 operated under Malacañan official Gilberto Duavit Sr, accountant Menardo Jimenez, and lawyer Felipe Gozon (GMA Network Corporate Profile 2015).

 

 

The architects of martial law knew that culture and the arts must be utilized to build acceptance and to popularize the tenets of the Bagong Lipunan or New Society. First Lady Imelda Marcos took the lead in the realm of art and culture. She immediately implemented projects that utilized art and culture to exemplify the good intentions and programs of the New Society. This was carried out through the construction of cultural institutions and edifices, and through the use of ethnic and folk icons for the goals of the regime. In 1973, the National Arts Center (NAC) was built on top of the legendary Mt Makiling, an active volcano. The unique arts center is an ivory tower set amidst an idyllic forest. Imelda Marcos in her speech during the NAC groundbreaking rites said that its establishment is the beginning of the “rebirth” of Filipino culture. The NAC in 1977 was expanded with the inauguration of the Philippine High School for the Arts that offered a dance program on western ballet and folk dance, along with programs in the other arts.

To offset the image that the New Society only supported high art, the First Lady built the Folk Arts Theater (FAT) in 1974. During the inauguration of the FAT, deemed to be the venue for arts catering to the masses, a grand street parade titled Kasaysayan ng Lahi (History of the Race) was mounted. It was designed to be the biggest national parade with over 20,000 participants that included performing artists, members of ethnic communities, local officials from all over the archipelago, and the contestants of the 1974 Miss Universe beauty pageant. Kasaysayan ng Lahi essayed the history of the Filipino race from prehistory to the New Society. The spectacle attracted thousands of spectators along Roxas Boulevard and was broadcast live on nationwide TV (Jarales 2013, 5; Namiki 2007, 45). The FAT was the venue of the 1974 Miss Universe Pageant, a major cultural project of the regime to prettify the image of martial law, especially to foreign media. The first to be held in Asia, the 1974 Miss Universe pageant was aired live via satellite all over the world on 19 Jul 1974 from the FAT, with the Philippine’s Margarita Moran as the outgoing Miss Universe. To soften the image of military rule, the pageant opened with the Philippine Military Academy’s honor guards marching gallantly with sashaying contestants. The crisscrossing guards and beauty queens were choreographed to create a kaleidoscope of masculine and feminine bodies. The pageant also featured a production number by the beauty contestants clad in Filipina costume, executing simple footwork and singing “Pamulinawen,” the favorite Ilocano folk song of Pres Ferdinand Marcos (Miss Universe Beauty Pageant 1974; Romulo 1987, 98).

Tourism was a big program of the New Society, designed to enhance the image of the Marcos regime. Eight months from the imposition of martial law, the Department of Tourism was established in May 1973, headed by Jose Aspiras who was a former congressman and an avid follower of Imelda Marcos. The Philippines was promoted as a peaceful country and an ideal place for international events and conferences. One huge promotional project was the hosting of the IMF-World Bank Conference in 1976, slated at the newly-built Philippine International Convention Center within the CCP Complex. The preparation for the International Monetary Fund-World Bank Conference remains in history as one of the classic examples of incredible tourism development. The grand project resulted in the frenzied establishment of luxury hotels using government funds and taxpayers money, amounting to billions of pesos. In a few months, the rise of many five-star hotels changed the bay side landscape of Roxas Boulevard. These hotels and international venues needed theatrical performances with dance as major component. Meanwhile, tourism promotion in the provinces led to the development of streetdancing with touristic intentions (Apostolopoulos et al, 2013, 236-38).

Despite the pronouncements of economic growth and development under Martial law, the gap between the rich and the poor widened under the regime. Unemployment rose and the economy had a big deficit in the balance of payments. An oil crisis in 1973 worsened the internal problems of the country. This explosive situation that could escalate into social unrest had to be diffused. Overseas employment was the answer. Labor employment abroad was a policy of martial law under the 1974 Labor Code of the Philippines. It is not surprising that from 36,035 overseas contracts in 1975, the number of overseas Filipino contracts rose to 434,207 in 1983. Among these OFWs were the cultural dancers who worked as entertainers abroad. There is no doubt about the contribution of the overseas Filipino workers (OFWs) to save the ailing economy: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (Central Bank of the Philippines) statistics show that remittances rose from $103 million in 1975 to $944.45 million in 1983 (Asis 2006).

The gap between the rich and the poor widened as the top 12.9 percent of the population enjoyed 45.5 percent of the country’s total income. Marcos signed Presidential Decree 1177 in 1977 to ensure automatic payment of public debts. This was enforced to affirm the good standing of the New Society to foreign creditors. Thus, the dictatorship succeeded in increasing Philippine foreign debt from only $360 million in 1962 to $27 billion by the end of the regime. The decree guaranteed automatic debt service payment even for loans that did not benefit the people, such as borrowings used for the stalled Bataan Nuclear Power Plant and the suspended Chico River Dam (Almario 2011 and 2013).

One of the most dramatic struggles of the Filipino people in the 20th century was the Cordillera peoples’ opposition to a prominent development project funded by the World Bank. This was the Chico River Basin Hydroelectric Dam Project whose operation would submerge the ancestral lands of the Kalinga and the Bontoc. To consolidate themselves, the two ethnic groups formed the Kalinga-Bontoc Peace Pact Holders Association (KBPPHA) which propelled the anti-Chico Dam campaign. The KBPPHA grew and gained local and international support despite military efforts to suppress it. On 24 Apr 1980, government troops killed Macliing Dulag in Bugnay village, Tinglayan, Kalinga. Dulag, who was vocal about his opposition to the Chico Dam, was a respected leader of the Butbut group of the Kalinga. His assassination led to the groundswell of support for the anti-Chico Dam struggle from all over the country and from the international community. Dulag’s martyrdom led to the unity of many villages and groups against the Chico Dam. The triumphs of anti-Chico Dam movement was followed by the successful protest of the Tinguian against Cellophil Resources Corporation (CRC). The CRC was owned by Herminio Disini, a Marcos crony who was given jurisdiction in 1973 to operate a logging and paper-pulp company covering 200,000 has in Abra. These struggles of the Cordillera peoples led to a strong united opposition against the Marcos dictatorship under the Cordillera Peoples’ Alliance. The struggles of the Cordillera peoples were expressed through their indigenous dances (Bolinget 2004).

By the early 1980s, the surge of the people’s mass movements all over the country was already being felt despite the government’s effort to suppress people’s actions. The pressures on the regime from the international press and the worldwide human rights movement increased. The catalyst to the sociopolitical upheaval was the assassination of opposition leader Benigno Aquino Jr who returned to the Philippines after three years of exile in the US. Aquino was shot on the tarmac of the Manila International Airport immediately after he alighted from his airplane on 21 Aug 1983. His assassination further intensified the growing opposition against the Marcos dictatorship. These mass rallies and protest actions utilized theatrical performances using dance and creative body movements to educate and entertain the people. Even the apathetic sectors and members of the elite joined the surge of protests which led to the EDSA Revolt in February 1986.

Martial law lasted only about 14 years in the history of the Philippines but the period was very significant, especially in the realm of art and culture. Though this historical phase saw the continued development of western art forms which were primarily supported by the elite, it also witnessed the rise of divergent forces which developed various expressions that helped to overthrow of the Marcos dictatorship.

 

Ballet and Modern Dance

Centralization and control were the strategies of the authoritarian regime. The CCP itself echoed this policy by making the Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company, later called CCP Dance Company, its resident dance company in 1974. The CCP Dance Company was renamed as Ballet Philippines (BP) in 1981. Imelda Marcos was the patron and chair of BP whose success with local and international audiences presented a good image of martial law. However, ballet was not the First Lady’s “favorite” art form, giving BP relative autonomy in creating its own form and content. But to keep away from any conflict with the martial dispensation, BP productions remained safely “apolitical,” and as such, were supportive of the tenets of martial law (Tan 1999, 9-12).

Other dance companies no longer enjoyed support from the CCP. They survived by rehearsing and performing elsewhere. Ballet at the Park and Puerta Real Evenings were regular concerts under the sponsorship of Teodoro “Ka Doroy” Valencia, a journalist and Marcos ally who was also known as a philanthropist. The sponsored shows were meant to bring western classical dance forms like ballet to the masses. Dance Theater Philippines mounted works every month at Rizal Park from 1973 to 1986, and sustained two full seasons of original works by Eddie Elejar, Julie Borromeo, Tita Layag-Radaic, Basilio, Tony Fabella, and Gener Caringal at the Meralco Theater in early 1980s. The Hariraya Ballet Company, after losing venue and funding support from CCP, performed most often at Puerta Real, Intramuros until the early 1980s, and at the Manila Metropolitan Theater. The Manila Metropolis Ballet of Elejar and Fabella also filled the annual seasons at Puerta Real in Intramuros during the 1980s, and later of Festival Four at the CCP and Sayaw Sining (Dance Art) at the Metropolitan Theater. The lack of support from the CCP did not discourage these ballet companies. In fact, many ballet dancers were developed outside of CCP such as Maniya Barredo, Vella Damian, Jun Dalit, Teofilo Pila, Loulie Dalupan, Nini and Pinky Mendoza, Irene and Hazel Sabas, Emellie Rigonan, Sophia Radaic, Mary Anne Santamaria, Anna Villadolid, Lisa Macuja, Eloisa Enerio, Jonathan Terry, Roberto Clemente, Vivencio Samblaceño Jr, Myra and Ida Beltran, Shirley and Jeng Halili, Mila Ferrer, Rupert Acuña, and Ricardo Ella (Villaruz 2004).

Imelda Marcos was keen on getting world recognition through ballet. The CCP produced western classical ballets such asAct III of Sleeping Beauty, 1972; TheNutcracke r, 1976 and 1977; and The Firebird, 1979. In keeping with the regime’s strategy of inviting international artists to put the Philippines on the world art scene, the First Lady gave the International Artist Award in 1976 to Margot Fonteyne who was a celebrity guest artist along with Rudolf Nureyev. Many of CCP’s classical ballet productions featured world-acclaimed dancers like Natalia Makarova and Patrick Bissel in Giselle,1979;andYoko Morishita in Swan Lake,1979. The CCP also invited foreign choreographers like William Morgan who mounted Napoli Divertissements and The Sleeping Beauty in 1983. Other foreign artists who came to perform or to train at the CCP were Martha Graham Dance Company, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Norman Walker, Garth Welch, Muneca Aponte, Rex McClaneghan, Alfred Rodrigues, Gerard Sibbritt, Takako Asakawa, Jan Stripling, Kenneth Gillespie, Gray Veredon, and Diana Haight (Fernandez 1981, 181-82). Ballet thrived under the regime because it was supported and patronized by the audience from the upper classes of society who either supported martial law or were silent about their opposition to it.

An important ballet genre was the contemporary opera-ballet, as exemplified by Luis Layag’s The Survival of St Joan, 1973, with music by Smokerise and lyrics by James Lineberger. There was the impetus for original Filipino works in rock opera and ballets. These were typified by Julie and Rose Borromeo’s Mahal (Beloved), 1975, with music by Abel Labrador and Mon Faustmann; Alice Reyes’s Tales of the Manuvu,1977,with music by Nonong Pedero and the Afterbirth; and Rama,Hari (Rama, King), 1980, with music by Ryan Cayabyab. The librettos of the latter two rock operas were by Bienvenido Lumbera.

Ballet choreography expanded in interesting ways during this period. Inspirations came from literature, history, folk songs, pop music, folklore, local customs, and actual events. Kulas na Batugan (Lazy Kulas), 1973, choreographed by Joji Felix-Velarde to the music by Antonino Buenventura upholds the New Society’s Green Revolution and land reform program with a storyline about a lazy farmer who falls in love with a landlord’s daughter. There were the various interpretations of the storyline of Carmen by Eric Cruz, Eddie Elejar, and Alice Reyes in 1975, 1980, and 1984 respectively; and Lydia Madarang-Gaston’s Anak-Bulan (Moon Child), 1976. The promotion of Original Pilipino Music, an important development under the martial law regime, had an impact on dance as shown by Limang Dipa (Five Armstretches) by Tony Fabella with music by Ryan Cayabyab. The piece was a romantic and humorous choreographed program on Manila’s urban street life that brought together the folk and the pop in an eclectic style. Cora Generoso-Iñigo created Baile de Ayer (Dance of Yesteryears)based on a scene written by Rolando Tinio, with music by Rodolfo Cornejo. It is a tragic tale about exploitation and revenge involving a peasant girl taken by a rich man as payment for her father’s debts. Another work based on Philippine literature is Sisa, 1978, featuring the character from Rizal’s novel. Also by Generoso-Iñigo, its music was by Lucrecia Kasilag. A patriotic choreography was Basilio’s La Lampara (The Lamp), 1980, with music by Jerry Dadap that dramatized the concluding moments of Rizal before his execution using the lamp as a metaphor. Another literature-based work was Masks, 1981,by Eddie Elejar, inspired by Virginia Moreno’s poem about human relationships, with music by Ramon Santos. Yerma, 1982,was a modern dance choreographed by Anton Juan with music by Francisco Feliciano based on Federico Garcia Lorca’s three-act play (Fernandez 1981, 136, 145; Villaruz 1994; Villaruz 2005, 133).

Ballet with folkloric and historical themes, earlier pioneered by Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, also became a major genre in Philippine ballet during martial law. The creation of works towards “Filipino ballet” became an important consideration because ballet companies who toured outside the country realized that various audiences abroad clamor for original dances with Filipino themes and flavors. It became clear that finding ethnic or national identity in dance was important in the global context. Gener Caringal’s Ang Sultan (The Sultan), 1973, with music by Kasilag, was about the forbidden love between a Muslim royal lady and an ordinary man. Works inspired by history are typified by Alice Reyes’s RajahSulayman, 1975, about the Muslim leader of Manila who challenged Spanish rule, with music by Alfredo Buenaventura. Choreography based on epic heroes and mythical characters include Lam-ang,1974, by Generoso-Iñigo; Labaw Donggon,1985, by Caringal; and Mariang Makiling, 1979, by Effie Nañas. Basilio’s three-part Tropical Tapestry, 1983, featured “Paglalang” (Creation) about the myth of Malakas and Maganda.

A significant development in this period was the brief but remarkable life of the Ballet Federation of the Philippines in the mid-1970s. It organized the annual national ballet festival from 1976 to 1978 and produced several full-evening ballet classics and original Filipino works. It drew provincial groups to perform in Manila and toured the provinces with Coppelia and a divertissement repertoire (Villaruz 1997).

With the growing nationwide protests after the assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr on 21Aug 1983, works in ballet mirrored the signs of the times. Basilio’s Misa Filipina (Filipino Mass), 1984, portrayed the death of Ninoy Aquino using the elements of the Roman Catholic mass and the contemporary interpretation of Christ. It was performed at the Manila Cathedral with music by Ryan Cayabyab sung by the UP Concert Chorus. The song “Bayan Ko” (My Country) which was revived by Freddie Aguilar in the early 1980s became the anthem of nationalist and anti-Marcos protesters. It was interpreted by many dancers and performed in alternative venues (Fernandez 1981, 184; Villaruz 2005, 133-147, 259; Villaruz 1997; Villaruz 2015).

 

Folk and Indigenous Dances

Traditional dances continued to flourish in their places of origin among the indigenous peoples all over the archipelago. These dances were performed according to the needs of the community members in every phase of life from cradle to grave. Ritual dances were performed to drive away angered or malevolent spirits in order to protect the people from sickness. Courtship dances among men and women were endemic as forms of entertainment and socialization. Marriage ceremonies were filled with music playing and community dancing. Dances to entertain as well as teach the young about life skills such as fishing, planting rice, and gathering honey were part of the artistic expressions of the people. Those that mimic the movements of birds, monkeys, wild boar, or fish express the people’s affinity with nature. Such indigenous dances define the cultural identities of each ethnolinguisticgroup.

In the national capital region, folk dance groups that appropriated elements of indigenous performances in their folkloric choreography played an important role in the New Society’s cultural program, TheBayanihan Philippine Dance Company enjoyed the patronage of Imelda Marcos and basked in the position of being the premiere dance group of the totalitarian administration. The relationship between the Bayanihan and the First Lady harked back to the time when the young Imelda Romualdez vied for the title of Miss Manila in 1952 with the support of one of the founders of Bayanihan, Helena Benitez of the Philippine Women’s University. When Imelda Romualdez married Ferdinand Marcos and eventually became First Lady in 1965, the Bayanihan was already the most internationally-renowned dance group. Imelda Marcos saw the Bayanihan’s potential in boosting the image of martial law. It became the favored dance company given grander opportunities. Its leaders were appointed to official government positions: Bayanihan’s music director, Lucrecia Kasilag, assumed the position of CCP artistic director and FAT president. Bayanihan’s dance director, Lucrecia Urtula, was named FAT director. Its costume director, Isabel Santos, was also named FAT costume director. The group’s stylized, glossy, and spectacular folk dance performances suited the taste of the First Lady. Bayanihan was always the first to be tapped as official performers for dignitaries and guests in Malacañang or the CCP. Its shows were effective in promoting the government’s policies and programs. In 1973, the Ministry of Tourism sponsored Bayanihan performers to promote the Balikbayan (homecoming) program for Filipinos in America. Within the same year, the government sponsored the group in Italy, France, Greece, Switzerland, Germany, England, Spain, Scandinavia, Vienna, and Thailand. In the coming years, the Bayanihan represented the country in “cultural missions” and promoted the government in events such as folk dance festivals all over the world (Bayanihan 2003; Namiki 2007, 54-59, 60).

As FAT artistic director, Urtula revived the Philippine Folk Dance Society in 1975 and conducted the annual National Folk Dance Workshop first launched at the Philippine Normal College. Attended by hundreds of public school teachers and folk dance practitioners from all over the archipelago, the annual workshop was later conducted at the FAT in partnership with the CCP and the Department of Education, Culture and Sports. The Society undertook projects like the publication of folk dance researches and fieldwork to document folk dances (Arandez 1997).

Despite the centralization of power and resources on one folk dance company, Philippine folk dance still grew in other directions with the formation of new dance groups. One such organization was the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group (ROFG). The ROFG was born on the very day martial law was declared when the national emergency disrupted the job of Ramon Obusan as artistic director of the official dance group of the Bureau of Customs. On that fateful day, Obusan decided to seriously continue his aesthetic and intellectual pursuits in dance in his own house in Pasay City. The Bicol-born Obusan was a fisheries graduate of the University of the Philippines, Diliman who taught at the Aklan Polytechnic Institute after graduation. In Aklan, he had the opportunity to observe local customs and traditional practices. His propensity for anthropology led him to enrol at the UP Diliman under Dr Espiridion Arsenio Manuel. He then joined the Bayanihan as instrumentalist and dancer in the 1960s. However, Obusan disapproved of how the Bayanihan staged Philippine folk dances with its highly stylized movements with emphasis on glamorized images of dancers donned in glittery costumes. Soon, Obusan formed his own informal folk dance group so that he could mount dances gathered from his cultural researches, naming it Ramon Obusan Folkdance Group. Then he changed “folk dance” to “folkloric” in the late 1970s to signify the “authenticity” of the group’s performances.

Obusan started the ROFG at the right time. Imelda Marcos’s numerous cultural programs and tourism projects needed all the available dance groups to grace public events like diplomatic missions, international conferences, festivals, beauty contests, corporate activities, and opening ceremonies of institutions. Through these extensive exposures, Obusan’s relatively authentic approach to folk dancing became known. Soon, the difference between the styles of the Bayanihan and the ROFG became distinct. Since Imelda Marcos was ROFG’s patron, many opportunities unfolded for the dance group. By 1974, the ROFG performed in over 20 countries in Europe, Asia, and the Americas. The ROFG created its own niche in Philippine dance by using a more authentic look in its production design, by enlisting the participation of dancers from indigenous communities, and by staging dances with a more anthropological approach.

Obusan’s works under the Marcos regime demonstrated the influence of the First Lady on his concepts. The ROFG had its own version of Malakas at Maganda (The Strong and the Beautiful) and its own version of Kasaysayan ng Lahi titled Noon Po sa Amin (Yesterday in Our Town) which is a choreography on Philippine history from precolonial to contemporary era. Obusan was a down-to-earth leader who knew how to deal with people in power. His closeness with Imelda Marcos did not affect his position in the postmartial law era. In fact, after the downfall of Marcos, the ROFG was named official folkdance group of the CCP by the succeeding dispensation of Corazon Aquino (Ramon Obusan Folklorinc Group 2015; Namiki 2007, 54-59 ).

Meanwhile, the luxurious hotels that were built in key cities of the country, especially in Metro Manila, needed shows that offered cultural entertainment to attract tourists. Thus the late 1970s saw the spread of cultural shows in hotels, restaurants, and tourist sites all over the country. An example of a dance group involved in this type of cultural dancing is the Folklorico Filipino Dance Company established in the 1960s with dance suites influenced by the choreographies of the Bayanihan and the ROFG (Kultura Filipino 2012).

Folk dance groups that were formed in the earlier period continued to prosper, as exemplified by the Darangan Cultural Dance Group based in MSU, Marawi City in Lanao del Sur. In the Visayas, the Kaanyag Pilipinas Dance Company was reorganized from the West Negros College Dance Company in 1975. The company had performed outside of Negros Occidental at the Luce Auditorium in Silliman University, 1977 and 1979; the Portopia ‘81 Exposition in Kobe and a tour of Hyogo, Osaka and Port Islands, Japan, 1981; the Philippine Folk Festival at the Folk Arts Theater, 1981. Another group that expanded in the period was the Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company, directed by Teresita Pil. At the time, it was the only Philippine regional dance group which garnered international recognition by winning the silver medal at the International Folklore Festival in Dijon, France, in 1980. In the National Capital Region, school-based dance companies like the UP Filipiniana Dance Group, the University of the East Dance Troupe, and the UST Salinggawi Dance Troupe continued their folk dance training and performances. The Far Eastern University Dance Group also flourished at the time until it disbanded in 1983.

The declaration of martial law disallowed any form of public gathering even in the most remote areas of the country. The curtailment of the freedom of assembly aborted the premiere of a modern interpretation of Jose Rizal’s 1879 play, El Consejo de los Dioses (Council of the Gods) in Bongao, Tawi-Tawi. The cancelled dance-drama was directed and choreographed by Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa using pangalay movement vocabulary (Amilbangsa 2015).

Tawi-Tawi was part of the Sulu Archipelago which was once the Sulu Sultanate’s center of power. Historically, the Muslim Filipinos enjoyed a sovereign existence recognized by the colonizers under the sultanates of Sulu and Maguindanao. Two centuries before the Spanish colonization of the Philippines, “a vibrant and flourishing civilization” thrived in Mindanao and Sulu archipelago (Buendia 2006; Wadi quoted in Rimban 2015). The sultanates’ high level of civilization can be seen from the exquisite dances, music, rituals, arts, and crafts. These artistic expressions were documented by Fernando Amilbangsa who, in 1964, married Datu Punjungan Amilbangsa, a younger brother of Sultan Mohammad Amirul Ombra Amilbangsa of Sulu. A native of Marikina and a Christian, Fernando Amilbangsa embraced the local culture of the Samal, Sama Dilaut, Tausug, and Jama Mapun ethnic groups. She was lucky to have lived in Jolo before the carnage in Feb 1974 when the island capital was burned down by combined land, naval, and air forces. In the time of peace before 1972, she was able to witness dances in Jolo. She transferred to Tawi-Tawi two years before martial law, navigating the islands to witness obscure dances and rituals, and to conduct interviews among elders and local artists. In 1974, she founded the Tambuli Cultural Troupe (TCT) based in the Mindanao State University, Bongao in Tawi-Tawi. The TCT became the performance laboratory to test her primary researches on three dance forms: the martial art called langka, the song-dance called lunsay, and the dominant dance style called pangalay or igal. Variants of the pangalay were staged from field research, such as bula’bula and tariray (bamboo or shell clapper dances), tauti (occupational dance on catching catfish), pangalay ha agung (dance on top of a big gong), and igal ha pattung (dance on elevated twin bamboo poles). Fernando Amilbangsa also documented the ritual and shamanic dances such as the magjinn, magjuwata, magomboh, magsalba, and magpugot. These became part of the TCT repertoire brought to Manila in 1974 with performances in major institutions and universities such as the University of the Philippines, Diliman. In 1976, Fernando Amilbangsa mounted the group’s first major production at the CCP. Art critics, the media, and the diplomatic corps in Manila welcomed the unknown dances staged in appealing yet primordial manner, which was also a testament to the sophisticated culture of the ethnic groups whose art and culture were being annihilated by the ongoing war. In the context of martial law, the warm reception accorded to the TCT gave hope and pride to the peoples of the Southern Philippines.

Recognizing the dances of the South as a unique Filipino expression, Fernando Amilbangsa was invited by the Philippine Education Theater Association (PETA) starting in 1977 to teach pangalay to its members. In 1978, Fernando Amilbangsa joined the Mindanao State University in Iligan City as faculty member. Here, she was chair and cofounder of the Integrated Performing Arts Guild which also utilized pangalay and langka for its theatrical performances (Amilbangsa 1983, 13-52; Amilbangsa 2015).

Dance research and publications in the martial law period were mainly on folk and indigenous dances. Juan C. Miel published Samar Folk Dances, 1973. Jovita Sison-Friese produced Philippine Folk Dances from Pangasinan, 1980. Teresita Pascua-Ines came up with Ilocano Folk Dances, 1973. Obusan documented his researches using video, which helped in the staging of the dances for the ROFG. Fernando Amilbangsa published a comprehensive research on the dances of the Tausug, Samal, Sama Dilaut, and Jama Mapun of the Sulu Archipelago in her book Pangalay: Traditional Dances and Related Folk Artistic Expressions, 1983.

Dissent under martial law became more powerful and meaningful through dance. One concrete example happened in 1981 during a commemorative gathering in Bugnay, Kalinga in honor of the slain Kalinga leader, Macliing Dulag. The celebration was punctuated by music playing and community dancing. The gathering became a yearly event held in far-flung villages until it culminated in the launch of the first Cordillera Day on 24 Apr 1985 at Belwang Sadanga, Mt Province. The first Cordillera Day was a momentous event held a year before the downfall of Marcos. Representatives from various sectors and peoples organizations supporting the cause of the Cordillera peoples converged to celebrate the victories in the anti-Chico Dam and anti-Cellophil movements. On this occasion, various Cordillera dances were performed. One of these was the Kalinga dance called palook which is performed during thebodong(peace pact). In palook, men dance playing the gangsa or bronze gong as women execute specific footwork with extended arm positions, moving in various circular and linear formations, following the leader. After the fall of the Marcos regime in 1986, the second Cordillera Day was held in the town center of Bontoc to express the people’s victory in the overthrow of the dictatorship. Since the first Cordillera Day in 1981, the annual event has been an intertribal celebration with dancing, rituals, gong-playing, and chanting to express important political issues of the Cordillera peoples (Bolinget 2004).

 

Streetdance

Tourism utilized ethnic symbols and rituals as exotic attractions to lure tourists, resulting in the commercialization and hybridization of indigenous dances and rituals. A case in point is Bukidnon’s Kaamulan. To local communities, kaamulan means any gathering for a specific purpose like a wedding, a rice harvest, or a community prayer. Under the regime’s policy of creating events with high touristic value, kaamulan was chosen as a “municipal event” in 1974. The policy led to the revision of kaamulan’s original meaning and intention. It was transformed into Kaamulan Festival with spectacular elements like streetdancing competition choreographed by outsiders and danced by performers sponsored by politicians. Commissioned choreographers would usually add pageantry because they consider the ritualistic indigenous dances as monotonous and ineffective for theatrical purposes. Tourism thus developed and legitimized a new breed of choreographers who were not mindful of cultural traditions and were wont to invent dance steps and movements to augment or replace the traditional ones (Opeña 2007).

On a grander scale than Kaamulan is the Ati-atihan Festival celebrated every January as a devotion to the Santo Niño. The policy of promoting mass tourism after 1972 resulted in the transformation of the precolonial tradition into a weeklong event with highly theatricalized performances. Branded as the “Filipino Mardi Gras,” the festival culminates with a streetdancing contest where dancers are transformed using fantastic costumes and makeup (Peterson 2011). The pageantry that characterizes the martial law festivals extends to other festivities that venerate the Santo Niño such as the Sinulog and the Dinagyang. The commercialization and theatrical performance of ethnic rites for the sake of tourism is a legacy of martial law which has been adopted by succeeding administrations until the 2010s.

Revelry and pageantry had become the blueprint of local festivals, a practice that may suit other social purposes. In the early 1980s, the sugar industry under the monopoly control of Marcos cronies collapsed. Plantation owners were bankrupt. The sugar workers and their families were destitute and hungry. Then in another tragic turn, 700 Negrenses perished in the sinking of Don Juan passenger ship. It was a time of great despair. To dispel the depression that swept over Negros Occidental, the city officials of Bacolod along with local artists initiated a big fiesta which they called MassKara, after the English term for “many people” and the Spanish term for “face.” In an effort to lift their sinking spirits, some 450,000 people of the Bacolod danced and paraded in the streets garbed in colorful and outlandish attire, wearing masks with big smiles. Since then, the MassKara festival has been celebrated in October of every year (Lonely Planet 2012).

Despite the good image generated by tourism for the totalitarian rule, critics abroad continued to expose the human rights violations and corruption of the government through foreign media. To offset the bad publicity caused by the international press, the government launched thebalikbayan(homecoming) program. Taglines and messages were developed to promote the program. Tourism public relations managers thought of ways to lure Filipino expats to visit the country. Filipinos abroad were lured to come back during Christmas because the Philippines had the longest yuletide season. Local governments were instructed to develop spectacular festivals, and the balikbayan were given tax exemptions and big travel fare discounts. Majority of the balikbayan came from the US. Many were hungry for the local fiesta and the streetdancing which were the highlights of the touristic activities (Apostolopoulos et al 2013, 239-240).

 

Cultural Dance

The entertainment business is one of the opportunities for OFWs. Hundreds of thousands of Filipino entertainers, majority of them women, worked abroad either as singers or cultural dancers mostly in Japan, and in other Asian, Middle Eastern, and European countries. Their dancing included Philippine folk dances, jazzed up folk, Hawaiian, feathered follies, current popular dances, and novelty dances. Among these overseas workers were the “Japayuki,” a coined term with derisive connotations for the Filipina entertainer in Japan. The Asian country was the most common destination of cultural dancers, a trend that started in the late 1970s. This was a period of continued economic growth for Japan resulting in the demand for cultural dancers, vocalists, and hostesses in Japanese night clubs and hotels. Most of these exported performers had little training and experience in dance.

One of the legitimate recruiters who trained cultural dancers for overseas employment was Bella Dimayuga. She established the Bellestar Promotions, Inc to recruit young and pretty women wanting to become performing artists, providing training in her studio (ZoomInfo 2015). Dimayuga learned the essentials of the cultural dancing business in the 1960s. At the age of 16, she passed stringent measures to qualify as a cultural dancer in Las Vegas. She was among the dancers recruited to be part of the Philippine Dance Festival Company managed by Steve Parker, then the husband of Hollywood star, Shirley MacLaine. Having gained experience in dancing overseas, Dimayuga cofounded the Mabuhay Dance Troupe which offered cultural shows to several Asian countries with a repertoire on folk dances such as maglalatik, tinikling, and singkil. Thus, she gained valuable experience in the cultural dancing industry to become the “impresario” of local dancers who were deployed in overseas entertainment jobs that include performances in luxury cruise liners. She exported talents to the United States, Europe, and Asia. When Japan became a major destination for cultural performers, Dimayuga founded Bellestar Promotions to respond to the demand for entertainers in Japan. Dubbed as “Bellestar dancers,” her performers underwent months of training with a fixed curriculum of dancing and value formation aimed at preparing amateur talents to become migrant workers in Japan (UNTV 2014). These positive efforts did not offset the huge negative connotation of being a “Japayuki.” Notwithstanding the negative aspects of cultural dancing like vulnerability to sexual exploitation, the fact remains that the dollars brought in by these girls and women helped the Philippine economy.

 

Social Dance

Social dances were widely promoted through television. TV dancing was helpful in normalizing the situation under martial law. Dance shows and variety programs with a lot of dance segments were among the highly rated shows in the period. Penthouse Seven aired in 1974 on GMA Channel 7, first hosted by Archie Lacson with different female hosts. The show had an instructional segment that demonstrated the latest dance craze to TV audiences: pop dances such as the robot, the bump, the L.A. walk, the hustle, and the swing (Salterio 2008). The dance show became more popular when it was hosted by Martin Nievera and Pops Fernandez and re-launched as Penthouse... Live!, starting in 1982 at GMA Channel 7. An afternoon TV show dedicated to disco music and dance was Discorama, 1975, which aired over GMA Channel 7 hosted by Bobby Ledesma and Joey de Leon. The show was barely rating until De Leon invited his buddies Vic and Tito Sotto to co-host the show (PEP Forum 2015). The 1980s saw the popularity of variety shows hosted by dancing stars. Vilma Santos hosted and danced in VIP (Vilma in Person). Alma Moreno was dubbed as the “Tangga Queen” as she danced wearing the skimpy underwear in shows like The Other Side of Alma, Rated A and Loveli-Ness (Francisco 2009; Donato 2014). TV dancing was a lucrative profession. Dance companies dedicated to TV dancing were formed during the period such as Penthouse Seven Dancers, Maribeth Bichara and the VIP Dancers, Disco Fantasy, Vicor Dancers, and Hotlegs.

Social dancing with emphasis on disco became a craze with the influence of Original Pilipino Music (OPM). The latter gave birth to the Manila Sound music genre. The promotion of OPM through mass media was a policy of the Marcos government and is considered the light and happy side of the martial law era. Manila Sound produced music for social dancing, particularly for disco, swing, rock and roll, and Latin pop dances. Manila Sound defined the 1970s, typified by songs such as “Aawitin Mo, Isasayaw Ko” (Sing it and I will Dance It), “Magsayawan” (Let’s Dance), “Disco Fever,” and “Swing it, Baby” by VST and Company; “Manila, Manila,” “Bongga Ka ’Day” (You’re Fabulous, Girl), “Annie Batungbakal” by the Hotdog; “Ang Boyfriend Kong Baduy” by Cinderella; and “No Touch” by Juan de la Cruz band. Disco bars and clubs proliferated in the period. Top-billing the list was Ernest Santiago’s Coco Banana which was enshrined in the song “Annie Batungbakal” by the pop group Hotdog. Coco Banana was the dancing bar for intellectuals, bohemians, fashion enthusiasts, and socialites. Meanwhile, the building spree of luxury hotels at the time did not ignore the disco mania. Every decent hotel was expected to have a good disco club. Famous disco places in the 1970s were Stargazer in Silahis International Hotel, Where Else in Hotel Intercontinental, Isis in Hyatt Regency, Lost Horizon at the Philippine Plaze Hotel, and Another World at the Manila Garden Hotel (Samonte 2014; Sioson-San Juan 2007; Loyola Diaries 2010).

Hollywood dance movies hit Philippine cinema houses with high box-office returns, led by Saturday Night Fever, 1977. The movie fueled the disco craze even more with its introduction of the hustle performed in partner or line formations. Subsequent foreign dance films like Fame in 1980, Flashdance in 1983, and Footloose in 1984, further promoted disco dancing. Local film production flourished under martial law and ushered in the “second golden age of Philippine cinema” that engendered various film genres, among which were the movies inspired by OPM hits and disco. Vilma Santos had the most number of dance films starting with Let’s Do the Salsa opposite Walter Navarro and Rolly Quizon in 1976; Disco Fever with Christopher de Leon and Cocoy Laurel in 1978; Rock, Baby, Rock with Spanish actor-singer Junior and Rolly Quizon; and Swing It, Baby opposite Romeo Vasquez, both in 1979; and Good Morning, Sunshine also with Junior in 1980. Nora Aunor danced as the character Annie in Annie Batungbakal, 1979, with Lloyd Samartino. Rio Locsin, Lorna Tolentino, Junior, and Charo Santos were cast in Disco Madhouse, 1980. Majority of the dance scenes in the foregoing films were choreographed by Geleen Eugenio. Youth-oriented comedy films such as Pabling (Playboy) and Blue Jeans in 1981 were replete with dance sequences.The former showcased the dancing prowessof partners Maricel Soriano and William Martinez while the latter featured an elaborate dance scene with singing trio Apo Hiking Society and screen sweethearts Alfie Anido and Dina Bonnevie. In 1984, Bagets (Young Ones) showed a teenage Aga Muhlach dancing like Michael Jackson (Star for all Seasons Filmography 2015; IMDb Annie Batungbakal 1979; Balbuena 2010).

While Manila Sound entertained the masses, the 1980s also saw the spectacular influence of Michael Jackson (MJ) on Filipino audiences with his Thriller album and singles such as “Beat It” and “Billie Jean,” all released in 1982. These hits were accompanied by groundbreaking music videos that showcased the international idol’s popping moves and signature dance steps. MJ dance patterns became the craze: zombie moves, pelvic thrusts, crotch grabs, head and foot walks, heel grooves, and the classic MJ moonwalk. In 1982, singer-dancer Gary Valenciano rose to popularity with his own popping gestures derivative of MJ’s style. The popping style which developed from California in the 1960s influenced funk, break dancing, and hip-hop—genres that became popular in the country starting in the early 1980s (Goot 2015; Sony Music Entertainment 2015).

 

Dance in Theater

The historic Manila Hotel was expanded and renovated in the 1970s. Its luxurious Fiesta Pavillion which could accommodate over 2000 guests was the venue of grand musical revues about the city of Manila for three consecutive years. The big-budgeted productions featured song and dance sequences choreographed by Alice Reyes utilizing the cleverly designed costumes by Salvador Bernal that allowed instant transformations which amazed and delighted audiences. With Leo Rialp as the over-all director, the continuing theme on Manila was developed in three production concepts: Manila, Manila: As Time Goes By, 1977, scripted by Nestor Torre; Manila, Manila: Doon Po sa Amin (Manila, Manila: In Our Place), 1978, scripted by Nicanor Tiongson; and Manila, Manila: Ngayon at Kailanman (Manila, Manila: Now and Always), 1979, scripted by Jose Javier Reyes (Tiongson 2007, 257-59).

Imelda Marcos restored the Metropolitan Theater (Met) in 1978. The Met’s first offering was produced by Kabataang Baranggay titled Isang Munting Alamat about the evolution of the Filipino race with verse, music, and dance. Conchita Chuidian Sunico was the Met’s executive director from 1978 to 1986. Sunico was a pre-World War II beauty queen and a socialite tasked to build a mass-oriented Met. A seasoned producer of grand operas and musicals, Sunico revived thesarsuwelawith AngKiri (The Flirt) and Ang Palabas Bukas (The Show Tomorrow),both in1979. The new venue became the home base of the Metropolitan Dance Theater Company under Veda Bañes who staged the company’s first concert in 1982. Some of the succeeding productions were Tintinnabulation, 1983; TheGreat WhiteWay I and The Mikado,1983; Cats,1984; Aristocrats, 1985. Significant productions were original musicals like Batibot, 1979; Kapinangan, 1981; Gomburza, 1982; and Ewagan,1984. These were dazzling and expensive productions that did not make money, and were deemed by anti-Marcos protesters as frivolous and insensitive to the plight of the majority who were hungry and oppressed, particularly since the Met is located in the heart of Manila amid the hurry and flurry of ordinary people who neither had time nor money to watch shows which generally offered “extravaganzas” with dancers, stars, and a full orchestra. After the Aquino assassination, the Met was perceived by the critical majority as a symbol of decadence amid the political upheaval. It was ironic that while expensive productions were being shown at the Met, rallies were being launched across the street at the Liwasang Bonifacio—one of the favorite converging grounds of demonstrators during the anti-Marcos protest movement after the 1983 Aquino assassination (Magno 2015; Quintos 2012; Philstar 2008).

Theater groups that were critical of martial law had toveil their dissent using historical characters, biblical stories, folklore, and allegory. Nationalistic theater organizations like the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) used theater and dance as an instrument of counterculture against martial law. Before martial law, the company produced plays critical of the Marcos administration, as exemplified by Ai’dao, 1972, about Muslim Filipino characters who chose to rebel after experiencing terrible injustice. When PETA’s founder, Cecile Guidote, left the country to elude arrest, PETA continued its mission to use theater to educate and to raise social awareness about the ills of society. However, due to the surveillance of military intelligence on groups and organizations, PETA had to conceal its critical messages. From 1973 to 1977, PETA employed dance, movement, and martial arts in the staging of its political plays.

The group’s basic training on creative body movement was based on Rudolf Laban’s Eight Basic Efforts. Additionally, PETA developed its own pool of martial artists who learned basic martial arts like kung fu, karate, and kuntaw. PETA’s pool of martial artists included Emman Lacaba, Edipolo Erosido, Katsch Catoy, Laura Catoy, Robert Montalban, Jojo Purisima, Greg Sta. Inez, Jack Yabut, George and Robert Atutubo. Cirilo Bawer introduced Kalinga dance movements and used these in Bodong, 1976. The members of Sining Kambayoka from MSU-Marawi also shared their knowledge on Maranao dances and martial arts. Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa held pangalay dance workshops from 1977 to 1979, and thus infused the aesthetics of Philippine traditional dance in PETA plays. Pangalay postures and gestures became “a major stream of dance theater language.” Fernando Amilbangsa introduced the dance form as the choreographic tool for productions like Ang Hatol ng Guhit na Bilog, 1977, an adaptation of The Caucasian Chalk Circle .The pangalay training prepared PETA artists for the mounting of historical dance dramas like Rajah Sulayman and Megat Salamat, 1978, and the major production, May-i, May-i, 1979, about Manila under the reign of Muslim leader Raha Sulayman from a scenario written by Emman Lacaba.

Meanwhile, PETA’s youth arm known as the Metropolitan Teen Theater League (MTTL), was adept in using allegory and history in productions that were highly critical of martial law. MTTL members utilized song, dance, improvisation, and creative movements to create original plays critical of the regime and of society’s basic ills. These plays were generally episodic and stylized, coming from the modes of expressionism and epic theater that used character types to represent sectors and classes in society. Kasi Babae Raw (Because She's a Woman),1975, exposed the commercialization and oppression of women; Juanang Tamad (Lazy Juana),1976, criticized militarization in the school campus; and Kuwentuhan Tatlo: Maria Makiling, Ibaloy, Busol (Three Stories: Maria Makiling, Ibaloy, Busol) used folktales and legends to oppose authoritarian rule. In 1978, MTTL produced Salaming Nahihibang at ang Epiko ng Punong Sinilya (Mad Mirror and the Epic of the Chaired Leader) and Sampung mga Daliri (Ten Fingers).The former was critical of how the government concealed Manila’s poor population while spending billions on the construction of hotels and condominiums. The latter portrayed the historical role of the youth in spearheading change and toppling a repressive order.

Mime was introduced earlier to PETA by Rolf Scharre in 1970, followed by Jojo Purisima in 1980. Purisima’s training produced Mima, Maskara, at Drama (Mime, Mask, and Drama) in 1981. Folk dance, jazz, modern dance, and ballet were used in PETA plays. Modern dance influence mainly came from the CCP modern dance training workshops under Alice Reyes. The dancers and movers trained in the foregoing dance forms include Mary Joan Fajardo, Maribel Legarda, Jojo Atienza, Connie Lauigan, Ditchay Roxas, Apo Chua, Mimi Villareal, and Gamay Arkoncel. Maribel Legarda emerged as a choreographer for productions using an eclectic mix of dance forms frombodabiland Hispanic, folk, and contemporary dance forms. Such eclecticism was characteristic of Canuplin, 1980; Pilipinas Circa 1907 (Philippines Circa 1907),1982; Nukleyar Iand II (Nuclear I and II), 1983/1985; and Oratoryo ng Bayan (The People’s Oratorio), 1983 (Samson et al 2008, 3, 47, 74, 90, 156-58, 189, 662-65).

PETA’s training arm, the Center for Integrated Theater Arts in Southeast Asia (CITASA), was instrumental in organizing theater groups in communities that exposed and opposed the military rule starting in 1976. Its outreach workshops were sponsored by the progressive Church sector in the provinces. The church-based performing groups used creative drama, music, and dance to create presentations aimed at raising awareness among the masses. For instance, PETA-CITASA’s training in Negros was supported by the diocese through the initiative of Fr Alan Abadesco who spearheaded the formation of Teatro Pangkatilingban (Community Theater). Fr Abadesco later cofounded the Negros Theater Guild.

In Mindanao, “theater of liberation” materialized as early as 1969 through the efforts of Fr Dong Galenzoga in Lanao del Norte and Karl Gaspar in Davao del Sur. Both used dance theater to organize Basic Christian Communities. In particular, Galenzoga formed a group called The Kolambugan Dance Theater based in Kolambugan town. The group drew its members from a mixed community of Christians and Muslims. It utilized Maranao folklore in their storytelling through dance drama. The group was invited to perform in various places in Visayas and Luzon in 1974-75 (Van Erven 1992, 76, 80-81).

By the 1980s, especially after the Aquino assassination in 1983, theater groups became more overt and daring in their anti-dictatorship messages.UP Peryante was a street theater group which performed in tandem with a singing group called Patatag. Composed of students and young cultural activists, they popularized the “song-and-movement” street performance called kilos-awit. This form of creative protest action became popular during the street rallies after the 1983 Aquino assassination. Peryante and Patatag performed kilos-awit during the yellow confetti rallies held at the business district of Makati. It was also a favorite number in the more militant mobilizations at the steps of the national Post Office in Liwasang Bonifacio, or at Mendiola near Malacañan. The kilos-awit was performed to boost the morale of striking workers in picket lines, or to add color to long people’s marches such as the Lakbayan organized against the Bataan nuclear power plant. It was a defiant form of protest and was part of mass rallies that were illegal at the time, unless protesters apply for a permit—which was almost always denied. The requirement for a permit did not stop protesters from holding rallies. Personalities like Sen Lorenzo Tanada, human rights lawyer Rene Saguisag, socialite Tingting Cojuangco, businessman Butz Aquino (brother of Ninoy Aquino), and publisher Chino Roces were in the frontlines of demonstrations to negotiate with riot police armed with phalanxes, truncheons, guns, and water cannons. In such moments of high tension, the kilos-awit performances diffused anxiety (Quimpo 2012, 354-62).

In 1979, a group of concerned artists called Tambisan sa Sining (Interaction in Arts) embarked on a mission to support workers on strike by serenading to raise funds. They also organized factory and service workers into cultural groups. Tambisan conducted training in music and theater, using body movement and gestures to amplify the meanings of cause-oriented songs. In 1982, the group mounted Awit, Tula, at Kasaysayan (Songs, Poems, and History) which was shown nationwide in factories, communities, and trade union meetings, as well as in key cities in Japan. Performers interpreted a wide selection of songs ranging from lively songs of the Beatles to the proletarian anthem known as “Internasyunal,” choreographed with the waving of red banners and flag of the Communist Party of the Philippines. In the same year, Tambisan produced Sigaw ng Bayan (Cry of the People) with an audience of 25,000 at the Araneta Coliseum. The performance utilized dance and body movements to dramatize the history of the Katipunan and the 1896 revolution. Other productions were Alay sa Manggagawa (An Offering to Workers), 1982, and Kara y Krusat Iba pang Kuwento (Heads and Crosses, and other Stories) that explained the need to boycott the 1984 presidential elections.

The anti-dictatorship movement was a rainbow coalition of political forces ranging from radical to reformist groups. The broad alliance emboldened artists who mounted performances which openly militated against the regime. The Concerned Artists of the Philippines, PETA, and other artists’ organizations joined hands to convene MAKIISA, the First National Theater and People’s Festival on Theater and Culture in December 1983 held at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago, Intramuros, Manila. MAKIISA aimed to consolidate the various initiatives of artists and cultural groups against the repressive regime. It also sought to promote and broaden “the cause for a nationalist and mass-oriented Philippine arts and culture.” The five-day festival held workshops on various arts that include music, mime, and traditional dances. Tropang Bodabil’s DalawangAnino sa Liwanag (Two Shadows in the Light)portrayed how a young revolutionary was held and liquidated by the military. Also in the bodabil tradition was the Negros Theater League’s Sakada (Seasonal Sugarcane Plantation Workers), which offered hilarious improvisations that depict the day-to-day struggles of sugar workers. Sakada ’s finale was a choreography in mime showing how a militant organizer decides to join the armed struggle. In Makiisa II, 1984, the Sining Malay Ensemble presented Lemlunay, an eclectic play that depicted the struggles of a Tboli community against incursion of lowlanders and big logging companies (Van Erven 1992, 77-8, 84-5).

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt, Philippine economy and politics remained highly vulnerable as institutional changes were in progress and political forces were realigning. Under the new administration, the Metropolitan Theater produced a musical titled EDSA .Cash-strapped by the end of the Marcos regime, the Met raised funds by serving as a venue for TV dance variety shows like Vilma! hosted by film star Vilma Santos which premiered over GMA network in 1986. Meanwhile, the CCP opened its doors to groups that were anathema to its elitist programs under the previous regime. With a new leadership, the CCP gave space to militant presentations such as Tambisan’s Mayo Uno ng Ating Paglaya (May Firstof Our Freedom) which was performed to an audience of workers (Tambisan sa Sining 2015). PETA’s Panata sa Kalayaan (Oath to Freedom), a product of MAKIISA, was also staged at the CCP Main Theater to celebrate the victories of the 1986 EDSA Revolt. Panata summarized two decades of cultural work to topple the totalitarian regime (Samson et al 2008, 3, 47, 74, 90, 156-58, 189, 266-69). However, the euphoria from the victory of EDSA Revolt dwindled just months after February, especially in the rural areas where the new dispensation barely made an impact on the lives of the masses. By September 1986, the Negros Theater League produced an original play titled Negros After February ’86, which portrayed how militarization and poverty still continued after the EDSA Revolt (Magno 2015; Quintos 2012; Philstar 2008; Van Erven 1992, 79).

 

Conclusion

The martial law era was a momentous historical period that engendered the development of Philippine dance. The polarized forces in Philippine society became the catalysts for the growth of existing and new dance forms; and the development of dancers, choreographers, researchers, and dance organizations all over the country. In retrospect, the short span of 14 years under dictatorial rule produced a rich harvest of new works and dance forms that were superior in form and/or content. Ironically, the dark and repressive years deepened awareness of how Philippine dance forms could be used to express ideas about socio-economic and political conditions. Martial law sharpened the need to reassess Philippine history, to rediscover traditional culture, and to redefine nationalism and the Filipino identity. Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

Ballet
Modern Dance
Contemporary Dance
Indigenous Dances
Social Dances
Hip-hop, Cheerdance, and Flash Mob Dance
Epilogue

Introduction

On 25 Feb 1986, PresFerdinand Marcos, with his wife Imelda, his children, and his cronies, boarded in haste a US Air Force plane en route to Hawaii. He was fleeing, driven to exile by a people’s uprising against his 21 years of authoritarian rule that saw the suppression of civil liberties, the torture and killing of thousands of political activists, and massive corruption that pushed the country further into debt. The 1983 assassination of Sen Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino and the subsequent 1986 EDSA Revolt paved the way for a new administration that was infused with new hope and faith in the restoration of freedoms in the country. After the EDSA Revolt, the concept “democratic space” became popular in the Philippines and was associated with the freedoms the new government by Corazon Aquino vowed to restore (Javate de Dios, Daroy, Kalaw-Tirol 1988, 234).

This sense of accommodation by the new national order was also felt in the cultural scene. In 1987, Ma. Teresa “Bing” Roxas, Nicanor Tiongson, and Florendo Garcia began the change in the orientation of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), a major institution that was associated with the deposed First Lady of the Philippines, Imelda Marcos. Five essential thrusts were introduced: Filipinization, which aimed to produce “original Filipino works rooted in the country’s traditions” (Tiongson 2009, 31-33); democratization, which opened CCP venues to more dance companies and audiences; decentralization, which encouraged the participation of the regions in the creation of a national culture; the promotion of artistic excellence, which recognized the pluralism of aesthetic excellence; and reorientation of international exchanges which emphasized the participation of Filipino artists in international events. These five thrusts would guide the productions and programs of the institution in the years to come. CCP’s new leadership created and implemented programs in consultation with stakeholders outside the institution—artists, dancers, musicians, film artists, cultural workers, and members of academe and media.

 

 

In the performing arts, CCP increased the number of its resident companies to include the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group (ROFG), and the University of Santo Tomas Symphony Orchestra, in addition to the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, the Ballet Philippines (BP), and the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra. CCP launched workshops, productions, events, and awards contributing to the envisioned “national culture evolving with and for all Filipinos” (Tiongson 2009, 31-33). Priority was given to the development of Filipino artists and their works, resulting in productions such as Dating Gawi, Bagong Anyo (Old Ways, New Image) by Douglas Nierras and Unang Hakbang (First Step) by the Chameleon Dance Company, both in 1991. CCP opened its doors to competent dance companies outside its network through venue grants and the Pang-alay (Offering)series. In dance, BP II launched dance workshops outside Metro Manila such as Davao and Iligan. To develop new linkages on the national and local level among dancers, choreographers, enthusiasts, and scholars, CCP hosted the first CCP National Dance Festival and Conference in Iloilo City in 1989. On the international level, CCP organized the first International Dance Conference and Festival of Dance Academies in 1991.

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt, and in response to the proposal made by the Alliance of Artists for a Ministry of Culture (AAMC), Pres Aquino established the Philippine Commission for Cultural Arts (PCCA) in 1987, encompassing “the arts, cultural heritage, and cultural dissemination.” The PCCA became the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) in 1992 (Tiongson 2009, 30). In dance, the NCCA gave subsidies to four dance companies: BP, PBT, Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, and the ROFG. It also provided grants to the priority projects of the National Committee on Dance (NCD). Over the years the NCD has extended financial support to arts councils, foundations, local government units, public schools, community-based performing groups/organizations, schools of dance/companies, dancers, choreographers, trainers, and teachers. Some of the NCD’s grants are the Resource Material Development in Dance grant, Dance Production/Collaboration grant, Dance Competition grant, and the NCCA Dance Season grant, all of which allow grantees to research, perform, compete, and to create and produce dance works or shows.

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt, cultural changes were significant not just in institutions tasked to minister to Philippine culture but also in the country’s general cultural landscape. The turn of the 21st century was marked not just by the visibility of artists working outside major establishments but also by the pronounced presence of popular culture on a global scale. New technologies paved the way for the circulation of literature, music, dance, performances, and all kinds of art forms beyond national borders. There was definitely a new energy felt in the realm of cultural production. The end of the Marcos era did not automatically result in the vigorous production of dance in the country. Although there was more freedom to explore the possibilities of dance, support for this ephemeral form was still an issue. Still, as an art that draws its form and energy from the human body, dance found novel ways of expressing itself.

 

Ballet

The state of Philippine art changed as the political atmosphere in the country shifted from a dictatorship to a new democracy.

Various dance groups outside the CCP demanded equal subsidy for their companies. These were the independent ballet/dance companies composed of Dance Theater Philippines, Hariraya Ballet Company, Dance Concert Company, Manila Metropolis Ballet Company, Dance Arts Philippines, and the Gener Caringal Dance Repertory Company; and two schools, namely, the Ben-Lor Academy and the Academie of Performing Arts. They petitioned for their inclusion in the national center, the right to use its performance and rehearsal venues, and for stable and regular financial support. But the CCP could only subsidize one ballet company. Therefore, the aforementioned groups banded together to form the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT).

The subsidy given to the PBT was partial and it was understood that the company would also look for other resources. The company was granted the use of performance venues for its season performances. It had a glorious premiere performance and rose to the standard set by BP. Soon, two ballet companies held regular performance seasons at the CCP: BP known for its experimentation in modern dance, and PBT, for its preservation of classical ballet forms. Both companies aimed to preserve a distinctly Filipino identity in their repertoire, despite arguments that ballet and modern dance were foreign to our culture. The CCP’s Coordinating Center for Dance, headed by former BP dancer Nestor Jardin, was tasked to coordinate the four resident companies of the CCP—BP, PBT, ROFG, the Bayanihan Philippine Folk Dance Company—and other groups, schools, and artists in the country. There were programs for dance education and performance. The former included workshops from visiting foreign dance groups and choreographers; outreach workshops conducted by local teachers in the provinces and rural areas; and the annual folk dance workshop. Performance programs included the Dance Venue Grant, which was awarded to individual choreographers and artists to enable them to present concerts at the CCP and the hosting of local and international dance festivals.

 

 

It was in this spirit of democracy that the annual Balletfest festival was launched in 1987. It gathered over 20 dance companies and schools from all over the country. Both BP and PBT, as well as the six independent companies and two schools that comprised PBT, participated in the annual festival. It nurtured ballet schools by providing opportunities for them to showcase their students and encouraged a friendly competition among schools resulting in the improvement of dance training and the quality of dances.

When Lisa Macuja returned to the Philippines as an artist-in-residence with the CCP in 1986, she danced in the classical productions of BP. Winning the silver medal at the 1987 Asia Pacific Ballet Competition in Tokyo, Macuja was immediately rankedprima ballerinaof the new PBT, holding this high position by herself for several years and dancing all the principal roles in PBT productions during her entire stay. She subsequently formed her own company, Ballet Manila (BM), produced full-length classical ballets in the Russian tradition, and successfully presented these to more people than any company had ever done in Philippine ballet history. Macuja also regularly invited her former St Petersburg mentors, People’s Artist of Russia Sergei Vilulov and his wife Tatiana Udalenkova, and guest ballet master Viktor Saveliev of Moscow (Villaruz 2012, 64), to administer master classes in the Vaganova method for her company. With former PBT artistic council member Eric Cruz as coartistic director, Macuja established BM as a touring company, with performances in the Philippines and later in Russia and the US.

Macuja’s “Ballet for the People” fulfilled BM’s mission to perform the classics before an audience of Filipino masses, not the regular ballet attendees. Soon, the company took residence in the Aliw and Star Theaters built right beside the CCP, as adjunct cultural theaters of the Manila Broadcasting Company and the year-round carnival, Star City.

The three big ballet companies coexisted, alongside another smaller performing group, BP II, established in 1990 under the helm of Agnes Locsin. It was a junior company separate from BP, to further train the apprentices and scholars for performance and to develop new choreographies and revive pieces that were no longer being performed. The apprentices and scholars trained more intensively in the modern form even if they still performed one or two full-length ballets each season. With CCP’s grants for residency programs, BP II and Locsin conducted workshops in Davao and Iligan in 1991 (Tiongson 2009, 33).

BP was known for its innovative “neo-ethnic” modern pieces, PBT for its classical and contemporary repertoire, and BM for its strictly classical ballet repertoire. All three companies, however, prematurely lost their principal dancers due to foreign job opportunities. A phenomenon that affected the dance companies was the recruitment of dancers for Hong Kong Disneyland. Disney might have given lucrative jobs to Filipino musicians, theater actors, and dancers, but in the first half of the 21stcentury, it also took a few dancers from BM and half the male soloists of PBT. In 2005, BP lost most of its soloists.

Competition from more popular forms of entertainment in Manila forced the marketing arms of the ballet companies to continue their reliable promotional scheme: they resorted to selling the classical ballets to schools. Aside from this strategy, BM produced Ballet and Ballads, which featured the company dancing with pop divas, such as Lani Misalucha, and this became a regular series very much like a TV variety show. Because the Aliw and Star Theaters are situated in the Star City compound, the ballets would find their way to the amusement park as an added attraction. BM bundled the ballet tickets with tickets for amusement park rides and other freebies, and with the Circus D’ Ballet. The circus as well as the different marketing gimmicks featured by the tie-up with Star City did promote the company to a bigger audience.

The company mounted several mixed-bill productions including the series titled The World Stars of Ballet, the most noteworthy of which was Stars of Philippine Ballet, 2013, which featured a homecoming of Filipino dancers abroad. More choreographers such as former BP artistic directors Max Luna III and Augustus Damian were invited to create works for BM from 2009 to 2013. Hazel Sabas was also commissioned to do a full-length ballet,Sinderela , 2012, the modern day Filipino version of the popular fairy tale character.

BP also found new ways to market its productions and make ballet appealing to a more general audience. Denisa Reyes’s coup was Darna, 2003, featuring the beloved Pinoy female superhero. Playing Maestro Ryan, 2005, showcased familiar and favorite pieces by popular composer Ryan Cayabyab. In the succeeding years, BP mounted works characterized by a wider range of aesthetics.

While heavily involved with the Contemporary Dance Network Philippines (later renamed to Contemporary Dance Network Manila), BP invited Paul Morales to lead the company as artistic director in 2008. With the revival of BP II in 2009, there were more choreographic opportunities for the younger members and aspirants of the company. While including contemporary dance processes and aesthetics in the repertoire and practice of the company, Morales also resurrected forgotten gems from BP’s over 40-year-old repertoire.

Younger members of BP created distinct works such as Rey-sing byCarissa Adea,Two of You byEa Torrado,and You, Me, Us by Ronelson Yadao, all in2009.In the same year, BP launched the BP Choreographers Cup ,a dance competition on neo-classical choreography. Among the choreographers invited by the company was Hong Kong-based Carlo Pacis who created the memorable Shifting Wait, 2010. Contemporary dance choreographers such as Elena Laniog and Ava Maureen Villanueva also mounted works for BP. Morales created Crisostomo Ibarra, 2010, Rock Supremo, 2013, and Manhid (Numb), 2014.

From 2001 to 2003, PBT staged more mixed-bill productions with dazzling showcase pieces such as the Great Classics and Tribute to Maestro Lucio San Pedro, both in 2001, Curtain Call, 2002,and Serenade and Other Ballets 2002 to 2003. The idea behind this was that shorter programs full of bravura dancing might excite audiences more than full-length ballets would. After 2003, PBT again mounted the full-length ballets it was known for, some of which were Tom Pazik’s Romeo and Juliet, The Hunchback of Notre Dame and La Bayadere .Past favorites were revised: Pazik’s Scherzo and Tzigane, Balanchine’s Serenade,and Campos-Cantero’s Carmina Burana. In 2004, Carmina Burana accompanied a short full-length ballet, titled Isang Bagong Bituin (A New Star), patterned after telenovelas that became popular in recent years. Gener Caringal choreographed to Willy Cruz’s pop songs, including Pangarap na Bituin (A Dream Star), Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle) and Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (Wishing It Would Never End). While some thought the use of Pinoy pop songs was abakya(cheap) concept, its performance at the CCP Main Theater lent an air of class to the music that was so enjoyed by lovers of karaoke.

Meanwhile, when each group performed in both local and international tours, their repertoire was generally Filipino. BP constantly performed Damian’s pieces from the Cayabyab suite. PBT’s regular tour and outreach show repertoire included Caringal’s Vinta and Fabella’s Beautiful Girls ,Marcha at Sayaw (March and Dance) or Fiesta (Festival), and the short version of Kundiman: Noon at Ngayon (Kundiman: Yesterday and Today). BM staged full lengths and circus acts in the theater, but on tour, they regularly performed Agnes Locsin’s Arachnida and Aguila (Eagle),Jojo Lucila’s Sari’t Bahag (Tubular Skirt and G-String) and Fabella’s Dalagang Filipina (Filipina Maiden).
