The years after martial law proved to be challenging for Philippine ballet which found itself looking for artistic and financial stability. Political changes also meant realignments in cultural priorities and ballet was not exempted from these vicissitudes. But the spirit of democracy encouraged more explorations in ballet which had generally been considered “classical” and for the middle class and the elite.

Apart from the three major dance companies, ballet schools and performing groups thrived. In 1993, the Association of Ballet Academies, Philippines (ABAP) was organized and then formally launched the following year. With founding members Vella Damian, Shirley Halili-Cruz, Ida Beltran-Lucila, Nina Anonas, Liza de la Fuente, Amelia Yulo, Nida Onglengco-Pangan, Araceli Root, Cherry Velarde-Mactal and honorary members/advisers Leonor Orosa Goquingco, Corazon Iñigo, and Esteban Villaruz, the organization, together with its affiliate members has worked to improve classical ballet education in the Philippines by holding workshops, performances, and tours. It was one of the important federation of dance companies in the Philippines (Beltran 2015) and has had around thirty members using a range of ballet syllabi, some of which were the Ballet Syllabus of the Commonwealth Society of Teachers of Dancing (CSTD) based in Singapore and Australia, the American Academy of Ballet Syllabus based in New York, the Philippine National Ballet Syllabus, the Cecchetti Ballet Syllabus, National Dance Syllabus, the Royal Academy of Dance Syllabus, the Australian Conservatoire of Ballet Syllabus, and the Vaganova method.

Over the past 30 years, many schools have emerged not just in the Metropolis but also in the regions. Schools in Metro Manila are Vella Damian’s Vella C. Damian School of Classical Ballet, Shirley Halili’s Halili-Cruz School of Ballet (HCSB), Liza de la Fuente-Castañeda’s Ridgepointe Ballet Center for Dance Education, Ianne Damian and Melanie Motus’s IDMM Ballet School, all in Quezon City; Araceli Valera Root’s Pink Toes in Antipolo City; Ana Emata’s Ana Emata School of Classical Ballet in Marikina; Amelia Garcia Yulo’s Ballet Repertory Philippines in San Juan; Effie Nañas’s Effie Nañas School of Dance in Mandaluyong; Desiree Peralejo-Medina’s DBC-ISAS Conservatory in Pasig; Sofia Zobel-Elizalde’s Steps Dance Studio, Maritoni Rufino-Tordesillas’s Danspace, Brezhnev Larlar and Pamela Ortiz-Bondoc’s Dance Theater Arts, and Perry Sevidal’s Perry Sevidal Ballet, all in Makati; Toni Lopez-Gonzalez’s Toni Lopez-Gonzalez School of Ballet in Ortigas; Noemi Onglengco Silangcruz’s Ballet and Arts Center in Taguig; Nida Onglengco-Pangan’s Ballet Dance Academy in Cavite; Marlinda Claravall’s Claravall School of Dance and Cherish Garcia’s Academi One, both in Parañaque; and Eli Jacinto’s Theatrical Ensemble and Artistic Movement (TEAM) and its sister school Hampton Court Ballet, both in Las Piñas.

Many schools offering classical ballet outside the Metro have become more visible. There is Ava Villanueva’s studio in Los Baños; Jackie and Joanne Go’s Le Conservatoire de Danse de Ballet in Baguio City; Sol Fernandez’s SF School of Dance, Nila Claravall-Gonzales’s Claravall-Gonzales School of Classical Ballet, and Annie Divinagracia Sartorio’s School of Performing Arts in Iloilo; Jeanette Garcia Sanchez’s Garcia-Sanchez School of Dance and Lydia M. Gaston School of Dance under its current artistic director Aliana “Cheenee” Alicia Rose Marie Limuaco, both in Bacolod; Fe Sala-Villarica’s BalletCenter, now run by Nicolas Pacaña and Gregory Aaron in Cebu; Faith Javellana’s School for Theater Art ‘N’ Dance in Cagayan de Oro City (formerly the Faith Dance& Art Center in Iloilo City); and Girlie Royeca’s Ballet and Performing Arts School and Agnes Locsin’s Locsin Dance Workshop, both in Davao City.

These schools all over the Philippines contribute to the still-growing professional practice of ballet, aided by competitions such as the ABAP Dance Cup, and the junior and senior ballet categories at the National Music Competition for Young Artists, which ran until 2013. It was replaced in 2014 by the National Ballet Competition hosted by the CCP.

The post-EDSA period was characterized by the ubiquity of popular culture and various forms of amusement spurred by developments in technology. Yet, although ballet had always been associated with elite culture and dance performances were deemed unappealing to the millennial youth, this genre not only survived but also managed to reinvent itself in various ways. Because there was no lack of exceptional talent and kinesthetic intelligence, ballet in the years after EDSA reworked itself and found specific niches where it could further grow.

 

Modern Dance

The warm reception to modern dance in the Philippines when it was introduced by famous choreographers such as Ruth St Denis and Ted Shawn in 1926 and Viennese Kaethe Hauser and Trudl Dubsky-Zipper in the 1930s was sustained by Filipino dancers and choreographers in the succeeding years. Former student of Hauser, Spanish modern dancer Manolo Rosado returned to Manila in 1958 after studying in the US with Shawn, Martha Graham, and Jose Limon. Also inspired by her mentors Hauser and Dubsky-Zipper, Rosalia Merino-Santos took an MA in modern dance in the US in the late 1960s and eventually returned to the Philippines and directed the FEU Modern Experimental Dance Troupe. Teachers who promoted modern dance in the country were Corazon Generoso (later, Iñigo) who also trained under Dubsky-Zipper, and Carmen Adevoso who for a brief period, taught modern dance in public schools before leaving for the US.

In 1970, Alice Reyes’s Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company at the CCP further strengthened the presence of modern dance in the Philippines. But even before this, Luis Layag already explored new ventures in dance which he pursued into the 1970s. Basilio earlier attempted the same at the Central Philippine University in Iloilo from 1964 to 1965. Basilio continued creating works using the vocabulary of modern dance all the way to his later works in the 1980s. Tony Fabella likewise contributed to the growth of modern dance from the 1970s to the 1980s as manager and resident choreographer of the Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company.

The history of modern dance in the country, however, shows how most Filipino choreographers do not strictly conform to rigid dance forms. Their works may cross over from one genre to another as they use technical and stylistic resources of their training background. Yet, although the post-EDSA Revolt period witnessed such cross-overs, there are works that may be considered more distinctly modern dance. The period saw a surge of creations integrating indigenous movements into modern dance pieces. One of the most controversial pieces perhaps was Agnes Locsin’s Igorot, 1987, which had the top half of the dancers’ bodies emulating Igorot dancing movement and gestures, while the lower half performing ballet steps, slightly reoriented in opposition to classical ballet impulses and accents.

When Locsin choreographed Igorot ,the CCP and BP were already 18 years in the dance scene. BP had by then amassed several modern pieces with Philippine themes in its repertoire, the most popular being Alice Reyes’s Amada,1970,Gener Caringal’s Ang Sultan (The Sultan), 1973, and Denisa Reyes’s For the Gods ,1985.Amada,which was based on Nick Joaquin’s short story,“Summer Solstice,” rendered rural Filipino culture in modern dance and was commended by a critic as having translated the Graham modern style into a more oriental form to accommodate the telling of a Filipino story (Fernau Hall, 1972). Reyes’s For the Gods,on the other hand, is based on the dugso, a traditional thanksgiving dance from the Manobo people of Bukidnon.

Using modern dance, many Filipino choreographers Filipinized ballet because it was a style in which they could creatively explore their own rich traditions. They developed their own choreographies, with Filipino themes, to Filipino stories, using Filipino music, and even borrowing from Philippine dances.Most of the early Philippine-themed works were neo-classic ballets or modern dance works that used a rural or precolonial royal backdrop to appear Filipino. Some were also based on stories written by Filipino writers, myths handed down through generations, or historical themes paralleled with religious motifs.Examples are Denisa Reyes’s Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows), 1988, and Diablos (Demons), 1989; Edna Vida’s full-length Ibong Adarna (The Adarna Bird),1990; and Enrico Labayen’s The Dupe of Time, 1991. Eli Jacinto drew on his folk dance experience in his Filipino-themed modern works such as the Igorot-inspired Sa Panimula ng Buhay (At the Beginning of Life), 1991.

Reyes’s Neo-Filipino dance series sustained the production of works revolving around Philippine culture. Conceived when she was in New York at a time when funding for the arts had become meager, Neo-Filipino was a call to Filipino artists to work together. Carried over to the CCP, the Neo-Filipino program pursued the vision of artists working together, innovating, and exploring movement (Carabeo 2014/15, 34). The Neo-Filipino dance series featured works characterized by a range of movement vocabularies and techniques. These include Hazel Sabas’s Cry for Home and Locsin’s Paglalakbay, both 1992; Victor Ursabia’s Pas Galagawgaw (Naughty Pas),Dwight Rodrigazo’s Bread of Angels, and Locsin’s and Alden Lugnasin’s Impasse, all in 1993; Brando Mirando’s Rhapsody and Judell de Guzman’s Juan at ang Bagong Adan (Juan and the New Adam), both in 1994; E. Reyes’s Wired, 2004; Max Luna’s KatiTaog and Lugnasin’s Ulaging (Daogdog sa Sanlibong Kulog), both in 2009; Novy Bereber’s To Whom it May Concern and Ronelson Yadao’s You … Me … Us,2010; Candice Adea’s D Bar, Edna Mae Labitoria’s PG 13, Paul Morales’s Spaghetti Night, Eisa Jocson’s I am not a robot, maybe a cyborg, and Lugnasin’s Guin Hilom Ko, all in 2011; and Gerardo Mercardo’s Ang Krus ng Alitagtag (The Cross of Alitagtag) and Cristine Crame’s Sinotros Gentillorum, both in 2012.

After her Igorot,Locsin continued to Filipinize ballet and modern dance which marked many of her works called “neo-ethnic,” a term coined by her collaborator, musician Joey Ayala. Her other neo-ethnic and modern choreographies include Dabaw, 1988; Bagobo, 1990; Moslem, 1990; Moriones (Morion Soldiers), 1991; Babalyan (Shaman), 1993; and Taong Talangka (Man-Crab). Elements of this genre are likewise seen in Elias, 1995, La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution), 1996, Hinilawod, 1997, and in her later independent works, Sayaw Ang Kiukok (DanceLike an Ang Kiukok Painting), 2005, and the Alay sa Puno (Offering to the Trees) series, 2010-13.

The number of modern dances with Filipino themes later dwindled in number as the style became more associated with Locsin, and choreographers opted to find their own choreographic voice. Upon the advent of contemporary dance in the 1990s, young choreographers found a new direction for dance, and the themes of their works were the concerns of the millennials.

 

Contemporary Dance

Since 1997, dance in the Philippines saw the emergence of a genre called contemporary dance. The usage has a history rooted in particular geographical contexts and practices in the United States and Europe. Contemporary dance practice was adapted from the propositions into the nature of dance by European practitioners, propositions which consist of rereadings of innovations first initiated in the US. Thus, although the usage of “contemporary dance” has a European inflection (Lepecki 2004, 170-81), its emergence in other cultures did not necessarily take the form of direct translations of the European practice. In the US, the term more often used is “postmodern dance” which generally refers to a specific period and movement in dance in New York City between the 1960s and the 1970s. Downtown New York during this decade saw many activities of choreographers, known as the Judson Church Movement which rebelled against modern dance exemplified by prominent figures like Martha Graham and Doris Humphrey. Whereas the term “modern dance” had been generally defined according to a codified technique such as the Martha Graham technique, contemporary dance’s “revolution” precisely consisted in liberating dance from any codification and insisting on being defined according to its context. The Judson Church artists disdained virtuosity, reduced dance to its essential elements devoid of scenic props and design, and borrowed and experimented with the compositional techniques of other art forms to answer their inquiry into the nature of dance. They also performed in alternative spaces other than the formal theater with its proscenium stage (Foster 1986, 169).

Contemporary dance in the Philippines has come to refer not to a genre per se but to a process and critical perspective which gave birth to more or less an identifiable aesthetics shared by a number of practitioners. What has come to be considered “contemporary dance” works are those characterized by a certain mode of production and a certain way of approaching and conceptualizing dance. Contemporary dance has generally been informed by particular ways of creating works outside mainstream cultural institutions. In tracing the “emergence” of contemporary dance practice in the Philippines, critic, professor, choreographer, and dancer Basilio Villaruz highlights particular developments in dance during certain decades: the 1950s saw Philippine folk dance achieving world-wide recognition; the 1960s, brought the professionalization in dance through the establishment of dance companies like the Pamana Ballet, Hariraya Ballet, and Dance Theater Philippines; and, the 1970s to the mid-1990s saw BP, which was housed in the CCP as a dominant force.

The creative output of BP was in the modern dance style exemplified by the works of the company’s founder Alice Reyes who mined indigenous rituals and cultural practices and rendered them in modern dance forms. Like the modernist period of the West which was highly influenced by indigenous cultures of the non-West, the same was apparent in the modern dance repertoire of BP. The latter complemented the vision of the modern nation-state because it embodied the image of modernity inflected by a Filipino sensibility.

In contrast to the modernist style, Denisa Reyes’s works questioned the notion of a singular Filipino identity and probed into the national identity’s contradictions and paradoxes. These were seen in her One Ton Pinay, 1979; Made in the Philippines, 1984; Balimbingan and Cock vs. Cock, 1987; and Asong Ulol,1991. In her artistic direction of this series, in the eclectic approach and treatment of her own works, and in her more collaborative process, all of which were departures from the controlled forms and processes of the modern style, the younger Reyes’s body of works ushered in the postmodern.

There is the observation that a new phase began in the late 1990s when artists were free to explore new themes, concepts, and world views within and outside of CCP. But while there were new points of view, these did not in themselves constitute a new movement in dance. In this instance, there was a break from previous practices and there were common concerns among artists working outside CCP and other mainstream institutions that merited calling their collective practice a new movement in art. This is the genre and the practice now recognized as contemporary dance in the Philippines which foregrounds the materiality of dance, emphasizing that its “form” is a result of minimal, or even lack of resources. Contemporary dance distinguishes itself from the modern from the way it conceptualizes and renders dance.

If a moment could at all be identified as the beginning of the practice of contemporary dance, it would be when Myra Beltran opened her studio as a performing space in 1997, with her Dance Forum (founded earlier in 1995), independently producing her own works. While blurring the boundaries of producer and artist and determining the means of its production independently, she also paved the way for the creation of a community of like-minded practitioners by producing the works of other independent choreographers, some of them previously connected with mainstream dance companies. All of these artists eventually formed the core of the independent contemporary dance community. The aesthetics which resulted from inquiry and exploration of creative processes were applied by other choreographers in their work, although in varying degrees and with different perspectives. It was in 2004 when this “new breed” of choreographers came to be visible as a community producing what came to be called independent contemporary dance in the Philippines.

Creating for alternative spaces implied questioning the concepts of dance accepted as the norm for the formal theater’s proscenium stage such as notions of beauty and excellence in dance. Truth.con Furia, 2004, a collaborative work between Beltran’s Dance Forum and Jose Jay Cruz’s Dancing Wounded Contemporary Dance Commune challenged the audience to reassess their attitudes towards the body and ideas of perfection. The second concern is the insistence that each work of contemporary dance had to be read as developing its own particular aesthetics borne of specific material conditions, as seen in Airdance’s launching production titled R-18,2004, under the direction of Paul Morales.

The third concern of contemporary dance choreographers working often in intimate spaces is the dancer’s relationship with the audience. The art gallery, Green Papaya Art Projects called attention to this in Anatomy of Love and Desire, 2004, curated by Donna Miranda. In other articulations of the same concerns, Jojo Lucila and his Chameleon Dance Company (later named the Chameleon Dance Theater under the direction of Raul Alcoseba), developed a repertoire informed by aesthetics of the urban poor and grassroots sensibilities. For the UP Dance Company’s conceptually-trained dancers, ballet, together with its aesthetics of space, is no longer the default dance form. The contemporary choreographic styles of Elena Laniog, Herbert Alvarez, and Ava Maureen Villanueva have influenced the work of other younger dancers.

A fourth concern among contemporary dancers is the idea of the personal being both political and social. Beltran’s solo repertoire shows how doing away with the hierarchical structure of theater and expensive productions leaves the audience only with the dancer’s body, a lone body on stage which also happens to be that of the choreographer’s. As producer, choreographer, and dancer, contemporary dance artists blur the lines between these roles and claim ownership of the dance.

Contemporary dances have a more intimate feeling. To be “expressive” and beautiful in dance, the dancer need not conquer or defy space as is the practice in performances for the proscenium stage. Rather, the emphasis is on what occurs in-between or in the interstices of each movement, in the suspension of each breath, in the creation and resolution of momentum, and in the physics of movement.

While contemporary dance’s “style” has been disseminated across the dance landscape in the Philippines, it first evolved from dancers who, while having had previous relationships with mainstream cultural institutions, eventually created their works as independent artists. The Contemporary Dance Map Series initiated under the Choreographers’ Network of World Dance Alliance-Philippines in 2005, had independent artists celebrating International Dance Day with a performance-tour of alternative spaces for dance in a span of two weeks. Yet, contemporary dance practitioners have had collaborative projects with the CCP, one of which was the Wifi Body Festival. This first contemporary dance festival in the Philippines used the template of the earlier performance tour in mounting a similar one within the confines of CCP.

Wifi Body’s second year introduced the choreographers’ competition for the solo-duet form that paved the way for a stronger presence of Philippine contemporary dance in Asia, particularly in Japan, Malaysia, and Singapore. The young winners who pursued contemporary dance were Ava Villanueva, who eventually became the director of Airdance and Rhosam Prudenciado Jr whose Which Way won second place in the competition in 2008 and was awarded the Grand Prize at the 2009 Yokohama Dance Collection Ex for the same work. Others who first choreographed for the competition and continued their explorations of contemporary dance were Zyda Marie Baaya, Gerardo Francisco (who would continue to create for Ballet Manila), Mia Cabalfin, Jed Amihan, Alfred Mercado, Frederick Fernandez, Ea Torrado, Al Bernard Garcia, Sarah Marie Samaniego, Japhet Mari Cabling, and Razielle Ann Mitchao.

The Contemporary Dance Network Philippines which became the official network of practitioners of contemporary dance in 2009, decided to change its name to Contemporary Dance Network Manila in 2011 as most of them were based in the Metropolis which inevitably gave their works a more “urban aesthetic.” Its succeeding projects were Moving Dance @ LRT Dance Express, 2010, Underground and Hijack Dance, both in 2011, and RE: Rosas ng Maynila @ BGC, 2014.

The year 2014 marked the last of the Wifi Body Festivalwhich aptly culminated with works of choreographers who, looking back at their years of producing contemporary dance, created new works placing their practice not just in the context of Philippine dance but in the much bigger context of Philippine society. Even without the festival, CCP continues the competition to cover emerging choreographers and developing artists.

As proven by the increase in the number of contemporary works and choreographers in the country after the 1990s, contemporary dance is a dynamic and critical practice. Thus, in the future practitioners might evolve other ways of characterizing its contours and aesthetics.

 

Indigenous Dances

The decades after martial rule saw folk dance orkatutubong sayaw, initially rooted in communal life, thrive in a time of uprootedness. Dancers left their ancestral lands to work in urban jungles or in foreign lands. Most merely knew the moves but not the why’s behind the shuffling of feet or the outstretched arms or the syncopated beats. Audiences fell under the spell of western pop culture and demanded drama and extravaganza instead of simpler dance forms. But folk dance did adapt. Some were performed as street dances or in mass demonstrations. Others were staged for local and regional cultural events and incorporated the influences of dance troupes based in Metro Manila and changes in technology (Namiki 2014, 74). In various ways and forms, folk dance during the post-EDSA Revolt thrived.

Even with the increase in cross-cultural contacts, diffusion of Western and Asian pop culture to the Philippines, and the intensification of technology’s influence on the lives of the Filipinos resulting in the disappearance of many traditional cultural practices and rituals, some folk dances continued to be integral to communal life.

Among the Kalingas, thebodongpeace pact rite with its indigenous ceremonial dance has continued up to the 21st century. The establishment of a bodong between Kalinga groups is marked by prolonged feasting, the playing of musical instruments, singing, and dancing. There is also dancing in thegaligadceremony where a peace-pact holder turns over a bodong to someone else, usually his son. The bendiyan of the Ibaloy, which originated in Kabayan, Benguet as a dance celebrating a successful headhunt or the tribe’s victory against its enemies, continued in the 21st century as a dance honoring Kabunian, the supreme being of the Benguet or Ibaloy or as a thanksgiving dance for a bountiful harvest. In the Sulu archipelago, ritual dances to drive away spirits that cause illness are the Badjaopagjinn, the magjuwata from South Ubian, Tawi-Tawi, the magpugot from Musu, and the magsalba from Bulikulul, the last two, in Siasi. Aside from propitiating the spirits calledapo-jin,the dance is likewise done for a good catch, trouble-free childbirth, long life, peaceful death, or a smooth journey to heaven.

Very apparent was how folk dance continued to be one of the most popular forms of cultural dancing after the 1986 EDSA Revolt. As the nation rebuilt its image through tourism after the fall of Marcos, folk dance was a regular in hotels, restaurants, casinos, cruise ships, tourist sites, and various events aimed to attract both local and foreign tourists. In 2002, of the total 667,226 OFWs deployed by the Philippines, around 77,870 OFWs went to Japan (POEA 2003) and many of these were cultural performers dancing the country’s most popular folk dances.

As guest entertainers in Japan, the dancers had booking contracts with their agents and club managers and were required to show their artist’s certification and other “documentary credentials” from the Philippines. But even if these cultural dancers were accredited under the Artist Record Book System by the Technical Education and Skills Development Authority after undergoing basic training in dancing, singing, and other performing arts, they were not spared from employment abuse. A number had no choice but provide other forms of entertainment, including prostitution. Unfortunately, as “professional guest performing artists” and not “workers,” the labor law in Japan did not apply to them (Matsuda 2003, 3). Beginning in 2004, there was a decline in the number of Filipino cultural performers going to Japan because its government was forced to impose stringent requirements for entertainers entering the country (Sun Star Manila 2011).

At the turn of the 21st century, folk dance performances were seen in almost all popular travel destinations in the Philippines such as Villa Escudero in San Pablo City and Tam-Awan Village in Baguio. Other areas were Boracay, Cebu, Davao, and Bohol which is famous for its Loboc river cruise dancers. The Amazing Show in Manila and Cebu is perhaps one of the biggest productions of cultural dancing featuring gays and transgenders performing indigenous ethnic dances from the northern and southern parts of the Philippines.

In contrast to the martial law era, there was more room for the “folk” in CCP after the 1986 EDSA Revolt. Before the revolt, reaching out to the regions “usually meant transporting performances created by Manila artists to the provinces, which tended to reduce regional artists and audiences to the status of passive observers or receptors of “high art” from the “sophisticated” center to the “deprived peripheries” (Tiongson 2006, 35). But this all changed in 1986 as the a wave of nationalism—a Filipino First mentality—swept the nation. CCP’s newly appointed administrators fought for more exposure for Filipino artists and the accessibility of art to all socio-economic classes. It included another folkloric dance troupe, the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group (ROFG), in its roster of beneficiaries. Through CCP grants or in collaboration with the Philippine Folk Dance Society, the ROFG conducted dance workshops for school teachers, held lecture-demonstrations for children, and provided lectures on Philippine folk dance and traditions (Namiki 2014, 50). The ROFG launched various programs aimed to expand the body of knowledge on Philippine folk dance. Its Unpublished Dances of the Philippines series presented dances and rituals never been included in dance books or integrated in the repertoires of performing groups in Metro Manila (Namiki 2014, 46)

The Bayanihan was declared the National Folk Dance Company of the Philippines in 1998, the year the country celebrated its centennial as a Republic. The two state-supported folk dance companies not only differed in their styles of folkdance but also in how they addressed the different needs of the State. The ROFG’s folkloric performance attempted to hew closely to the “original” folk dance forms (i.e., dances as “practiced or performed by native dancers of cultural/ethnic communities” ) while the Bayanihan rendered folk dances in a more theatrical manner (Namiki 2014, 60). The Bayanihan was more visible in government-sponsored international events in the Philippines and in international tours as a representative of the country, while the ROFG’s overseas engagements were more dedicated to local audiences, focusing on productions to educate the Filipinos. To a large extent, the two companies complemented each other’s contribution in creating a sense of nationhood. Obusan was proclaimed National Artist for Dance in 2006, almost 20 years after the last National Artist Award for dance was given to the first director of Bayanihan, Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, in 1988 (Namiki 2014, 80-81).

There were two folk dance festivals CCP supported after EDSA 1: the Pang-alay (Offering) : A Festival of Philippine Folk Dances andthe Sari-Saring Sayaw, Sama-Samang Galaw: Mga Tradisyon at Interpretasyon (Different Dances, Unified Movements: Traditions and Interpretations) both held during thePhilippine Arts Month in February. These festivals brought together folk dance groups from all over the country. Some of these were the Araullo University Dance Group, Bayanihan, Bungkos Palay Dance Ensemble of Science City of Munoz, Centro Escolar University Dance Troupe,Kaamulan, Kabpapagariya, Kaloob: Philippine Music and Dance Ministry, Kalilayan Folkloric Group-MESUF, Lahing Batangan Dance Troupe, Lahing Kayumanggi Dance Ensemble of Laguna, Nagalas Chi Kalinga, Nayong Pilipino, Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe, ROFG, Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe, Silliman University Kayahag Dance Troupe, Sindaw Philippines Performing Arts Guild, Sining Bulakenyo ng Malolos, Sining Kalinangan Mapua Tech Dance Company, Sining Kumintang ng Batangas, Sining Lahi Folk Dance Troupe, St Anne Theater Dance Company of Taguig, University of the East Dance Troupe, and the UPLB Filipiniana Dance Troupe. Over the years, the Hwa Yi Ethnic Dance Center, a group of young performers of indigenous Chinese dance, has regularly joined the festivals, promoting cultural understanding between Filipinos and Chinese. The support given by CCP to these events was a way of reaching out to dance groups in other regions and tapping them to help create a common national heritage.

Another space that has served as a comfortable home for folk dance is the university. At the Palawan State University, the Sining Palawan Dance Troupe concentrates on promoting the province’s indigenous dances as well as the dances from southern Philippines. At the University of Santo Tomas, the Salinggawi Dance Troupe continues to perform popular folk dances such as the maglalatik, tinikling,and sayaw sa bangko. Bulacan State University’s Lahing Kayumanggi Dance Troupe has its own offerings, too—a wide variety of traditional Philippine dances that includes occupational and festival dances, and even war dances. Meanwhile, the Philippine Normal College Baranggay Dance Troupe continues to perform both the country’s katutubong sayaw and native songs.

The country’s premiere university, the University of the Philippines (UP), is home to one of the most acclaimed folk dance troupes in the country. The UP Filipiniana Dance Company, founded in 1935 as the UP Folk Song and Dance Club by Francisca Reyes-Aquino, has, for 80 years, served as training ground for future torchbearers of Philippine cultural dances. It has provided young dancers rigorous cross-training in jazz and contemporary dance, and has cultivated their passion for research in the area of folk dance. The UP Filipiniana was known for its Cordillera region and Muslim Mindanao dance repertoires. It represented the country in international festivals, the most recent one being Pyesta Kolon Datal held in Aug 2015, organized by the Conseil International des Organisations de Festival de Folklor et d’arts Traditionnels (CIOFF).

Other school-based dance groups include the Centro Escolar University Dance Troupe, Far Eastern University Folk Dance Group, Ingat Kapandayan Cultural Dancers of the Notre Dame of Jolo College, Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe of the Carlos P. Garcia High School in Manila, Silliman University Kahayag Dance Troupe, Sining Kalinangan Mapua Tech Dance Company, Sining Lahi Folk Dance Troupe of the Lakandula High School in Manila, Sining Kumintang ng Batangas of the Bauan High School, Lahing Batangan Dance Troupe of the Lyceum of the Philippines University in Batangas, and the St Louis University Dance Troupe. All these have performed and won recognition both in the Philippines and abroad. Other active groups are the Marikina Dance Guild, Leyte Dance Theater, Mga Anak ng Inang Daigdig, and Fiesta Filipino Dance Troupe.

Beyond academe, various community- and provincial-based groups that promote indigenous dances continue to flourish. The Francisca Reyes Aquino Memorial Foundation (FRAMF), for example, has been conducting folk dance workshops and seminars in schools and communities across the archipelago since 1991.With the guidance of Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, the AlunAlun Dance Circle on the other hand, has focused on preserving and promoting the pangalay/igal/pansak, the indigenous dance among the Samal, Badjao/Sama Dilaut, Jama Mapun, and Tausug peoples of the Sulu Archipelago, through both traditional and nontraditional choreographies. In 2015, Fernando Amilbangsa was conferred the Ramon Magsaysay Award for her “single-minded crusade in preserving the endangered artistic heritage of southern Philippines, and in creatively propagating a dance form that celebrates and deepens the sense of shared cultural identity among Asians” (Ramon Magsaysay 2015)

The post–EDSA Revolt period also witnessed the popularization of regional folk dance festivities such as the Kaamulan (to gather) Festival in Cotabato joined in by indigenous groups in Bukidnon.From mid-February to the first week of March, these groups participate in numerous events, one of which is the performance of their rituals and dances such as the monkey and frog dances. The Kaamulan also features groups playing their indigenous instruments.

The Panagbenga (Blooming of Flowers) or Flower Festival in Baguio, a month-long celebration that begins in February and extends to the first week of March, spotlights gangsa music and Cordillera dances such as the Ibaloy’s bendiyan. Among the numerous events are the Grand Street Dancing Parade followed by a field demonstration of dances based on folklore and rituals.

The Agal-Agal (Seaweed) Festival, a five-day celebration participated in by 11 municipalities honoring the Sama, Badjao, Jama Mapun, and Tausug of southern Philippines, is held every September in Tawi-Tawi. The much-awaited dance performances of the different groups revolve around the seaweed harvest, pangalay dancing, and other aspects of the people’s every day life. Tourists are treated to music from thekulintanganensemble that serve as accompaniment to performances of the pangalay/igal, kuntao, silat, lunsay which are dances unique to the indigenous peoples of Tawi-Tawi. The colorful attires of the performers are trimmed with seaweeds and various marine products.

Older festivals that began before or during the martial law period as part of tourism continued after the EDSA Revolt. Most, if not all, of these festive forms were magnified in terms of length of celebration, financial investment, and cultural articulation.

Aklan’s Kalibo, Ibajay, Batan, Makato, and Altavas witnessed their Ati-Atihan Festival in honor of the Child Jesus or Santo Niño evolve into a more colorful and upbeat event which would run for a month, culminating on the 3rd Sunday of January (Reyes-Tinagan 2001, 47-8). Thebudyong,agongorbagtoesounds, shouts and chants of the Ati, songs of the Maraynon, and the inano (monkey dance), inagong (Maraynon war dance), and langagaran (courtship dance) dances gave way to innovations (Reyes-Tinagan 2001, 104). It was after the EDSA Revolt when the celebration intensified, with snare drums and lyres and even bands becoming more regular musical accompaniments. Revelers in Kalibo came in character costumes like Michael Jackson or as show girls in the famous Parisian music hall Folies Bergere, dancing like the King of Pop or a cabaret performer (Alcedo 2012).

In Cebu, the Ati-Atihan-inspired Sinulog, which began in 1980, evolved into one of the country’s biggest festivals. Celebrated on the third Sunday of January to honor the Santo Niño, the festivity has several groups of participants in flamboyant costumes weaving through the streets while dancing the sinulog. To the beat of the drums, participants take two steps forward, one step back, a combination quite different from that of Kalibo’s Ati-Atihan. As a way of keeping the integrity of the sinulog in the wake of various choreographic innovations, dance workshops and demonstrations were sponsored by the CCP, together with the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, and the Philippine Folk Dance Society. Physical Education teacher and choreographer Dolores Suzara was a key figure in the efforts to impart to the participants the significance of the festival. The Sinulog is also celebrated in other provinces in the Visayas: in Kabankalan, Negros Oriental, Digos, Davao del Sur, and in Jimalalud, Negros Oriental.

The Dinagyang of Iloilo, which was inspired by the popularity of Kalibo’s Ati-Atihan and the religious component of Cebu’s Sinulog became more magnified from the late 1990s onwards. The simple linear formation and basic “step right, step left, step right, raise left” footwork, which was close to that of Kalibo’s footwork in the 1970s, transformed into criss-crossing formations in the 1980s. As much as there was a strong presence of popular culture in the dances, the distinct movement vocabulary of indigenous groups in the Southern Philippines also found its way to the choreographies (Buensuceso 2014, 2015). And with choreographers attending dance workshops in Manila, the modern and contemporary dance vocabularies have been woven into the ethnic or so-called tribal movements of the dances (Flogen 2014).

Street dancing is also integral to several festivals rejoicing the defeat of Lucifer by Saint Michael the Archangel. In Iligan City, street dancing which has become the main event of the Kasadya (Merriment) Festival is enriched by different local dances such as the diyandi (dance in honor of Saint Michael), eskrima (war dance), Higaonon dances, and the yawa-yawa (devil-devil) (Alejandro 2008, 74-5).

During the Tinagba Festival in Iriga City, Camarines Sur, farmers express their gratitude to Our Lady of Lourdes by “symbolically offer[ing] their first crop” to her. A major part of the celebration is the Agta Tabangon or Itum (black) group performing a dance mimicking their way of life in the mountains (Alejandro 2008, 101).

And as if the grand festivals are not enough to boast each region’s faith, history, tradition, cultural dances, and agricultural produce, the annual Aliwan Fiesta or the so-called Mother of All Fiestas was organized by the Manila Broadcasting Company in 2003. The Cultural Street Dance Competition is considered the highlight of the gathering of the best cultural performances of the country. The competing contingents perform folk dances combined with popular western dances as they parade from the Quirino Grand Stand to the Aliw Theater, in the CCP Complex.

These celebrations continue to draw huge audiences, both local and foreign tourists attending not so much as to see the choreographies of local dance groups but to soak in the carnivalesque atmosphere, and with all senses heightened, gyrate like everyone else to the deafening sound of the drums and feel a sense of oneness with the crowd. Because all these festivals are crucial to their regions’ tourism program, it is inevitable that they become more commercially appealing every year. Yet, the danger of forgetting the significance of the festivals has been counterbalanced by efforts of the organizing committees to keep the performances in line with the supposed meaning of the celebrations.

The festivals may have placed folk dances in a context that forced them to relentlessly innovate, resulting in modified movement vocabulary and tempo, but the very same context has also provided these dances a space for their visibility. In the 21st century, most of these dances have been taken out of their original settings. They are danced on stage, instead of being embedded in the daily activities of indigenous communities. We see performances of folk dances aboard cruise ships, in barangay basketball courts, in variety shows on television, and in restaurants, bars, and hotel lobbies in the Philippines and abroad. Folk dance, according to critics, has become purely for commercial purposes, and caters to western theater aesthetics to meet the demands of an audience that only seeks to be entertained by something new and exotic.

Paradigm shifts, however, have allowed a more liberal, yet still critical approach to folk dances. To say that the dances lost their cultural mooring when they were staged by universities, integrated into commercial festivals, or performed in various venues both in the Philippines and abroad, is to assume that they no longer embody the “folk” or the people’s beliefs, practices, and aspirations. But the history of Philippine dance has proven that it will always be a dynamic form— a corporeal, religious/spiritual, historical, and material practice expressing the people’s hopes and dreams. An embodiment of both sacred and secular investments, the folk dances of the 21st century continue to express not only the body’s constant response to cultural and economic changes but also to the spiritual needs of every performer and the collective impulse of a community .

 

Social Dances

The landscape of dance in the Philippines during the post-EDSA Revolt was also marked by the rise in number of clubs, fitness centers, and ballroom studios that became the hub of social dancing enthusiasts. The dance fusions found in these places could be traced to the popularity of dancing in Philippine TV beginning in the 1980s. As variety shows became a household phenomenon, there was likewise an increase in demand for dancers who became mainstays of shows like Vilma! later retitled Vilma In Person, 1986-95; Superstar, 1972-89; Maria! Maria! ,later retitled Maricel Live! ,1986-89; The Other Side of Alma, 1981-83 and Loveliness, 1987-88; Manilyn Live!, 1986-88; Lotlot and Friends, 1985-88; Tonight with Dick and Carmi, 1988-91; POPS!,1992-96; Vina,1993-94; and The Sharon Cuneta Show,1986-88 in IBC13 and 1988-97 in ABS-CBN 2. Television viewers would look forward to the impressive opening numbers of their favorite stars who hired choreographers and rehearsed for hours to impress the audience.

The choreographers behind these shows, in particular Geleen Eugenio and Miles Obra, invented the “helicopter” move where the female star was lifted and twirled overhead by her male partner. They also introduced the “buhat-tapon” (lift and throw) combination where the female superstar was lifted by three male dancers, thrown into space, and then caught by six other male dancers at the other end of the dance floor (Ramos 2013, 134).

With the popularity of TV dancing, a number of independent groups danced their way to commercial television. Some of these were the VIP Dancers, Powerdance, Hotlegs, Adrenaline, Whiplash, Solid Gold, Discorama Dancers, Julie Borromeo’s Dance Arts, and Veda Bañez Metropolitan Dancers. The VIP dancers was one of the most famous groups showcasing a range of dance styles: commercial pop, street dance, ballet, jazz, gymnastics, hip-hop, ballroom, folk, funk, broadway, theatrics or theatrical, and athletic dance steps. Ballroom fusion was associated with this group and the combination of styles inspired more dance fusions on TV dancing which continued until the first decade of the 21st century.

Also regularly seen on TV in the 1980s were dance groups that promoted record companies: the Vicor Dancers, Blackgold Dancers, WEA Dancers, Dyna Dancers, and the WEA Twins. A number of dance contests became much-awaited segments of daily TV shows which popularized the Spanish hustle, salsa, LA walk, swing, the bop-bop girl, and cycling punk. There were likewise a number of all-boy dance groups that usually guested in TV shows: Gary Valenciano’s Maneuvers, the Streetboys, and the Universal Motion Dancers (Ramos 2010, 134).

In the late 1990s, a group of alluring dancers became a hit. Initially a group of back-up dancers for the “Laban o Bawi” (Fight or Retreat) game show of the noontime TV show Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!), the Sex Bomb Dancers were known for their flexibility and ability to “contort their bodies like invertebrates” (Ramos 2013, 135). Their hit song and dance “Spageti Pababa” (Spaghetti Going Down)was phenomenal and in 2010, their music video “Bilog na Hugis Itlog” (Round-shaped Egg) was used to teach viewers the newly implemented elections procedure. After its stint with Eat Bulaga!, the group joined the show Happy Truck ngBayan (Happy Truck of the Community) of TV5. Later, the group’s members became freelance dancers and appeared in several shows.

The 1990s saw another generation of celebrity dancers which was also backed up by the VIP dancers. Bb. Pilipinas-Universe Charlene Gonzales and the 1993 Ms Universe Dayanara Torres together with Troy Montero and Franco Laurel impressed viewers in their show titled Eezy Dancing on TV5, 1995-98, which was later retitled KeepOn Dancing onABS-CBN 2, 1998-2001. The warm reception to ballroom dancing on Philippine TV carried over to clubs, afternoon discos, and bars in urban centers especially Metro Manila as more enthusiasts not only frequented these places but also hired dance instructors to teach them the moves. As ballroom dancing became more sensational, it morphed into another social but extremely competitive dance, known as dancesport.Like the earlier ballroom dances that were featured in TV variety shows, dancesport had its own share of television exposure: Lucy Torres-Gomez’s Shall We Dance? onTV5, 2005-10, which eventually became Celebrity Dance Battle.

Dancesportin the Philippines was characterized by athleticism and became a “higher level of ballroom” (Samson 2014). Noticing that the Philippines had no dancesport organization, Blackpool Modern Standard champion (senior level), Paul Bishop connected the World Dance and Dancesport Council with the Philippine Sports Commission (PSC) which was interested in participating in the World Ballroom Championship and in the Olympics. Through the efforts of the PSC and the newly formed Dancesport Council of the Philippines, Inc. (DSCPI), dancesport took off in the country. The DSCPI sponsored the first dance congress at the Ninoy Aquino Stadium in 1997, an event which introduced the competitive style of ballroom dancing.

The local scene has provided encouragement to dance enthusiasts who could join a number of competitions all-year round. For example, the DSCPI holds amateur rankings three times a year. Cebu City hosts the Dancesport saSugbu while the annual Philippine Summer Ball is held in different regions of the country. Schools and universities have also provided a regular venue for students interested in dancesport. Almost every month of the first half of the year has competitions joined in by around 80 to 150 pairs (Samson, 2014).

With the exposure of the youth to dancesport in local competitions, there has been a dramatic increase in the number of children going into dancesport. In many competitions, majority of the contestants come from the youth sector—“the Youth, Junior, and Juvenile athletes”—and each event sees close to thirty couples vying for trophies and cash prizes (Samson, 2014).

In the international scene, Filipinos have also been winning in dancesport competitions: Michael Mendoza won in the South East Asian games dancesport category, Alberto Dimarucut and Deborah Civardi were the first Filipino professionals representing the country in Blackpool, England in 2000, and Edna Ledesma was the first Filipina to win a gold medal (Latin senior division) in the prestigious Blackpool Competition in 2005.

Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo’s Proclamation 203 in 2002 set Nov 4 to 10 as National Dancesport Week. Since then, dancesport competitions have become more popular in schools and universities around the country. Sports associations like the State Colleges and Universities Athletic Association, the Private Schools Athletic Association, and the Association of Local Colleges and Universities have included this category in their competitions. At the 2013 DSCPI National Championship, a new category of dancesport was introduced: wheelchair dancing. The new form was envisioned to encourage differently-abled people explore their kinesthetic talents. After participating in workshops, not only were the dancers able to join both local and international competitions. They were also invited to perform in shows and TV contests (Samson 2014).

Practitioners have been training teachers and coaches all around the country. A number of local coaches, on the other hand, have not only offered free workshops to their students but also sponsored their training under foreign coaches. Professional dancesport organizations like the Philippine Dance Teacher Association, the Philippine Dance Sport Association of the Philippines, and the DSCPI-Professional Division hold conferences, seminars, and workshops to further strengthen dancesport in the country. Dancesport Team Cebu, in collaboration with Cebu’s local government, has offered free workshops to children coming from different parts of the province, enabling them to join national competitions (Samson 2014).

From social clubs to ballroom studios, to fitness centers, and to basketball courts. Social dancing is no longer just a hobby or a leisure activity among Filipinos who get together for various reasons. Upon migrating to other venues or spaces, including television, social dance has gained unprecedented popularity over the years. No longer is social dance generally associated with the older generation as more young girls and boys have fearlessly executed dance routines with grace and energy.

 

Hip-hop, Cheerdance, and Flash Mob Dance

From the late 1980s onward, the Philippines, like most, if not, all countries in the world, experienced the intensification of the effects of new media on almost all aspects of society. The digital age inevitably informed the ways by which Filipinos looked at their identity and created communities which were no longer confined to the national borders. Social networking redefined or even reconfigured the ways by which Filipinos experienced politics, religion, and culture. It is in the context of the drastic changes in technology which in turn accelerated the pace of globalization that dance in the Philippines saw itself moving towards different directions in the late 20th and early 21st centuries. Two significant dance phenomena that caught the country’s attention were hip-hop and the dance flash mob.

To understand hip-hop in the Philippines is to view it as pulses in the country’s cultural histories. Hip-hop is alive, especially in the underground scene, and like a pulse, it has distinct beats corresponding to specific historical landmarks and encounters with mainstream media as well.

Since its emergence in the South Bronx of the US in the 1960s, hip-hop has always been an inter- and trans-disciplinary cultural phenomenon, an amalgam of art forms, or in hip-hop language, the “elements.”Turntablismis closely linked to music,graffitito the visual arts,rapto poetry, and breaking to dance.

In the 1970s and 1980s, the Filipino-Americanbalikbayan(Filipinos visiting from abroad) brought with them the music and movies featuring the hip-hop culture phenomenon in the West. Also in the 1980s, mainstream media, specifically dance shows, highlighted new trends in fashion and dance from the US. It was the dance-everything decade inundated by dance contests, dance movies, and dance clubs. Television became one, if not the primary, avenue by which hip-hop dancing was seen and learned by viewers almost round the clock; there were the evening dance variety shows, Loveliness and Vilma, and noontime shows Eat Bulaga! and Student Canteen with dance contests. Perhaps the most important dance contest of this era was Dance 10 ,featuring pioneer poppers, lockers, and breakers such as Darwin Tuason, Jerry Dignum, and The Eclipse Breakers’ Francis Magalona. While these programs may not have exactly promoted hip-hop culture and its elements, it was through them that some careers of mainstream hip-hop icons took off.

In 1984, three major dance-themed films featuring hip-hop dancing were released: Hot Shots, with Gary Valenciano showing off his strutting, popping and locking; Campus Beat, with Aga Mulach dancing the Michael Jackson style of popping, locking, and shuffling; and Bagets 2, with Francis Magalona executing strut, breakdance, and some power moves. The music industry’s WEA Dancers, Knap Sax, Funk System Dancers, Octo Full Force, Vicor Dancers, Octo Mechanics, and (Octo) Maneuvers became major players in promoting hip-hop dance and music all over the country. They became inspirations of a number of hip-hop b-boycrews that crossed into the mainstream like the Street Boys, which became popular for their power moves.

Numerous dance clubs and discotheques were places for producers and choreographers to scout fresh talents who could be developed as pop stars specializing in rapping and dancing. Some of these dancers’ hangouts were Faces, Kudos, Jealousy, and Mars in Makati, and Heartbeat in Quezon City.

Also happening simultaneously with the popularity of hip-hop films was the immediate formation of hip-hop crews, most of them b-boy crews. The new hip-hop culture that embodied youth rage, dissatisfaction, unrest and at the same time, a sense of brotherhood and camaraderie amongst crew members, fit perfectly into the brewing unrest in the country that eventually erupted into People Power or EDSA Revolt.

Most of the early hip-hop crews that were formed in the Philippines were in fact breakers or b-boy crews like the pioneering Info-Clash Breakers whose members included the hip-hop icon Andrew E., Ground Control, Whooze Co., and The Eclipse Breakers, crew of the “Master Rapper” Francis Magalona (Junaini 2015). These groups would meet up in empty parking spaces around the Metro and other nearby towns surrounding the Greater Manila Area. Frequented places were Quad and Glorietta in Makati, Ali Mall in Cubao, and places near the US bases in Angeles City, Pampanga.

Greatly influenced by hip-hop culture in America, these hip-hop crews or clans were usually composed of groups that specialized in the four elements of hip-hop—rap, breaking, turntablism, and graffiti. Some of the famous and pioneer hip-hop crews and/or clan affiliations were Rock All Parties Crew, the early crew of Andrew E., Mastaplann, True Asiatik Tribe, the Battle Krew with J-Mastah and B-boy Artstrong as head b-boys, and 4EastFlava with its affiliated breaker crew Funkadellic Posse.

During the mid-1980s, a paradigm shift in cultural practices was felt with the fall of the Marcoses. The state’s privileging of the fine arts orbeaux artsover popular music and songs and disco dancing gave way to the resurfacing of many artists and artistic productions previously snubbed by the dictatorship.

Popular musicians were very active during the three-day EDSA Revolt and even created an “anthem” for the uprising—the composition “Handog ng Pilipino sa Mundo” by Jim Paredes and sung by a number of established pop singers at the time. These artists who formed the Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit or OPM were later at the forefront of the struggle against the dictatorship. They also became the voices and faces of the new Aquino regime (Valdes 2013) which supported them by promoting and patronizing popular music and establishing new cultural and artistic institutions that would promote “true/ly” Filipino arts and culture through the NCCA, and setting up policies to promote original Filipino music. In the years that came after, cultural productions centered on the theme of “national pride and identity” through various experimentations in indigenization by using Filipino and other local languages in popular music, interweaving indigenous visual motifs with new fashion, and merging indigenous rhythm and beat with popular tunes and compositions. This trend was picked up by the growing hip-hop community in the country. While the theme of national pride and identity was close to the roots of hip-hop culture in America where productions mostly revolved around racial pride and identity, Filipino hip-hop pioneers used “indigenization” as a way to truly create and represent a Filipino hip-hop culture.

By the early 1990s, there were three spaces for hip-hop dancing: mainstream media, or television shows and movies; dance clubs and discotheques; and underground hip-hop meeting points which were mostly parking lots used as battle grounds for breakers and rappers. Most of these spaces, in one way or another, influenced the development of, paved the way for, and or simply intersected with many of the hip-hop icons and game changers in the country.

In 1990, Francis M or the Man from Manila and his crew The Eclipse (b-boy crew) and Spindicate Posse (DJ crew), which included pioneer turntablist Dj Master of Disaster or Dj MOD, released the song “Mga Kababayan” with its indigenous instrumentations and mixes. Rapping in sarong accentuated by accessories with indigenous motifs, their song and fashion statement truly represented the post-EDSA Revolt mood and the new cultural agenda of the Aquino regime centered on nationalism, Filipino identity, and pride. This became the mark of the so-called Golden Age of hip-hop in the country which was characterized by numerous fissures in hip-hop practices and politics, including debates in language and the rise of femmecees, old and new school hip-hop, novelty and authentic hip-hop, and even studio and street hip-hop dancing.

During the Golden Age of hip-hop which lasted until the mid-1990s, there was still a steady stream of so-called manufactured rappers with dancers such as Lady Diane, MC Lara, and even Michael V. as part of their acts. But underground hip-hop culture whose practitioners were schooled and rooted in the hip-hop communities in the US came to dominate the hip-hop scene both under and above ground.

Mastaplann was a game changer in this new hip-hop culture in the Philippines. The group includedbalikbayansMCs Johnny “Type” Luna and Butch “Tracer” Velez and affiliated with the turntablist group The Megateam composed of DJ Sonny, DJ Ouch, and DJ MOD, and the b-boy crew and Battle Krew with members like J-mastah, B-boy Artstrong, and MC Type’s brother Mark Luna. Mastaplann introduced to the mainstream dance scene a kind of hip-hop fashion characterized by oversized jerseys and extremely low-waist baggy pants and jamming or freestyle dancing associated with the streets. It was also one of the first groups that produced a music video featuring the four elements of hip-hop, exploiting the new MTV Asia hype when it aired in 1992 in order to disseminate “authentic” hip-hop culture in the Philippines.

In the 1990s, Andrew E’s pioneering Rock All Parties Crew of the early 1980s continued to make waves in the hip-hop scene with Espiritu’s continuing DJ stints in various discotheques around the Metro as well as his hosting of rap contests on television and radio shows. The winners of these competitions became the first artists that Andrew E. developed and produced under what is considered to be the first hip-hop recording company in the Philippines, the Dongalo Records.

Disco Mix Club or DMC Philippines, headed by former radio Dj Jessie Cambosa, was the main platform that allowed all elements of hip-hop to flourish in mainstream media. DMC did not only manage hip-hop crews composed of MCs but also developed DJ and b-boy crews, so much so that in 1993 the First Asian Dance Music Convention was held at the Philippine International Convention Center (PICC). The convention pulled together b-boys, hip-hop crews, and enthusiasts from all over the Philippines and around the globe, and hosted DJ workshops and seminars on hip-hop culture, as well as the First Asian Dj Mixing Championship.

In the following years, hip-hop dance occupied a relatively smaller space in the hip-hop culture as hip-hop music became the focus of most crews. This was music that particularly veered away from the party, dance, and club type, and focused more on eithergangsta(slang for gangster) or socially conscious rap with heavy themes accompanied by heavier mixes that were not as dance-able as the earlier ones. But hip-hop dancing found new venues: the studios.

In the 21st century, the most popular hip-hop dance groups have been found in studios, some of them, with almost no affiliation with other hip-hop crews. This has sparked debates on the issue of “authenticity” and the difference between street dancers and studio dancers. But hip-hop dance crews produced by and hosted in studios were primarily responsible for the resurgence of hip-hop dance in the country, whether this was “authentic” hip-hop or not. They have created a steady stream of hip-hop dancers and enthusiasts through their classes and performances, respectively, engendering a new generation of performers and audiences for hip-hop. These dance crews have also provided a clearing for Filipino hip-hop dancers all over the world by joining and winning in worldwide hip-hop dance competitions. The Philippine All-Stars and the UP Street Dance Club are among the pioneers of hip-hop dance produced in studios. In recent years, film picked up on the resurgence of hip-hop culture. Pintakasi, 2012, directed by Lee Meily, featured the first batch of Philippine All-Stars in its opening breaking credits. The hip-hop dance movie inspired by Francis M’s song of the same title Kaleidoscope World released in 2013 and directed by Eliza Cornejo, is considered to be the first hip-hop dance movie in the Philippines.

While Pinoy hip-hop is still largely concentrated in the Greater Manila Area, its energy in various urban centers across the country is undeniable. Cebu has one of the largest concentration of hip-hop practitioners in the Visayas while Zambaoanga released its own brand of Chabacano rap.

Also gaining a following beginning 2000s is cheerdance, which has been the source of pride of the country’s major universities, thus attracting more dancers from the student body. It gained public interest when the University Athletic Association of the Philippines (UAAP) launched its cheerdance competition in the mid-1990s. Since then, cheerdance has become not just a much-awaited segment of every UAAP opening but has acquired its own identity.

Cheerdance in the Philippines might have its roots in the American sport of cheerleading which incorporates dance, gymnastics, cheer, group stunts, and pyramids (American Sport Education Program 2009), but it has evolved its own particular characteristics such as having a specific theme and being longer in routine. Examples of themes adopted by the competing cheerdance teams in the 2013 UAAP cheerdance competition are the party theme (UP Pep Squad), Egytian theme (UST Salinggawi Dance Troupe), Arabian theme (NU Pep Squad), military theme (Animo Pep Squad of DLSU), sports theme (ADMU Blue Babble Batallion), and fire theme (UE Red Squad) (Gangalani 2014). From the mid-1990s onwards, melding folk dance, hip-hop, martial arts, gymnastics, and even yoga movements in well-conceptualized choreographies has become a common cheerdance practice.

Over the years, two universities with strong dance groups have been neck and neck in the competitions—the University of the Philippines Varsity Pep Squad (UP Pep Squad) and the University of Santo Tomas Salinggawi Dance Troupe (UST Salinggawi). In the early years of the competition, UP sent its UP Filipiniana Dance Troupe but from 1998 onwards, the UP Varsity Pep Squad competed for the university. Other groups such as the Far Eastern University’s Cheering Squad and the Ateneo de Manila’s Ateneo Blue Babble Battalion challenged UP and UST beginning 2010. In 2013 and 2014, the National University’s Pep Squad dominated the competition with their nearly perfect execution of stunts and dance moves.

The Philippines holds four major competitions in cheerdance. Aside from the UAAP Cheer Dance Competition, there are three other local competitions: the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) Cheer Dance Competition, the National Cheerleading Championships Incorporated (NCC), and the Philippine National Games (PNG). The NCC, has been active in promoting cheerleading and has an annual search for the best groups in the Philippines. Around 250 schools with 5,000 athletes have participated in the competition. Stressing the distinct form of cheerleading, NCC’s efforts have been geared towards making the public realize that cheerleading is not just a form of entertainment but a sport in itself (Fernandez 2015). The Philippines’ 27-all-girls team, Team Pilipinas, won gold medals in the South East Asian Cheerleading Open from 2011 to 2013, and competed in Australia, Malaysia, and Singapore (Fernandez 2014; Dreschler 2014).

Undoubtedly, both cheerdance and cheerleading have drawn the interest of the Filipinos. While the former is considered more artistic and the latter, more athletic and thus considered a sport, both have become very popular in the country.

At the turn of the 21st century, television and movies seemed to have been overtaken by other forms of media in influencing dance. Digital technology and social media affected social dancing in tantalizing ways, and gave birth to various art performances, foremost of which is the dance flash mob.The term refers to people mobilized through e-mail, cellular phones, and social media to do an unusual and entertaining activity in a designated place or places. It originated in New York City in 2003 when culture writer Bill Wasik astonished the world with extraordinary and quick performances by people who filled the city streets. The media called these surprising performances “flash mobs” (Walker 2013).

The dance flash mob is utilized by One Billion Rising (OBR), the global campaign targeting the participation of one billion people to end violence against girls and women. Conceptualized by Eve Ensler, author of Vagina Monologues, the campaign seeks to mobilize girls, women, men, and the LGBT (lesbians, gays, bisexuals, and transgenders) sector to gather in specific places in over 200 countries to express their protest against gender-based violence, oppression, and inequality. Through a choreography inspired by the theme song, the throngs who are mobilized feel a sense of community and solidarity. In the Philippines, simultaneous activities happen in many locations every year to celebrate OBR, a campaign that started in 2012 when a crowd led by women and girls from all social classes converged at the Liwasang Bonifacio, Manila on Bonifacio Day, Nov 30. They danced and sang “One Billion Rising Philippines.” The first dance flash mob of OBR led by the women’s group,Gabriela, OBR coordinator Monique Wilson, and feminist nun, Sr Mary John Mananzan, opened a whole day program on the 149th birthday of hero Andres Bonifacio (Guda 2012; Acayan 2012).

Soon, OBR campaigners like the Gabriela women’s party utilized YouTube and social networking sites to disseminate the choreography for the theme song “Isang Bilyong Babae and Babangon” (One Billion Women Will Rise). The pop choreography is composed of marching steps, side steps, and stomping of the feet followed by the raising of the right arm extended forward with the index finger pointing upward. The latter is the signature OBR movement symbolizing the act of rising. Other gestures and moves include clenched fists being raised overhead, clapping and waving of arms and hands, and blocking techniques from martial arts. The gestures of the choreography are named thematically such as “March,” “One Billion,” “Rise,” “Resist and Shout,” “Defend,” “Fight Back,” and “Unite.”

In 2013, principal spokesperson of OBR in the Philippines, Monique Wilson, led 5,000 people, including organizations such as the Gabriela Women’s Party, Gabriela, New Voice Company, and the Quezon City Government in Tomas Morato, Quezon City to “strike, dance, and rise” on 17 Feb. Valentine’s Day was renamed “V-Day” or “Violence Against Women Day” (Oliveros 2013). Mobilization through digital media resulted in the motley turn-out of “risers” – students in uniform, nuns, children, teachers, police, members of the entertainment business, and veiled Muslim women. There were dance numbers from the Maharlika Dance Group of the Polytechnic University of the Philippines and a poetry interpretation by members of Gabriela and the LGBT community of “Still I Rise,” a poem by Maya Angelou (Ranada 2013).

The simultaneous performance events of the 2014 “rising for justice” OBR gained the support of a greater number of people in the light of the alleged corruption and plunder cases committed by elected officials in the wake of natural and man-made calamities. The events called for action against many issues such as power hike, commercialized education, modern day slavery, and various forms of violence against women and children. There were gatherings in Metro Manila—at the University of the Philippines (UP), Diliman campus, with the UP PEP Squad impressing the crowd with their cheerdancing stunts and human pyramids; the Payatas dumpsite; Taguig City Hall; Maybunga Elementary School in Pasig City; Tondo, Manila; Mehan Garden, Manila; and the Japanese Embassy. Farmers and fisherfolk danced to protest against mining and unfair wages in Calatagan, Batangas and at Hacienda Luisita, Tarlac, respectively. Davao City had women leaders dancing by the beach while city folks participated in the dance flash mob at Rizal Park. Filipina migrant workers in Hongkong were among 10,000 people at Victoria Park calling for the abolition of modern slavery and seeking justice for Indonesian domestic worker, Erwiana Sulistyaningsih, who was tortured by her employers (New Voice Company 2014; HK Pinoy TV 2014).

OBR’s 2015 call was “rise for revolution.” The dance performances called for truth and government responsibility in the wake of the carnage at Mamasapano, Maguindanao with casualties among soldiers and civilians. The 2015 performances were participated in by women and men from indigenous groups all over the country: at the Bonifacio Shrine in Manila, the multisectoral crowd grooved to the rock group Talahib’s interpretation of “On Potok,” a song about the dispossession of the Agta people and danced to the cheery and militant theme song “Babangon na sa Rebolusyon” (Rising to Revolution). One of the more memorable performances was the dance flash mob at the quadrangle of St. Scholastica’s College, Manila where 4,000 uniformed school children, teachers, and nuns danced to the 2015 theme song. Meanwhile at UP Baguio and at the People’s Park, Cordillera women performed their folk dances to the rhythm of native gongs (UPB Obra 2015). In Davao City, indigenous groups dressed in their colorful native costumes performed their ethnic dances accompanied by traditional instruments while the main flash mob at Rizal Park had thousands from all sectors and ages, majority of whom were women and girls. On Chater Road, Hongkong Filipina migrant workers danced to the beat of the OBR theme songs “Isang Bilyong Babae ang Babangon,” “Break the Chain” and “Babangon na sa Rebolusyon” (Lau and Chan 2015).

OBR is a unique global campaign that relates the issue of women to bigger social problems. It locates domestic issues of each country in the international arena, generates international awareness about local problems, and builds solidarity across sectors, classes, and borders. The use of the dance flash mob gives the protest event a celebratory character that attracts the participation of thousands of people.

 

Epilogue

For almost 30 years after the 1986 EDSA Revolt, dance in the Philippines proved to be as dynamic and vibrant as ever. The end of the martial rule did not exactly result in overwhelming state support for the arts, let alone dance. But dance found a way of reinventing itself. Folk dance, ballet, contemporary dance, and many other popular forms such as hip hop, cheerdance, and dance flash mob were able to locate themselves in a period characterized by unrelentless shifts in political alliances, economic instability, and heightened media influence on people’s lives. The post-EDSA Revolt period may have seen and felt the effects of the global dance market on Philippine dance but it also saw the creative transformation of the country’s dances. Compelled to face the cultural realities of the late 20th and early 21st centuries, dance in the Philippines raised a number of provocative inquiries regarding its very nature, form, and function in society. Both veteran and new choreographers, dancers, scholars and critics continued to enrich Philippine dance. Different choreographic visions emerged as a number of dance practitioners decided to create works on their own, with only minimal or even no assistance from government institutions. A plurality of styles became a mark of the post-EDSA Revolt era as the various dance genres responded to aesthetic, political, economic, and cultural issues. In an era of visual consumption, Philippine dance managed to have various trajectories and refused to be constrained by financial limitations. Space was no longer an issue as dance was seen on stage, on the streets, and other public places.Throughdance andindance, the Filipinos “lived” their negotiated identities in a period of so many possibilities. Written by Myra Beltran, Joelle Jacinto, Sarah Lumba, Rosalie S. Matilac, Roselle Pineda, and Ruth Jordana L. Pison
