text:
Filipino dancers performing in other countries had their trail blazed for them, so to speak, in the 1950s and even earlier. Mention should be made of FelyFranquelli, a student of LuvaAdameit, with her character dances in the 1930s, and ManoloRosado and RubenNieto with Spanish and modern companies in Europe and Mexico in the 1950s. Also among the earlier Filipino dancers in Europe were MaribelAboitiz and EddieElejar, FelicitasLayag-Radaic, and Exequiel Banzali. There were Benjamin(Villanueva)Reyes, JaminAlcoriza, and Julie and RoseBorromeo, folk dancers RicardoReyes and his daughter Alice, and movie star Shirley Gorospe. On Broadway, MaureenTiongco was joined by TonyLlacer and ElGabriel when she starred in Flower Drum Song. Cely Carrillo also worked on Broadway, while her daughter Cynthia Onrubia danced for Jerome Robbins and later helped stage the revival of his dances for musicals. Then there were the cultural dancers who used to do mostly folkdances, but who are now doing popular entertainment numbers in hotels and clubs. Over time, more and more Filipino dancers have gone abroad for various reasons, as more and more multicultural platforms for dance in international spaces have opened up. Many have been guests or members of foreign companies, dancing as soloists in international dance productions or being invited to perform with particular companies for longer periods of time. A number of Filipino dancers have also gone as students, having been offered dance scholarships in programs hosted by dance companies or housed in university arts programs. These have allowed many young Filipino dancers to develop and learn under the tutelage of various international institutions. Other dancers become dance teachers in universities, researchers, or establish their own companies or dance groups. Still, others make their name abroad by dancing professionally in international dance competitions, gaining renown as performers as well as athletes.

Due to the growth and vibrancy of Filipino dance communities in the international scene, the categories of Filipino dancers abroad have become wide-ranging and far-reaching: those who travel abroad to dance for only short periods of time; those who stay for long-term engagements; those who migrate to or settle in particular countries where they have stayed to dance professionally or competitively; and those born abroad to Filipino parents, such as the Filipino-American dancers who have gained prominence in the United States for their performances and other dance initiatives.

Many leading Filipino dancers have performed as guests of foreign companies, for example the Hong Kong Ballet (HKB), Singapore Dance Theater, Royal New Zealand Ballet, and Ballet Company of Hawaii. Victor Madrona, who was with HKB, guested in Paris at a gala arranged by Anton Dolin. LisaMacuja, now Lisa Macuja-Elizalde, has danced in over 90 cities around the world, in Japan, Cuba, and New Zealand among others. On the other hand, choreographer TonyFabella did a piece for the HKB, and GenerCaringal has done the same for the Singapore Dance Theater.

Filipinos who have joined the HKB at various times were Benjie Toledo, Tadeo Bernales, ConradDy-Liacco, Nicole Gaston, and Jun Mabaquiao; and with City Contemporary Dance Company, Tina Fargas. Hong Kong also became home to many Filipino dancers when the Disneyland there opened in 2005. Scores of Filipino dancers auditioned for a spot in the daily shows or the parade and decimated the rosters of the ballet companies. More than a hundred of the best dancers of the Philippines left to dance in Hong Kong at the time (Mijares 2015, 79). Ballet Philippines (BP) lost all its principal dancers and soloists. After the exodus, dancers continued to leave for Hong Kong, but in more manageable numbers. Among those who joined the ranks were Jethro Pioquinto, Irish Abejero, Gisele Guarin-Abejero, Johnny Amar, and Ria Victorino.

In the early 1990s, Carlo Pacis, Carlos Garcia, and Oliver Palad were awarded scholarships to the Hong Kong Academy of the Performing Arts (HKAPA). Pacis joined the HKB, now teaches with the HKAPA, and choreographs for BP every now and then. Garcia later joined the famous Lesfamous Les Ballets Trocadero du Monte Carlo as a lead ballerina. In 2012, after winning the gold medal at the 7th Helsinki International Ballet Competition, Candice Adea accepted a contract to dance with HKB.

In Singapore , Mario Esperanza, Ric Culalic, Donato Ferrer, and Paul Ocampo danced with the Singapore Dance Theater. Like Hong Kong Disneyland, the Universal Studios in Singapore has also become a lucrative option. This is also true for performing groups on cruise ships. For half a year, dancer and choreographer Elena Laniog works with the UP Dance Company in between cruises.

In other parts of Asia and the Pacific, Biag Gaongen performed with Taiwan’s famous Cloud Gate Dance Theater from 2009 to 2011 before he moved to Austria. His former BP codancer Ronelson Yadao later joined Cloud Gate Dance Theater 2. Meanwhile, RicardoElla, BrandoMiranda, and Vivencio Samblaceño were principal dancers of the Royal New Zealand Ballet, while Sophia Radaic was a member. Ella went on to join the Australian Ballet, doing solo parts. Lucy Patrimonio-Jumawan, former director of the Silliman Dance Company, also danced and taught in Australia. Noel Dumlao later formed his own dance company there.

In the United States, the biggest number of Filipino dancers is in New York, where they work in ballet or modern companies, musicals or Philippine folkloric groups. The PhilippineDanceCompany ofNewYork was founded by Bruna Seril in 1943. The Reynaldo Alejandro Dance Theater premiered a number of Rizalian dances in New York. For a period of time, Joy Coronel, together with Ching Valdes, danced for the company, and was also with the All Nations Dance Company. DenisaReyes, Kristin Jackson, and Miguel Braganza presented their original works in New York. Jackson became a member of the Laura Dean Dancers and Musicians and teaches and choreographs in New York. )

Also, ManiyaBarredo, TinaSantos, EnricoLabayen, and OdonSabarre all used to dance in New York. ElizabethRoxas and Maxie Luna III, a nephew of LeonorOrosa-Goquingco, are members of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, and were earlier with the Joyce Trisler Company. Mercedes Mañago is with Ballet Hispanico. Cristina Escoda who danced for years with American Ballet Theater, is now its artistic administrator. Lydlyd Gaston, Cecile Santos, KristinJackson, and JoyCoronel, on the other hand, have appeared in Broadway musical productions. Tiffany Mangulabnan danced with Ballet Next in New York. Mica Bernas worked with the Carolyn Dorfman Dance Company and later began to teach in the music and arts program of BIMA, originally Berkshire Institute for Music and Arts, in Brandeis University.

American-born Filipino dancers have also made their careers in New York, such as Anthony Huxley and Georgina Pazcoguin, both of whom dance with the New York City Ballet. In 2015, Stella Abrera became the first Filipino-American principal dancer of American Ballet Theater (del Mundo 2015).

The Atlanta Ballet in Georgia has had ManiyaBarredo asprima ballerina, Maiqui Mañosa, NicolasPacaña (formerly from Dance Spectrum in San Francisco, Hawaii Ballet, and the Boston Ballet), Mia Monica, and Jorge Laico who later danced with Oakland Ballet together with Cristina Buencamino before joining several other companies around the US. He eventually became the director of Wilmington Ballet Academy in 2009. Faye Abigail Tan and Jared Tan also danced with Atlanta Ballet.

In San Francisco, California, Carlos Carvajal of the famous theatrical family choreographed for the San Francisco Ballet and his own group, Dance Spectrum. Also dancing in San Francisco were Angela del Pilar and Eloisa Enerio. The latter, who used to be with the Ontario Ballet Theater in Canada and Pacifica Ballet in California in the 1980s, eventually joined the dance faculty of the Young Americans College of Performing Arts in Corona, California in 2014. Quincy Jacinto danced with Ballet Pacifica in California. Also in California is Ruby Buted with the Contemporary Dance Company in Los Angeles.

Many other dancers have joined companies across the United States. ToniLopez-Gonzalez danced with the Washington Ballet for a number of years. Rebecca Rodriguez was with the Cincinnati Ballet in Ohio, the Dallas Ballet in Texas, and moved to Ballet Met in the same state where she is the ballet mistress. Maricar Drilon was with the Utah Ballet before becoming artistic director of Northwest Classical Ballet. Christine Rocas is with Joffrey Ballet in Chicago, and her brother Derek Rocas is with Alabama Ballet. Melissa Greco is with Princeton Ballet and Angelo Soriano is with the Disney Company.

Other Filipinos and Filipino Americans have been in the United States as students, dance teachers, and researchers, among them, Ricardo Trimillos in Hawaii; Gregoria Baty-Smith in Guam; Mario Recto and CesarMendoza in Chicago; FeSala-Villarica in San Diego, California; Loulie Dalupan in San Francisco, California; Bing Locsin in Los Angeles, California; Ted Leyson at the Jacob’s Pillow of Ted Shawn in Massachusetts; and Israel “El Gabriel,” former ballet master in an Israel ballet company and later with the University of California-Irvine; and Paul Ocampo, in Southern Utah University, teaching modern dance, ballet, folk/cultural dance, movement for actors, and composition.

There are also Filipino dance scholars in Canada such as Patrick Alcedo who is the director of the MA and PhD programs in Dance and Dance Studies in York, where he also teaches folk dance.

Filipinos have become popular not only in the United States but also around the world as winners in different competitions. Michaela “Pinky” Puno gained renown as a dancer through competitive ballroom dancing all over the US. Young figure ice skater Michael Martinez impressed the audience at the Lake Placid, New York, and at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia. He has also competed in Estonia and Germany.

ReynaldoAlejandro’s book PhilippineDance lists numerous Philippine folkloric groups in the United States,from Alaska to Wisconsin. Alleluia Panis is theater director, choreographer, and the inspiration behind Kularts, a group featuring contemporary and indigenous Philippine arts, and the Alleluia Panis Dance Theater (APDT) in San Francisco. There were also groups directed by JovitaSison-Friese, and Christine Javier. Many of them are in New York, where they were formed by former members of Bayanihan PhilippineDanceCompany, Folklorico Filipino, and other companies.

Folk dance was introduced as early as the 1950s in Stockton, California through Carmen G. Tomek’s Sampaguita Dance Troupe in Little Manila. Here, Brian Anthony Batugo, a Filipino-American born in the United States, established The Little Manila Dance Collective through the CrowdRise fundraising campaign. The project is meant to rejuvenate and sustain the presence of Filipino folk dance among Filipino communities in Stockton.

There are several studios established and run by Filipino dancers in the US. Setting up a studio geared toward teaching dance to Filipino-American children, after years of popularizing dance in media and television in the Philippines were the Aldeguer sisters, Terri and Lally, who opened the Aldeguer Sisters Performing Arts Center in Los Angeles, California in 2000. Quincy Jacinto eventually established the Riverside Dance Academy + Performing Arts in Riverside, California in 2013.

In 1994, the Pacific Northwest Ballet in Washington opened the DanceChance program, a full scholarship targeted to young, potential dancers who demonstrate aptitude for ballet in elementary schools, with priority given to minority populations and low-income students. One of its products is Eric Hipolito Jr, a first-generation Filipino-American who was the first DanceChance student to become a full member of the Pacific Northwest Ballet. His brother, Enrico Hipolito, followed in his steps and completed the same program (Duff 2012).

In Canada, YvonneCutaran, who is now with L’École des Axées Danse, was a principal dancer with Les Grands Ballets Canadiens which also hosted Barredo and ReyDizon. ManuelMolina was with Les Ballets Jazz de Montreal, Harkness Ballet, and Ballet Nuevo Mundo de Caracas (with Gloria Tobilla de la Casa). Ida Beltran who was with the Shumka Dance Company, also taught at the Edmonton School of Ballet and the Victoria School for the Performing Arts in Canada. Jojo Lucila, with whom Beltran formed the company Chameleon Dance Edmonton, choreographed for the Edmonton Festival Ballet, Edmonton Contemporary Dance Centre, Dance Unlimited, and MOD Contemporary Dance.

The United Kingdom has had its population of Filipino dancers. Mitto Castillo, considered to be the first Filipino to join a British ballet company, became principal dancer of Northern Ballet Theater in 1982. Nelly Ledesma studied in the Rambert School of Ballet and Contemporary Dance in London.

Filipino dancers were also in Europe. Lisa Macuja studied ballet on a scholarship grant at the Leningrad Choreographic Institute in Russia and was the first foreign ballerina to be invited as a soloist in the Kirov Ballet in 1984. A special issue of Dance Magazine on dance in Yugoslavia mentions a number of unnamed Filipinos. Contemporary dancer and choreographer Myra Beltran was a member of the Ballet of the Theatre Prishtina, Yugoslavia, and Ballet of Oldenburg, Germany.

Dancing in France and Switzerland were Ronnie Leonardo, Gina Mariano, and AugustusDamian who was a principal dancer with Maurice Bejart’s Ballet of the 20th Century. Damian moved on to dance in Berne, Switzerland. Ernest Mandap was a member of BP II when he was invited to join Jeune Ballet du France in 1991. He spent the rest of his career in France, coming back sporadically to the Philippines to dance with BP and to choreograph works for the company, Ballet Manila, and Airdance.

Germanyhas been the most hospitable of the European countries. LuisLayag and FranklinBobadilla danced in Heidelberg; Layag was also with Pina Bausch’s Wuppertal Dance Company. AnnaVilladolid was a dance scholar in Munich before joining the National Ballet, and eventually marrying the company’s ballet master, Tomas Mayr. Javier Picardo in Freiburg and Munster, Mary Anne Santamaria in Kassel, Robert Medina, and Nina Anonas have performed in Frankfurt. Augustus Damian first danced in Munich’s Ballet am Gartnerplatz, later joined the Bejart Ballet, and then moved to another German company.

Others who have danced in Germany are William Miller, Bettina Escaño, Mitto Castillo, and Irene Sabas. Unita Gaye Galiluyo, who moved to Switzerland in 1998, has since been performing there and in Germany. In the same year, Sonny Locsin joined Jeune Ballet de France then moved to Italy, then Germany, shortly after. Anna Villadolid who often guested with the Birmingham Royal Ballet is now in Munich and conducts dance-specific Pilates group classes at the BallettSchule Benedict-Manniegel. Armand Angeles is dancing and teaching in Germany.

Likewise, Georgette Sanchez, Ardee Dionisio, PJ Rebullida, Biag Gaongen, Marcelino Libao Jr, and Elmer Domdom have danced in Germany and France. Irene Sabas herself later moved to the Royal Ballet of Flanders in Antwerp, Belgium. With her husband, dancer David Campos Cantero she heads a dance company called the Ballet David Campos in Barcelona. Her sister Hazel Sabas-Gower used to choreograph and teach in the company, which later employed Elline Christine Damian, Aileen Gallinera, Lea Baduria, and Eduardo Espejo Jr in 2005.

Franklin Bobadilla, formerly with the Heidelberg Ballet, became a soloist with the Scapino Ballet in Amsterdam, Holland, while Paul Ocampo was with the National Ballet in Amsterdam. Don Marasigan taught and danced in Italy.

Although the presence of Filipinos and Filipino-Americans have always been felt since our first performing groups impressed their international audiences, there has been not just an increase in the number of Filipinos performing abroad over the decades but also a remarkable visibility of Filipino-Americans establishing their niches in the world of dance. Many of them have made a mark as performers, choreographers, teachers, and researchers. A number of Filipinos who have become members of companies around the world, have come home for brief periods of time to choreograph for local companies. The decades to come will definitely have more Filipinos crossing national borders and establishing careers in different countries. But with the ease in travelling afforded by the 21st century global networks, the Philippines will most probably have more of these Filipinos abroad as visiting performers, choreographers, and scholars, making the field of dance in the country more vibrant and exciting. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, updated by Joelle Florence Patrice Jacinto, Louise Jashil R. Sonido, and Ruth Jordana L. Pison

Teachers and Mentors
Conclusion

Like all other art forms, Philippine dance has had a wealth of sources for choreography. Among these sources are musical works, indigenous and folk dances, literary arts, visual arts, history, religious rituals and works, social issues, theories and other themes, and teachers and mentors. These have been used by Filipino choreographers to create penetrating, and even edgy, dance works which attest to the eloquence of imagination and kinesthetic intelligence of the county’s dance practitioners.

 

Musical Works

Musical scores have inspired Filipino choreographies. Carl Orff’s compositions from 24 Medieval poems titled Carmina Burana :Cantiones profanæ cantoribus et choris cantandæ comitantibus instrumentis atque imaginibus magicis was choreographed by Alice Reyes in 1975 and by David Campos Cantero in 1995.

Several Filipino choreographies explored opera literature in their respective renditions of Carmen ,the four-act opera of French composer Georges Bizet: Eric Cruz, for Vella Damian’s Dance Concert Company, 1976; Rene Dimacali, for his school in Bacolod; Alice Reyes’s full-evening for Ballet Philippines (BP), 1984; Alden Lugnasin, restaging Cruz’s work for BP in Carmen Trilogy, 2007; and Airdance’s Carmen de la Cruz ,2006, a Philippine version set in 1970s Manila. Also incursions into opera include Eric Cruz’s La Gitana, 1982, and Camille, 1983,based on Verdi’s Il Trovatore and La Traviata, respectively, and both to music by JeffreyChing.

Likewise a composition of Bizet, the religious hymn Te Deum, framed Denisa Reyes’s work of the same title in 1985, interweaving symbols of Christ’s death and resurrection with those referring to the country’s uncertain political future.

Compositions of the romantic period impassioned Manolo Rosado’s Claire de Lune, Arms Etude, both in 1958, and Serenata d’Amore, 1964. Some of Remedios “Totoy” de Oteyza’s ballets were done to the concertos of Edvard HagerupGrieg and Pyotor Illych Tchaikovsky’s Serenade for Strings (Theme and Variations), 1984. The latter’s music also inspired Tony Fabella in his Three Tchaikovsky Waltzes, 1983. Other compositions of the romantic period stirred Fabella in his Glazunov Variations,1984; A Dance Offering, 1986; Dancing to Donizetti, 1987; and The Company, 1991; Sabas in her Six to Borodin, 1988; and Locsin in her Four Last Songs, 1998, to Richard Strauss’s composition.


 
 

 

Western neo-classical music ignited the imagination of many choreographers. Remedios “Totoy” de Oteyza did her ballet to one of Cesar Franck’s notable works, Variations symphoniques (Symphonic Variations).In 1970, Tony Fabella mounted La Verite (The Truth) and Eddie Elejar created If Somebody Steps on Your Toe on the Fifth Beat of the Polka, Don’t Say Ouch, Polka Back, Or ... using the works of Dmitri Shostakovich. Denise Garcia created The Last Flower, 1974, and Gener Caringal completed The Rite of Spring, 1978, both to the music of Igor Stravinsky. Effie Nañas choreographed Variations D’Amour, 1975, to the modern composition of Jean Françaix. De Oteyza had a number of pieces spurred by contemporary compositions like George Gershwin’s Rhapsody in Blue, Sergei Rachmaninoff’s Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini,Aram Il’yich Khatchaturian’s Masquerade Suite, Nikolai AndreyevichRimsky-Korsakov’s Capriccio Espagnol, and MauriceRavel’s Bolero.

Popular pieces have set several dance works into the groove. Julie and RoseBorromeo, Lally and Terry Aldeguer, DouglasNierras, and other dancers worked in jazz, used popular songs, blues, and New Wave music. They have done much of the choreography for both local musicals and Broadway adaptations. BP also mounted All That Jazz, 2006, featuring works such as Gil Khan Ravago’s Miedo 5.6 and James Laforteza’s How ’Bout A Gershwin, both to the rhythm of jazz.

Integrating Eastern and Western traditions, Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa uses pangalay movement vocabulary to choreograph Western classical compositions. The integrative experiment was employed in the following works: “Canon in D Major” by Johann Pachelbel performed in 2000, 2002, 2006, and 2011; “Waltz of the Flowers” by Tchaikovsky in 2003, rendition by Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra; “Air on G String” by Johann Sebastian Bach in 2009; and “Piano Sonata in C Major” by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart premiered in 2011.

For some works, though, it is the life of a composer which propels the choreography. The life of ballet’s greatest composer Tchaikovsky was encapsulated by Basilio in his pas de trois, Perjured Hearts,1972,and later in TchaikovskyFantasy, 1982.African water drumming exemplified in Water Drums 1 by Baka Forest People of Southeast Cameroon inspired Amilbangsa to createWaterusing the fluid movements of pangalay in 2001. Similarly, the drone-like rhythm of Ravi Shankar’s sitar music complemented Amilbangsa’s pangalay choreography utilizing multiple masks covering all angles of the head, also in 2001.

 

Filipino classical composers stimulated many choreographers to produce original works in dance. Elejar created Juru-Pakal (The Enchanted Kris) in 1971 to Jose Maceda’s original music. De Oteyza choreographed Spectrum in 1972 to the composition of Rodolfo Cornejo. Joji Felix-Velarde choreographed Antonino Buenaventura’s Kulas na Batugan (Lazy Kulas) in 1973. Cora G. Iñigo’s Baile de Ayer (Dance of Yesteryears), 1974, was created to the music of Rodolfo Cornejo and an original scenario by National Artist Rolando Tinio. Fabella worked with Ramon Santos to produce Siklo (Cycle) in 1977. Caringal and Bayani de Leon produced Atlantis in 1978. Basilio worked with Nicanor Abelardo’s Sinfonietta for Strings in his Exultations, 1984, and to the same composer’s Cavatina in his Cavatina.

Local compositions have moved Filipino choreographers to create memorable dances in various forms and genres such as pangalay, ballet, and modern dance. One favorite composition is the lullabye “Sa Ugoy ng Duyan” (As the Cradle Rocks), with music and lyrics by Lucio San Pedro and Levi Celerio. The melodious and melancholic song has inspired many choreographers such as Basilio, Amilbangsa, and Denisa Reyes to create their own interpretation of the child’s longing for a mother’s affection. Patriotickundimansuch as “Bayan Ko” (My Country), composed by Constancio de Guzman and with lyrics by Jose Corazon de Jesus, fired up the imagination of many dancers and choreographers through turbulent times in Philippine history. Examples are Basilio’s Isang Lakbay,Isang Hantungan (One Journey, One Destination), 1983, and Fabella ’s Four Songs,1987. Filipino love songs alluding to the nation accompanied ballets such as Elejar’s and Vida’s respective productions of MutyangPasig (Muse of Pasig), 1980 and 1983, and Philippine Ballet Theatre’s regular staging of Fabella’s Kundiman: Noon at Ngayon .Manuel Velez’s “Sa Kabukiran” (In the Countryside) inspired Amilbangsa to create a playful pangalay choreography using fans and traditional hats, which premiered in 2000. Filipino folk songs prompted the creation of original choreography for the AlunAlun Dance Circle utilizing folk songs such as “Paruparong Bukid,” “Pamulinawen,” and “Sitsiritsit Alibangbang.”

Many songs that have touched the hearts of Filipinos have also roused choreographers. Alice Reyes’s BungkosSuite,1972, had pieces to Miguel Velarde’s “Dahil Sa Iyo,” while Alice Reyes’s Mga Babae (Women), 1987, was done to Inang Laya’s music. Basilio created several pieces to popular tunes: Alaala (Memories) and Take Me Back,1983, to music by Debuque-Consunji, A Scrapbook,1986, and Mga Awit ni Basil (Basil’s Songs) I, 1987, and II, 1989. In 1989 and 1990, Fabella created Pinoy Talaga (Genuine Filipino) and Beautiful Girls, respectively, both to Jose Mari Chan. Ryan Cayabyab’s album titled One inspired Fabella ’s LimangDipa (Five Armstretches), 1981, and Vida’s Ensalada (Salad), 1981 while his other popular songs were the material for Playing Maestro Ryan, 2005, comprised of pieces by Fabella, Lugnasin, Christine Crame, Irish Abejero, Novey Bereber, and Agustus Damian. Pop divas, such as Lani Misalucha enlivened the productions of Ballet Manila’s (BM) annual Ballet and Ballads which showcased the company dancing with sought-after singers. BP’s Damian, Morales, Lugnasin, and Mark Rosolini choreographed to new, old, local, and foreign songs in Songs in 2012.

Adaptations of foreign pop songs became popular in the 1970s and were revived by literary writers like Jose F. Lacaba in the 2000s. Amilbangsa was inspired to create original pangalay choreography for pop songs in Pangalay ng Bayan: Konsiyerto ng Tula, Salinawit, at Musika (Pangalay of the Nation: Concert of Poetry, Song-Translations, and Music), 2011,featuring choreographies for songs adapted and translated by Jose F. Lacaba such as “Moon River” / “Ilog at Buwan,” “One Note Samba” / “Mahinang Samba,” and “What a Wonderful World” / “Ba’t Ganito Ang Mundo?”

 

Indigenous and Folk Dances

Movement vocabulary from indigenous dances have been commonly integrated into ballet and modern dance pieces as inLuis Layag’s MindanaoSketches,1972; Basilio’s Mosque Baroque, 1975; DenisaReyes’s Arem, 1975, Ifugaos,1978, and FortheGods, 1984; KristinJackson’s Kolias,1984. Locsin calls “neo-ethnic” her intense stylistic exploration in Igorot,1989, Bagobo and Moslem,both 1990, and Babalyan ,1993. Amilbangsa utilized pangalay, langka (martial arts), and lunsay footwork (song-dance) in Stillness in Motion, premiered in 2000.

Contemporary dance choreographies integrating indigenous movements are seen in Al Bernard Garcia’s Sulog sa Kinabuhi (Surge of Life), 2011, based on the buklog ritual; Japheth Mari Cabling and Abigail Carlos’s Nasalapuan (Birthing), 2013,taking off fromthe binanog (hawk dance) and birth ritual of the Panay Bukidnon tribe; and Elenia Laniog and Sergio Gahol’s pieces in Nicanor Tiongson’s play Labaw Donggon: Ang Banog ng Sanlibutan (Labaw Donggon: The Hawk of the Universe), 2013, directed by Jerry Respeto.

The dance style itself may motivate choreographers to construct ballets in various degrees of adaptation or stylization. LuvaAdameit, for example, transformed Maria Clara and rural dances by performing them on pointes. Leonor Orosa-Goquingco continued this stylization, which culminated in Filipinescas.LucreciaReyes-Urtula followed suit in her folkloric ballets for the BayanihanPhilippineDanceCompany. So did the following: Borromeo in ZagalasdeManila (Young Maidens of Manila), 1968, and Kalingan, 1969; Basilio in Bailes Fil-Hispano (Filipino-Hispanic Dances), 1965, and Tropical Tapestry,1975 and 1978; Layag-Radaic in Tanan (Elopement), 1968, and Nan-Pangkat,1975; Alice Reyes in Bayanihan Remembered in 1987; and Elejar in Rigodon Sketches,1976, and Rigodon,1989.

Ballet, contemporary dance, and Latin and ballroom dancing sensually interweave their vocabularies in BP’s Tango Filipino/La Divina,2006,showcasing several works of Damian in Soledad, La Trampera, El Sol, Sueño,and Buenos Aires Hora Cero; and of Lugnasin in Never Never Never, Always Follow Me, This Is My Life. Edna Ledesma, senior Latin champion in the 2005 Blackpool Dance Festival in Blackpool, England, joined the show. She also showcased this interweaving with her own La Yumba, Che Tango Che, La Cumparista.

Contemporary movement and word games playfully combined in Basilio’s Games,1970;Merino-Santos’s Halina’t Maglaro (Come and Play), 1971; NonoyFroilan’s Iba’t Ibang Salita (Different Words), 1988; and Locsin’s Ismagol,1990, while Jojo Lucila’s Martial Ways,1991, was based on martial arts.

 

Literary Arts

Literature, both oral and written, has inspired dance artists to create stirring narratives.

Classical Greek literature impassioned choreographers to create moving, and sometimes even disturbing works. Guest choreographer Gerard Sibbritt created Phaedra,1975, William Miller choreographed Antigone,1975, and Eric Cruz did Medea,1978, for Vella Damian’s, Dance Concert Company, produced by Ballet Federation of the Philippines. Almost two decades since Cruz’s Medea, Locsin did her version in 1995.

More William Shakespeare’s dramatic and other literary forms have been explored locally in Elejar’s JulietandHerRomeo,1970; Basilio’s RoyalSonnets,1972, based on Shakespeare’s sonnets; Vida’s Romeo and Juliet,1977; Alice Reyes’s RomeoandJuliet,1981; and Myra Beltran’s The Romeo and Juliet Project, 2001. Caringal was inspired by Othello for his Vermilion Scarf,1982. TrudlDubsky-Zipper, Reyes, Vida, and Carlo Pacis did their respective versions of MidsummerNight’sDream in 1951, 1976, 1989, and 2013, respectively.

In 2013, BP celebrated the holiday season with Vida’s rendering of Charles Dickens’s A Christmas Carol .

Orosa-Goquingco worked out dances for the adapted W. B. Yeats Kalbaryo (Calvary), 1971, while Basilio took Thomas Mann’s A Death in Venice for Between Sky and Sea,1973. Federico Garcia Lorca’s play Yerma was the basis of Anton Juan’s 1982 modern dance choreography of the same title.

The Ramayana was adapted for rock-opera ballets by AliceReyes in her Rama, Hari (Rama, King), 1980, in collaboration with Ryan Cayabyab who composed the original music, and by Denisa Reyes in her Realizing Rama which premiered in Hanoi in 1998, set to the original music of Indonesian Rayahu Supanggah whose composition combined elements of ASEAN music for the contemporary dance production.

In the local scene, creation stories have been rendered in dance. The battle between the sky and the sea was reenacted in “Long Ago” in LeonorOrosa-Goquingco’s Filipinescas: PhilippineLife, Legend,andLoreinDance,1961. The work features the first man and woman, Malakas (Strong) and Maganda (Beautiful), as do JulieBorromeo’s Babae at Lalake (Woman and Man) to Ramon Tapales. Also based on the narrative is Basilio’s “Paglalang” (Birth/Creation) to Ruben Federizon’s music in TropicalTapestry,1975. In 1991, Eli Jacinto explored the Filipino creation myth where the first peoples were molded from clay by Bathala (God) in his Sa Panimula ng Buhay (At the Beginning of Life). Unfolding the origins of the Manobo people is Alice Reyes’s 2009 restaging of the 1977 Tales of the Manuvu, with libretto by National Artist for Literature Bienvenido Lumbera.

MariangMakiling of Laguna and otherdiwata(spirits) inspired many a work, including the first full-length ballet named for the goddess and staged in 1939 by AnitaKane, the ballets of EffieNañas, Sabas’s Daragang Magayon (Beautiful Maiden), 1991, and Si Banahaw, Makiling, at Juan, 1985. Other oral narratives took on new lives in dance such as in Villaruz’s work Tinagong Dagat (Hidden Lake), 1994, based on two texts: a legend about ill-fated lovers who drown and F. Landa Jocano’s book on Sulod culture.

The mythical bird,sarimanok,inspired ReynaldoAlejandro’s Legend of Sarimanok, 1968, adapted from the legend recounted by A. V. H. Hartendrop and Merino-Santos’s Sarimanok,1968. The adarna birdis the heroine of Ibong Adarna by deOteyza and IndayGaston-Mañosa for the Hariraya Ballet to music by Rodolfo Cornejo in 1970. Vida’s Adarna, 1990, on the other hand, was done to the libretto by Nicanor Tiongson. Myra Beltran’s Star Maiden, 1997, whose story signifies the marriage of heaven and earth, was based on a folktale found in the Cordillera and Bukidnon regions in the Philippines. More than a decade after, the narrative about the mythical bird returned to the stage in the contemporary dance drama Adarna,2011, by Ava Maureen Villanueva, Jed Amihan, Rhosam Prudenciado, Jr, and Mia Cabalfin. AlejandroRoces’s tale about roosters is the basis for Merino-Santos’s OfCocksandKings ,1958, about how two princes, hastening the death of their ill father, are turned into roosters by Bathala.

Epicshave inspired both folkloric and theatrical dance recreations. Early works of this kind Tomaneg at Aniway (Tomaneg and Aniway), 1975, and Labaw Donggon,for the 1985 Singapore Arts Festival. In 1997, the same episode about the Panayanon epic hero Labaw Donggon was used by Locsin for a production at the Philippine High School for the Arts. With Edwin Duero, she also reworked the Sulod epic Hinilawod into a dance drama for the Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company. Another tale about the brothers Indarapatra and Sulayman was turned into Katakata Sin Rajah Indarapatra (Stories of Rajah Indarapatra), 1968, and Juru-Pakal (The Enchanted Kris), 1971, both byElejar. Paul Alexander Morales’s rock-ballet-musical Manhid (Numb),2015, was about Philippine epic heroes come to life for the youth of contemporary times.

The fanciful world of children’s literature and fairy tales provide the narratives for Alice Reyes’s Emperor’s New Clothes,1970, and Cinderella,1981, 1984, 1989, 2002, and 2014; Vida’s The Little Tailor,1980, Peter Pan,1983, and Alicein Wonderland,1985; Nañas’s Snow White,1988; and Lugnasin’s Peter Pan’s Neverneverland, 2004.

Jose Rizal’s novels have made quite an impact on ballet and contemporary dance. His characters and narratives are found in Leonor Orosa-Goquingco’s NoliDanceSuite, 1955;Generoso-Iñigo’s Sisa,1978; Alejandro’s Rizaliana Suite; Locsin’s Salome, 1994; and Paul Alexander Morales’s Crisostomo Ibarra, 2010.

Contemporary literature has been rendered in many choreographic pieces. ArturoRotor’s story “Zita,”1982, was recreated by Basilio in dance. NickJoaquin’s works are especially popular and have provided the storyline for the following: Alice Reyes’s Amada, 1969,based on “Summer Solstice;” FelicitasLayag-Radaic’s May Day Eve,1971, Lydia Madarang-Gaston’s Anak-Bulan (Moon Child), 1976, and Basilio’s Agueda,all based on “MayDayEve.” Joaquin also wrote a fairy tale, “The Magic Garden,”for Orosa-Goquingco in 1958. JoseGarciaVilla’s “Mir-i-nisa” was choreographed byBorromeo and Layag-Radaic in 1969 and 1989, and Cruz in 1976, and Basilio worked with ChrisMillado’s Babaeng Itawes (The Itawes Woman), 1988. AlfredYuson’s poem moved Labayen in his Icarus EternallyDamned/TheDupeofTime, 1991, while VirginiaMoreno’s poems inspired Elejar’s Masks,1981, and Beltran’s Order for Masks, 2005. Poetry reading fused with pangalay choreography was performed by the AlunAlun Dance Circle in Konsiyerto ng Tula, Salinawit, at Musika, 2011. Poems interpreted in pangalay were “A la Juventud Filipina” (Sa Kabataang Pilipino) by Jose Rizal, “Nawawala Kong Tadyang” (My Lost Rib) by Marra PL. Lanot, and “Pang-alay” (Offering) by Benilda Santos. An early rendition of poetry using pangalay movements was in 1989 when Fernando Amilbangsa choreographed Merlinda Bobis’s interpretative rendition of her poem “Awit ng Babaeng Mandirigma” (Song of the Warrior Woman).

BM’s From Page to Stage, 2008, took the audience to a world of enchantment in the tales of Filipino writer Severino Reyes in Tatlong Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Three Stories of Grandma Basyang). Choreographies were done to three of his Lola Basyang stories: “Ang Prinsipe ng Mga Ibon,” (The Prince of Birds), “Ang Kapatid ng Tatlong Marya” (The Sibling of the Three Marias), and “Ang Mahiwagang Biyulin” (The Magic Violin). Alamat: Si Sibol at Si Gunaw (The Legend of Sibol and Gunaw), a children’s book drawing on the country’s treasure trove of magical tales, myths, and environmental issues written by Palanca hall of famer Ed Maranan became another inspiration for the company to launch itsalamat(legend) series in 2009.

From the 1990s onward, popular culture’s influence on dance became more visible. Caringal’s Filipino Komiks (Filipino Comics), 1993, excited the audience with memorablekomiks(comics) characters Darna and Valentina, and ten years later, Denisa Reyes staged her own rendering of a favorite Filipino heroine in her Darna .

In 2004, telenovelas also made their way to the stage, providing the format for Caringal’s short full-length ballet Isang Bagong Bituin (A New Star), to Willy Cruz’s pop songs, such as “Pangarap Na Bituin” (Dream Star),“Bituing Walang Ningning”(Star without Sparkle) and“Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas” (Wishing It Never Ends).

 

Visual Arts

Choreographers also drew inspiration from both the visual arts and visual artists. Basilio was inspired by paintings in Ode to Boticelli,1981, and CrystalConcerto and Canto to Canaletto,1983. The kinetic energy of Denisa Reyes’s Muybridge Frames, 1983, was prompted by the studies of photographer Eadweard Muybridge whose stop-action pictures paved the way for more studies on human and animal movement. Sheworked with sculptor AgnesArellano in Balimbingan (Opportunism), 1987, using the latter’s Bosch and the Hollow Men. In the 2000s, Locsin had two major works based on paintings— Sayaw Ang Kiukok (Dancing Ang Kiukok), 2005, and Sayaw, Sabel (Dance, Sabel ),2010, inspired by visual artist BenCab’s iconic“Sabel,” which is a reimagining of Noli Me Tangere ’s Sisa. Fernando Amilbangsa choreographed a four-dimensional interpretation of a ground painting in Pangalay and the Pavement Painting of Sining Obando Artists at the north park grounds of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in celebration of Philippine Independence in 2000. The pangalay suite Bangko ni Billy (Billy’s Bench),premiered in2002, was created for the functional sculpture of National Artist Napoleon Abueva to the novelty songs of Yoyoy Villame to illustrate everyday scenes in a park.

 

History

Historical events and the lives of historical personalities have become the compelling force behind numerous choreographies. Locsin’s La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution), 1996, was a contemporary ballet on the nation’s struggle against Spanish colonial rule. Fernando Amilbangsa’s Abduction of Napsa, 1992,was a pangalaychoreography based on a historical account about Sultan Mawalil Wasit’s pursuit and capture of a pangalay dancer named Napsa from Simunul island, Tawi-Tawi. A full-length historical dance drama in pangalay by Fernando Amilbangsa was Tawag sa Bantawan (Cry of the Watch Tower), 2008, performed by community artists of Maribojoc, Bohol, under the direction of Lutgardo Labad. The dance drama essays the history of the Punta Cruz watch tower during the Spanish colonial era when the Boholano were prey to slave traders.

Forceful figures in history are at the center ofAlice Reyes’s Rajah Sulayman and Generoso-Iñigo’s Gabriela, both in 1978; LuluPuertollano’s dance in Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s opera Diego Silang; Basilio’s LaLampara (The Lamp), 1980; Dwight Rodrigazo’s Indios Bravos (Brave Natives), 2004; and Lugnasin’s, Rizal Revisited/Double Takes, 2007.

Cruz choreographed a work featuring the characters Spartacus and Phrygia, and later turned them into AndresBonifacio and Gregoria de Jesus in his AngKatipunero (The Revolutionary) pas de deux. The revolutionary leader is also the subject of Caringal’s contemporary ballet Andres KKK,1996, Rodrigazo’s Itak ni Andres (Bolo of Andres), and Lugnasin’s Balintawak, all in2013.

Historical fiction has been worked into a modern dance piece byAlice Reyes in ItimAsu (Onyx Wolf), 1970, and into contemporary dance by Myra Beltran in Itim Asu: 1719-2009, 2009.

 

Religious Rituals and Works

The rituals of Philippine ethnic groups for a good harvest, to ward off evil, and to cure illnesses have been the center of dance and drama renditions. Alice Reyes produced many works inspired by traditional rituals: At a MaranawGathering,1970, depicted a ceremony in the Southern Philippines; Dugso, 1972, portrayed ababaylan’s ritual over a young man’s rite of passage; and Anting-Anting, 1973, delved into the Filipino belief in the power ofanting-antingoramulets. The Higaonondugsowasmade contemporary in DenisaReyes’s FortheGods, 1985. Rituals are periodically reenacted by the folk themselves, or staged by folk dance troupes. A common figure is the shaman who engages in possession or ecstatic dancing that transports him or her into a trance, as seen in Edward Defensor’s restaging of the ritual in Ang Babaylan,(The Shaman), 1988. Choreographer Ramon Obusan also has his reenactment of the Bagobo cleansing or anointing ritual in Pamalugu (Cleansing), 1989, in the four-daygin-umcelebration. Agnes Locsin’s Bagobo, 1990, on the other hand, focuses on the once-observed ritual for human sacrifice of Davao’s Bagobo.

Christian rituals, rites, and prayers have been used to frame numerous dance pieces: Elejar’s Misang Pilipino (Filipino Mass), 1974; Basilio’s Dark Night of the Soul, 1964, Doxology,1970, Divine Anthology,1982, Panalangin (Prayer) and Misa Filipina (Filipino Mass), both in 1984; Vida’s Pagsamba (Worship), 1976; BrandoMiranda’s Ang Misa (The Mass), 1985; and dances in Kasilag’s operatorio, Spiritual Canticles, 1991.

Religious narratives have provided the structure for several dance works.In 1964, Alice Reyes sketched the Christianization of the Philippines in 400 Years in 40 Minutes for the Eucharistic Congress in Bombay. Biblical stories have also been danced, as in Anita Kane’s TheParable of the Foolish Virgins; Basilio’s The Resurrection of Lazarus and The Rebels,1971; and Vida’s Isaiah,1982. Stories of saints and devotional literature have inspired several works: Kane’s The Life of St. Agnes;Felix Padilla’s Viaticum,1970; Alice Reyes’s Santo Niño and Chichester Psalms,1973; and Cruz’s Interior Castle,1982, to the music of Fr Manuel Maramba for the Dance Concert Company.

 

Social Issues

From rituals to religious texts, Filipino choreographers have likewise turned to Philippine realities for contemporary issues as reflected in Denisa Reyes’s Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows), with libretto by NicanorTiongson, and Basilio’s Muling Pagsilang (The Rebirth), 1986, prompted by a renewed faith in the nation after the fall of the Marcoses. A heartrending piece is Ma. Elena Laniog’s On the Wings of 44,2015, which was choreographed almost immediately after the Mamasapano massacre in Maguindanao.

In the 2000s, a range of social issues became the subject matter of choreographic works. Beltran’s Payatas: point counterpoint,2001, was on domestic violence, sexual exploitation by the church, and political opportunism while Rodrigazo’s Karga Tapas (Cut and Load), 2008, zeroed in on the miserable lives of thesacadas(seasonal plantation workers) in the haciendas of Negros Occidental.

Gender-related concerns have served as themes of numerous choreographies over the decades: Basilio’s Sweet Warfare, 1982; Jackson’s Pakiusap: Mail–Order Bride Story (A Plea: A Mail-Order Bride Story), 1991; Alice Reyes’s Mga Babae, 1987; Denisa Reyes’s Suwana: A Reconstruction of a Myth,1994; Beltran’s Unbearable Lightness,2000; BP’s Men and Women, 2005, featuring Labayen’s Stringed, Strung, Stranged, Damian’s After Whom,’L, ’ and Anecdotes of Hate, and Lugnasin’s Bound .Airdance’s Body PoliticsSeason, 2006, which included Malakas@Maganda (Malakas and Maganda)and Deus ex Machina,was a series of shows focusing on “thinking” and feeling bodies and on bodies as sites of contestations for power. Fernando Amilbangsa’s pangalay dances in celebration of International Women’s Day, Alay sa Kababaihan (Offering to Women), 2012, were created to renditions of women singers such as Inang Laya, Susan Fernandez, and Sylvia la Torre. The dance flash mob global campaign to combat violence against women and children in the Philippines began in 2012. Henceforth, the campaign has been held annually and marked by the singing and dancing to the theme song, “One Billion Rising Philippines.” Child rights is one issue that became a nationwide advocacy in the 1990s following the international recognition of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. Fernando Amilbangsa created a full dance ritual with the AlunAlun Dance Circle titled Sunset Ceremony in 2000 to ignite the international campaign to end child prostitution, child pornography, and child trafficking on the occasion of the ECPATInternational Conference on Young People’s Participation Against Sexual Exploitation of Children.

Moved to recognize the effects of long-ignored social issues, choreographers of the late 20th and early 21st century rechanneled these harsh realities into their works. Disturbed by the effects of irresponsible logging of the Philippine forests, Locsin launched her Alay sa Puno (Offering to the Trees) series, 2010-13, dealing with environmental degradation. The work’s solos and duets embodied the different parts of a tree—“Ugat” (Root), “Dahon” (Leaf), “Puno” (Trunk),” and “Sanga” (Branch), and “Bulak” (Flower).” Climate change brought extreme weather disturbances such as Typhoon Ondoy that inundated Metro Manila. These natural disasters urged Fernando Amilbangsa with the AlunAlun Dance Circle to create a full-length dance concert on Earth Day titled Alay sa Kalikasan (offering to nature), 2012, advocating environmental protection.

In a daring project dwelling on a generally unacknowledged reality in the country,Michael Barry Que and Gebbvelle Ray Selga staged their work titled Pavillion 4, 2014, on the painful complexities of mental health problems besetting many Filipinos. Labayen likewise joined BP’s Body Positive+,a dance concert to raise awareness for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), with his “swan song” Will You Still Be There, 2015 .

 

Theories and Other Themes

Another interesting influence on dance from the 1990s onward was literary theory, in particular, poststructuralism. Such crossing of influence and fields have resulted in provoking pieces. UPDC had a number of deconstructed dance classics, like Cinderella into Mariang Sinderela, ang Bagong Bayani (Maria Cinderella, The New Heroine)by Joelle Jacinto and Angela Lawenko Baguilat, 1996; Nutcracker into Cracked Nut, Maria Clara’s Colonial Dream by Veronique Duma Berdin, Desiree Peralejo Medina, and Jesusa Noveno Noel, 1997; Giselle into Ang Higanti (The Revenge) by Ava Maureen Ong and Joyce Comia Banal, 2003; Petroushka into Pedro Kusinero (Peter the Cook) by Herbert Alvarez and Ma. Elena Laniog, 2004; Swan Lake into Sa Itim, Sa Puti (The Black Swan and the White Swan) by Yasnina Jumalon and Gianella Reyes, 2009; and La Sylphide into Sylvia Ligaya (Sylvia Joy), 2014, by Jeiel Hernandez. Beltran’s Trace of a Trace, 2003, picked up Jacques Derrida’s notions of constant deferral of meanings, traces, presences, and absences, and articulates these ideas in dance as text.

 

Teachers and Mentors

Strong influences on dance also came from teachers who helped shape the careers of students and dancers: Norman Walker, Pauline Koner, Alice Reyes, Denisa Reyes, Generoso-Iñigo,Fabella, Basilio, and Locsin. Orosa-Goquingco’s pioneering work in folkloric stylization influenced many, including ReynaldoAlejandro. De Oteyza and Kane pursued classicism in their themes and teaching. Layag-Radaic followed in Kane’s footsteps as a teacher. RicardoandRobertaCassell exemplified choreographic range and practical professionalism in the crucial years of Philippine ballet. From her research on the dances of the Sulu Archipelago, Fernando Amilbangsa started the use of indigenous dances related to a classical tradition as a rich tool for choreography.

 

Conclusion

The numerous sources and influences that have become the inspiration of dance could only lead to the cultivation of its lush landscape in the Philippines. The various kinds of works, many of which defy clean categorizations, attest to the Filipino choreographers’ artistic sensibilities and efforts to continuously enrich their choreographic languages. In the bodies of the country’s dance practitioners, materials for choreographies do not only become themes or subject matter but, more importantly, serve as ways of pursuing movement. With a deep understanding of movement and propelled by a wealth of cultural texts, practices, and issues, Filipino choreographers have always worked with, around, and even against existing dance forms, creating compelling works of diverse idioms.
